business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: â€”Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 352 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian Government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 383 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 494 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(a) a proposal has been made by the Department of Transport to build a major no-curfew international airport in Sydney's western suburbs;
(b) airports and attendant infrastructure are a major source of air and noise pollution;
(c) Western Sydney already suffers from the worst air pollution in Australia;
(d) an additional airport in the Sydney airshed will only serve to greatly increase such pollution; and
(e) an airport in Sydney's west will harm the lifestyle and wellbeing of citizens living and working within the Sydney airshed.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate not pass any bill which would lead to the construction of any new airport within the Sydney airshed.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 252 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate, the deleterious effects of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. Make available the draft text of the Agreement
2. Make a public statement about its intentions with regard to the signing of the MAI, detailing the beneficiaries of the Agreement, and accountability measures for all corporations
3. Not sign the MAI unless substantial amendment is made, including the observance of international agreements including environment, labour, health and safety and human rights standards
4. Extend the deadline for signing the MAI to enable full and proper public consultations to be held

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 565 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate decisions by the Howard Government affecting the price and availability of medicines.

The decision to remove (delist) a number of drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and also the decision to pressure people to switch to cheaper, older and less effective drugs, will disadvantage the less well off in our community who will not be able to afford the best most suitable drugs, the drugs their doctors have prescribed for them.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate recognises that these changes are unfair. We call on the Government to reverse these decisions immediately.

talk.start.para: Senator West(from 77 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembed in Parliament.
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House support of the undersigned for the establishment of radiotherapy services at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will commend the establishment of radiotherapy services at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga to treat cancer patients residing in the southwest region of New South Wales and north eastern Victoria.
The House is advised that the Minister for Health, Dr Andrew Refshauge, MP has given `in principle' support to the proposed country-located "sister" clinics at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga.

We, therefore, respectfully request the House to call on the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Michael Wooldridge MP, to urgently approve the provision of these vital radiotherapy services for country cancer patients who are now disadvantaged by being forced to attend metropolitan based services for long periods of treatment.

(1) Examination of developments in contemporary Japan, with particular reference to:

talk.start.para: â€”I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ€”
(a) notes that the Government has, after 80 years of public service, privatised the court reporting agency, Auscript;
(b) notes that, as a result of the decision, hundreds of loyal employees of Auscript, all of them women, have lost their jobs;

(f) notes with satisfaction that the full bench of the commission, in a decision handed down in March 1998, found in favour of the workers and their union and ordered the Government, through the Attorney-General's Department, to pay the workers an estimated $2 million in severance pay, and that the commission also gave them the opportunity to access pro-rata long service leave and lump sum superannuation benefits; and
(g) condemns the Government for its callous and heartless disregard for loyal, dedicated and long-serving employees of the Commonwealth.

debateinfo.title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

talk.start.para: â€”A message has been received from the House of Representatives agreeing to the following bill without amendment:

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ€”

The commencement of the Aged Care Act 1997 in October of last year saw the implementation of legislation that guarantees an aged care system that maintains the comfort and dignity of older Australians in a way that is viable and sustainable. However, as with any reform of major significance, it has become apparent that there are some issues that require finetuning and others that relate to the administration of the act that need addressing.

In November 1997 the Government announced a number of measures that will promote our vision of a secure future for older Australians. These measures maintain the integrity of the Government's structural reforms while addressing issues raised by some older Australians. I am very pleased to introduce today the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 which will see the implementation of these measures.

The Government remains committed to bringing real improvement to nursing homes, too many of which are simply in no fit state to be a safe, comfortable and dignified home for older Australians. The accommodation bond arrangements for residential care were designed to provide a source of much needed capital to be used for the upgrading of nursing home buildings.

However, it became apparent that some older Australians believed that they may not be able to afford the bond or would have to sell their homes to pay it. The Government has listened and responded by introducing an accommodation charge, instead of a bond, for nursing home level residents. The accommodation charge maintains the principle of people making a contribution to improving the quality of their accommodation, where they can afford to do so. But it also takes account of the special circumstances of nursing home level residents and gives certainty in what can be a difficult time.

The accommodation charge has been capped as a daily rate of up to $12 a day, or $6 a day for assisted residents, for a maximum of five years. Concessional residents, or those who qualify under hardship provisions, will not be required to pay any charge. The bill extends many of the consumer protections that currently apply in relation to accommodation bonds and requires aged care providers to meet a range of responsibilities in relation to the charge.

These new arrangements will provide flexibility and choice for residents in how they pay the charge. For example, residents may choose to rent their family home and to use this income to pay the charge. This bill amends the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlement Act to exclude this rental income and the value of the property from the pension income and assets test.

The Government also remains committed to those who devote themselves to caring for older people in their own homes. The bill alters from five to two years the period during which a resident's home must have been occupied by a carer in order for the resident to qualify as a concessional or assisted resident. This change will make it easier for residents to qualify and attract a higher level of Government subsidy. It will also mean that carers will be able to remain in the family homeâ€”further recognising the vital role that carers play.

The bill also changes the current requirement for concessional or assisted resident status to be rolled over where a person moves between services. Concessional or assisted resident status will now be assessed whenever a resident enters a new service. This will enable a change in status with any change in circumstances. This is a more equitable arrangement that matches the level of Government support with a resident's ability to contribute towards the costs of their care.

The bill also addresses anomalies in the new aged care legislation in relation to the revocation of approved provider status and the imposition of sanctions for breaches of responsibilities under the previous system. Provisions will be introduced that will enable the Commonwealth to take strong and decisive action against these providers, for example, where they have been convicted of serious crimes such as the abuse of residents or fraud. The Government is committed to ensuring that only those providers who meet their responsibilities will be able to provide care to the most frail and vulnerable in our society.

It has also come to the attention of Government that the responsibilities of providers in relation to the kinds of fees residents and intending residents can be asked to pay need to be clarified. The bill contains provisions that makes it very clear that residents cannot be asked to pay additional fees, for example, to be placed on a service's waiting list, beyond those already allowed by the Aged Care Act.

Lastly, the bill makes provision for a number of minor changes to facilitate better administration of the Aged Care Act. These include clarifying a number of definitions and providing for an `entry form' to enable people to be advised about their level of income tested fees as soon as possible. It also clarifies rules about pre-entry leave and entering accommodation payment agreements where a person has a mental impairment and the keeping of essential aged care service records in English. An amendment is also made to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Simplification Measures) Act to correct a minor cross referencing error.

These changes are the result of the Government listening to and responding quickly to address these issues. We have acted in a timely and sensitive way to keep the benefits of the aged care reforms flowing to consumers now and into the future.
The accommodation charge will ensure the continued improvement of nursing home buildings and improved services for consumers.

The other amendments clarify and improve some of the current arrangements set out in the Aged Care Actâ€”the legislation that has seen the most significant reform to the provision of aged care in Australia over the last decade. The legislation that encourages innovation, flexibility and creativity in service delivery and planning.
Ordered that the further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned to the first day of sitting in the winter sittings, in accordance with standing order 111.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the following matters be referred to the Committee of Privileges for inquiry and report:

(1) Whether Senator Parer failed to declare a relevant interest before a division in the course of proceedings on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 on 4 December 1997, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2) on 28 May 1997, or on a motion to disallow the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations (Amendment) on 23 May 1996, or on any other relevant debate or division.
(2) Whether Senator Parer committed a contempt in regard to these debates or divisions.
(3) Whether Senator Parer knowingly failed to provide details of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests and whether any contempt was committed in that regard.

This parliament is the heart of our democracy. If it is to be respected by the people, if it is to be robust and healthy in itself, it must function free of corruption and protected from the taint of being abused by elected representatives for self-invested motives. Elected members must ensure not only that we are not financially advantaged by our use of the enormous power which the people of Australia have voted us, but that we are seen to be above such a conflict of interest.

For that very reason, in 1994, the Senate established its Register of Pecuniary Interests. The register came into being after a decade of opposition by the coalition, at the behest of the then Labor government in the wake of the sports rorts affair of 1993. The register requires each of us as senators to declare interests such as shares and real estate which may be enhanced by our actions while in office. Moreover, we are obliged to declare such interests in the Senate when speaking or voting on matters which affect them.

They are very modest requirements. They fall far short of the expectation at local government level in Australia, or even of the House of Representatives standing order 193 that an elected representative stands down from a vote on matters affecting her or his interests. As senators know, on several occasions over the last two years, I have drawn attention to the standing orders requiring senators to declare their interests. Those occasions have included important votes on the woodchip industry, mining and family trusts. The response has not been one which indicated that every senator appreciated the importance of disclosing interests. Some senators have heaped scorn on the idea or, at least, my determination to make it work and to make senators properly accountable according to our standing orders.

Remarkably, there have been four separate references to the Senate Standing Committee on Senators' Interests, to try to have the requirement for disclosure either stopped or reducedâ€”or at least reviewed. That is: while the requirement was dishonoured, no one worried; when I insisted it be observed, there were immediate moves to get rid of it. This week there has been yet another reference to the senators' interests committee to have the standing orders reviewed. In other words, if senators object to rules requiring that they come clean on potential conflicts of interest, do not insist that senators conformâ€”insist that the rules go.

However, in the past, the committee has stood firm. Let me read from its ruling of September last year entitled Why declarations of interest during debate and prior to division should continue. After laying down eight potent reasons, the committee concluded:
In the current climate, abolition of the requirement to declare relevant private interests in debates and divisions would be seen as a backward step and would attract media attention and criticism.

The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, has admitted that he failed to list very large interests in the register. He was, of course, aware of the register because he had declared other interests. But in the case of his shareholdings in Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd, he failed to disclose.

At the outset, it is as clear as day that if any ministry courts conflicts of interest, it has to be the ministry for resources and energy, Senator Parer's ministry. There could be no more pertinent an interest than coalmining. Yet Senator Parer left off the register this large component of his interest in coalmining, said to be worth $2 million. The standing orders are explicit. Let me quote:
(2) That any senator who:
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests . . .

shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly, but the question whether any Senator has committed such a serious contempt shall first be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report and may not be considered by any other committee.

Senator Parer knew the register well enough to enter other assets. He was well aware of his Queensland Coal Mining Managementâ€”QCMMâ€”shares because he previously chaired the company. It takes an illogical leap of imagination to conclude other than that he knowingly failed to register his interests.

If it were a small gift, a plane ride or a dinner out, it may not have figured prominently enough in events to ensure that his memory would be prompted to make the needed entry into the register. But $2 million in shares is a major, classic asset for which the register was set up by the Senate. To believe Senator Parer's explanation, that these assets were simply overlooked, is to believe the man who said that he forgot to register the car because it was a Rolls Royce.

When it comes to the matter of declaring an interest during debate here in the chamber, there are a number of occasions when a major crossover of interests has occurred between Senator Parer's personal holdings and the matter before the Senate. Let us take the example of 4 December last year. I drew the attention of Senator Parer and everyone else here to the need for senators with interests in mining to declare them when voting on the native title legislation. A number of senators made such a declaration, as you will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Parer did not. On 28 May 1997, there was a long debate and then votes on the issue of diesel fuel rebatesâ€”a matter involving more than $1 billion. Senator Parer led the debate for the government. He declared no interest, yet answers to questions I later put to him have revealed that his company, QCMM, the company in which he had shares, had benefited in 1995-96 by $1.7 million from that rebate; that is, a cheque for $1.7 million was given to the company in which he held a major holding, and he knew it. Can there be a clearer conflict of interest? There cannot.

Senator Parer knew the score. He knew of his interest. He knew how the diesel fuel rebate system meant government handouts to mining companies, including his. After all, he was the minister, yet he failed to tell the Senate, as required by the Senate standing orders, by the law.

In summary, Senator Parer has knowingly committed the most flagrant breaches of the Senate standing orders. He has treated the Senate with contempt. In October 1997, in the debate on whether a matter relating to the Australian Law Reform Commission should be referred to the Privileges Committee, Senator Harradine said this:

I do not want to canvass all of the other matters that have been raised during this debateâ€”such as whether the person who committed an act which may be held to be in contempt knowingly committed that act or had any reasonable excuse for commission of that act. These are matters which, it seems to me, are more properly dealt with by the Privileges Committee.

He added very firmly that the matter should go to the Privileges Committee because it involved `the protection of the processes of this parliament'. I could not agree more. In May last year, in voting against a move to have matters relating to Senator Colston investigated by the Privileges Committee, Senator Harradine averred that justice demanded that the Australian Federal Police inquiry be allowed to take its course and not be jeopardised by a parallel inquiry of the Privileges Committee. He said:
In any other circumstances, I would feel that the matter ought to proceed immediately to the Privileges Committee.

There is, of course, no police inquiry on this occasion and, as Senator Harradine said, the matter should proceed immediately to the Privileges Committee. If ever there was a clear-cut case, this is it. Senator Parer has, prima facie, treated the Senate standing orders with contempt. The Privileges Committee must investigate the matter. For us to scupper that objective would be to risk the Senate itself being held in contempt by the people of Australia. I urge fellow senators to defend the standing orders and to defend the Senate itself by supporting this motion.

talk.start.para: â€”This is, of course, a political witch-hunt. Senator Brown has no interest in defending the standing orders in this place. For him and his small band of supportersâ€”and there is only a small band that remain these daysâ€”this is the ultimate revenge. It is revenge against somebody who had a background in the mining industryâ€”those that the Greens hate and will forever hate. What a chance for Senator Brown, as the leader of that small band, to come in here and force Senator Parer to go off to the Privileges Committee to justify himself. It may cheer Senator Brown's small band of supporters, but it should not succeed because a case has simply not been made out.

speech.para: For the Labor Party, of course, it is simply a scalp that they seek. They have no interest in this matter in terms of any merit or otherwise. What they have made clear from the outset is that they want another ministerial scalp as part of what they see as a process of return to government.

There has been a convenience of motive here between Senator Brown with his prejudices and Senator Faulkner and his team on behalf of the Labor Party, who have jumped on the bandwagon of Senator Brown's motion in what they see as an opportunity to place further pressure upon Senator Parer. We are talking about an honourable senator. No-one has made any suggestion that Senator Parer has sought any personal advantage in this matter. He is, I think, highly respected within the community as a very competent and able minister. That means that the Labor Party must try all the harder to bring him down.

The issue is whether it is appropriate for the Privileges Committee to be used by the Labor Party and Senator Brown in this political exercise. The case I put is that, in these circumstances, it is totally inappropriate. Why is it inappropriate? It is particularly inappropriate because judgment has already been passed by the Labor Party. One only has to recall the comments made by Senator Faulkner in this place when he shouted across the chamber, `He is guilty as charged', to realise how inappropriate it would now be to ask the Privileges Committee, including members of the Labor Party under the discipline of Senator Faulkner, to pass an objective judgment on this matter. Nothing would bring the Privileges Committee into greater discredit than for it to be abused in that way.

Senator Faulkner is not the only who has prejudged the issue. Senator Ray and Senator Cook have also done so. If honourable senators so wish, I will go through the Hansard and point to each occasion on which it is demonstrated that the Labor Party has prejudged the matter. Let me refer to a few examples. On Monday, 23 March this year, Senator Faulkner said in this place, `He is guilty as charged.' And he did not just say it, he shouted it. Can there be a clearer indica tion of a judgment having been made than that statement?

In the same presentation he said that this was `a flagrant conflict of interest'. He went further when he said that `the opposition has exposed his'â€”that is, Senator Parer'sâ€”`deceit in this matter'. He continued:

What we say now is that this proves that Senator Parer is guilty as charged. The only issue remaining is the sentence, and there is only one appropriate sentenceâ€”that is, that Senator Parer should resign or be sacked by the Prime Minister.

Given those comments, how can the Labor Party seriously expect this issue to go to the Privileges Committee to determine whether or not Senator Parer has committed a breach? It is totally inappropriate. The members of the Labor Party would have no alternative but to accept the direction of the party hierarchy. In the past, we have seen the sort of discipline that the Labor Party imposes upon its senators, and any attempt to come in here and argue, as no doubt Senator Faulkner will, that in some way the Labor Party will now be free of any party restraint and take an objective and independent view, would be seen to be farcical.

I regret to say it, but Senator Faulkner seems to have muffed it again. By prejudging this issue, he has determined that it would be inappropriate for it to be considered on its merits by the Privileges Committee. As I said, it was not just Senator Faulkner. Other members of his merry band were part of the conspiracy. On the same dayâ€”23 Marchâ€”Senator Ray said:
When you read Senator Parer's declaration to the Prime Minister today, there is an admission of guilt.

Senator Cook said that `the web of deceit is growing by the day'. So the charge has gone from `guilty as charged', to `admission of guilt', to `web of deceit' by three of the leading players of the Labor Party in this place on 23 March 1998.

Senator Cook came back the following day and reinforced it even further when he said, `This is a case in which there is a clear breach of public duty . . . '. He did not say, `I allege a breach of public duty'; he said that it was a clear breach of public duty. Senator Cook had determined that guilt had been proven in this case. He went on to say, `There is no question about that.' So on 24 March, Senator Cook said that there was no question on the issue of guilt. Yet, today, the Labor Party is going to argue that the Privileges Committee, including members of the Labor Party, should determine whether or not a case has been proven. It is farcical.

On 12 March, Senator Faulkner used the words `overwhelming evidence', and a little later he said that it is `a serious breach'. I draw your attention to the relevant provisions of the standing orders on what the committee has to determine. In the terms of the standing orders, the Privileges Committee would have to determine whether there has been a serious contempt, but on 12 March Senator Faulkner said that there was a serious breach.

That is further evidence of the Labor Party having prejudged this issue. It has already made up its mind. That demonstrates how farcical it would be to send this matter to the Privileges Committee to seek to address this issue on its merits. To quote further from Senator Faulkner, on 12 March he said:

Does Senator Parer possess shares or similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of his portfolio responsibilities? The answer to that question is yes, he does. Has Senator Parer divested himself of these shares and interests? The answer is, of course, that he has not. Is he in compliance with this much discredited prime ministerial code of conduct? No, he is not.

In these circumstances, to even suggest that the Privileges Committee would be the appropriate body to consider the matter is ultimately to undermine public confidence in a very important institution within the Senate's structure. The committee would be asked to make a determination on the merits, when the second largest party in this chamberâ€”the Labor Partyâ€”with members on this committee, has already determined that guilt has been proven. Of course, Senator Brown, the mover of the motion, is part of this political exercise as well.

But, apart from that reason, unfortunately, Senator Faulkner in his leadership of the Labor Party, has lost the opportunity to appropriately refer this matter to the Privileges Committee. Of course, when the allegation was made, it should then have been referred rather than the Labor Party seeking to make two weeks of political gain by making, as I said the other day, an allegation and stating it as fact, that is, that the case has been proved. By doing that, they have simply lost the opportunity to go to the Privileges Committee on merits. There are also a number of serious issues that I think the Senate should look to as a lesson for the future in relation to this type of matter.

There are before us three separate and distinct issues. The first of the issues raised by Senator Brown is the provision of the standing orders that requires senators during a debate to stand in this place and indicate any potential relevant interest. One can only sayâ€”and I say it with a touch of embarrassment because we were all part of the drafting of these standing orders or at least the debate on these standing ordersâ€”that this particular provision is ambiguous, to say the least. It is highly unclear, for example, whether, if a particular interest has appeared in a senator's declaration, it is necessary for the senator to stand again in this place. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, would have experienced the confusion of senators around the chamber on that particular issue.

It is also highly unclear whether the relevant interest would cover something that we commonly refer to around here as a generic interest. For example, if a minister for primary industry is a farmer, should he have to stand on every occasion and say, `I'm a farmer'? Or should he only have to stand if there is a potential direct benefit for him in relation to part of his agricultural pursuits from the piece of legislation that is being debated in this chamber?

These are serious issues that ought to be contemplated by the committee in charge of this particular process. Clarification should ultimately be debated in this place and written into the standing orders.

Senator Brown raises three specific examples here. He says that Senator Parer should have risen in this place because of a potential conflict of interest in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill. In that specific instance, as we have heard from Senator Parer, he had no knowledge of any conflict, direct or indirect. He subsequently has learnt that there may have been a Wik claim on some interest that he might have. But, if he had no knowledge of that at the relevant time, obviously it does not apply in any event.

The next two examples fall more clearly within the level of confusion that I am talking about. The first of these is the issue in relation to diesel fuel rebate. Senator Brown says that Senator Parer had an obligation to stand on that issue because, if he indirectly had some mining interest, then he could serve to gain. But, of course, that is a classic case of the type of generic issue that applies to anyone who has any interest in the mining industry, rather than applying specifically to any particular mine.

But, beyond that, what Senator Brown has not said in this place is that the government's reforms chopped $60 million off the outlays in relation to diesel fuel rebate. So, if you take Senator Brown's argument to its logical conclusion, he is asking Senator Parer to stand in this place and say, `I've lost some benefit through this legislation that's being debated in here.' Surely that is not what Senator Brown is suggesting. It demonstrates how inappropriate it is in these circumstances to stand.

The other instance raised by Senator Brown is the decision of the government to remove export licensing. Of course, that was a whole of government decision and an announcement was made prior to the last election. In those circumstances not only is it generic but, in an instance where it is a whole of government decision, is there any obligation on a particular minister?

There is no doubt in my mind that these issues require clarification. They should be considered by the Senators' Interests Committee, and I hope it will do so in due course. But any suggestion in the background of confusion in relation to this particular provision that Senator Parer should be sent to the Privileges Committee so that the committee can examine whether or not he should have stood is quite farcical.

There are so many instances in this place when senators have been unclear as to wheth er their circumstances fall within the standing order, clause 5, as adopted on 17 March 1994. Is Senator Brown suggesting that in each and all these instances these senators should be referred? Of course he is not. This instance is simply, as I said, Senator Brown of the Green movement seeking the ultimate revenge against someone who has a background and history in the mining industry.

The other matters relate to what is or is not in Senator Parer's specific declaration. The one that I think senators on the other side would say is the one of substance is that which relates to Senator Parer's family trust. The family trust was stated in the Register of Senators' Interests. What was not stated was the investment of the family trust. Clearly, in the past, senators were unclear as to whether beneficial interests had to be stated. There is no dispute about that, because the Senators' Interests Committee told us so. We find that it issued a letter on 20 March 1997 seeking to clarify the matter, therefore acknowledging, of course, that the relevant provision of the standing order in that regard, which is clause 3 of the resolution of 17 March 1994, is also ambiguous.

In its letter of 20 March 1997, the committee said that beneficial interests, the shareholdings of a trust, should in fact be disclosed. As we know, in this instance, Senator Parer has informed the Senate that he does not recall receiving that letter. I would say that the committee has erred in fact. The committee should have not simply issued an explanatory memorandum but sought to change the terms of clause 3 in the resolution of the Senate to state the obligation that the committee is suggesting should be incurred as a matter of practice. If that had been done, the obligation would have been clearly within the standing orders and we would have all understood our particular responsibilities.

There is not only the issue of those senators who may not have seen this particular letter from the committee that was deliveredâ€”we all, of course, get thousands of letters; I am told that I get some 16,000 letters a yearâ€”but also a very serious issue as to what is the standing of this particular change to the explanatory rules. I understand that it is being suggested by the Labor Party in its witch hunt of Senator Parer that the explanatory memorandum that was sent out by the committee has the same standing as the resolution that has been passed by the committee itself. In doing so, it is relying upon that part of the standing orders which says that the committee is to determine the form which the register will take. That, I would put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is clearly a misinterpretation of what these provisions provide.

The form is really the form of the document that is to be lodged within the parliament, not the obligation of a senator. The obligation of a senator has to be the obligation that has been clearly set out in the standing orders. The committee has acknowledged not only that the obligation is ambiguous in this regard but also that there has been an accepted practice that it did not include an obligation to declare beneficial interests.

So how in those circumstances can it be seriously arguedâ€”if it is to be argued seriously, which it is not because this is just a political exerciseâ€”that the Privileges Committee should now look at Senator Parer's instance and determine whether there has been a serious contempt of the Senate? To simply ask the Privileges Committee to do that in these circumstances, I would suggest, would be an abuse.

The other issue that has been raised is what Senator Parer refers to as his superannuation interest. This group of companies had a fund in which former employees and directors were given some interest. Of course, there is a technical question as to whether that was declared, but that is not the case here. The case is what were its investments, and that is too indirect to be part of any reasonable charge. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Let me commence my contribution by going to the motion before the Senate, which the opposition has examined very carefully. In terms of the orders of the Senate on senators' interests, it is quite clear that, in relation to part 3 of Senator Brown's mo tionâ€”`whether Senator Parer knowingly failed to provide details of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests and whether any contempt was committed in that regard'â€”this is an appropriate matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report.

speech.para: I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the second point under `Registration' in the order of the Senate makes clear in relation to its order on senators' interests:
(2) That any Senator who:
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests by the due date;

shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly, but the question whether any Senator has committed such a serious contempt shall first be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report and may not be considered by any other committee.

It is unarguable that it is proper for that matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee. In relation to the justification for parts 1 and 2 of this motion, I have to say that the standing orders perhaps are less clear, and it is worth examining why part 5 of the senators' interests order is worded the way it is. Part 5â€”`Declaration of interests in debate and other proceedings'â€”is worded differently. That part of the order, of course, relates to parts 1 and 2 of Senator Brown's motion, which is before the chair. The issue here is whether that is a matter that is appropriate to be dealt with by the Privileges Committee.
The opposition believes that to be the case, given the circumstances we have and the resolution agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988. Part 6 deals with matters constituting contempts and says:

That, without derogating from its power to determine that particular acts constitute contempts, the Senate declares, as a matter of general guidance, that breaches of the following prohibitions, and attempts or conspiracies to do the prohibited acts, may be treated by the Senate as contempts.
Subpart 8 of matters constituting contempts is headed, `Disobedience of orders', and reads:
A person shall not, without reasonable excuse, disobey a lawful order of the Senate or of a committee.

On that basis I think a case can be made, perhaps not as clear as the case in relation to knowingly failing to provide details of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests. But clearly part 5 of the senators' interests order is an order of the Senate. I think under the Senate standing orders disobedience of an order is a matter that can be strongly argued as one that constitutes a contempt.

At the commencement of this debate it is worth recalling very briefly some of the history in relation to the introduction of disclosure rules on pecuniary interests in the Senate. In government the Labor Party tried for years and years to introduce a similar system to that which the then Labor government had introduced in the House of Representatives in 1984. The then coalition in opposition delayed, obstructed, filibustered in every way that was possible and managed in fact to delay introduction of disclosure rules until 1994.

We think that is absolutely a disgraceful performance from the coalition, bearing in mind that the House of Representatives had in place a similar system for 10 years before the Senate. I remind senators that we were reduced to ensuring that we had introduced a voluntary system of declarations of senators' interests which other minor parties and Independent senators engaged in when the then opposition, the Liberal and National parties, did not cooperate.

When we circulated our draft proposal in March 1994 we omitted the requirements for senators to declare relevant interests in debate or prior to voting in a division. That is part 5 currently in the standing orders on pecuniary interests. That was omitted. We had taken the view at that time that a comprehensive register of interests, together with strict guidelines and application of those guidelines for updating declarations, would make such a requirement redundant.

It was Senator Hillâ€”this is the truth of the matterâ€”who then was the opposition leader, who took a very strong contrary view to that of the Labor Party. I want to remind Senator Hill of what he said at the time. It stands in stark contrast to what he says today. In Hansard on 19 August 1993, on declaration during votes and proceedings, he said:

There are many other concerns that we have in relation to the form. We are amazed that, for some reason that is not explained by the ministerâ€”but subsequent speakers on the other side might fill the gapâ€”the government has removed from this draft the provision for ad hoc declarations which it had included in previous proposals. Notwithstanding the lodgment by a senator of a statement of registrable interests, in previous drafts a senator was to be obliged to declare any relevant interest at the beginning of a speech in the Senate chamber and after a division is called, if they propose to vote in that division.

That has been a principle that we have adhered to on this side of the chamber. We have always accepted that if a senator, who has a conflict of interest, is going to participate in speaking or in voting, then the interest that could be in conflict should be made clear so that the public and the parliament can understand the position of that senator. Why has the government taken out that obligation, that it was going to put in previous proposals, in the draft that is before us today?
We are of the view that if this is to proceed, and the numbers in this chamber seem to indicate that it is, such an obligation should be reinserted, and we have an amendment to that effect.

He goes on to argue the case further. It was Senator Hill who demanded that this part of the Senate standing orders be included in the orders on senators' interests. It was not the then government, who thought it would be enough to have a full and complete disclosure and very regular updates in the Senate declaration of interests, but Senator Hill who demanded that this go in. But today he says, `It doesn't matter. Just ignore that. We don't care about that any more.' We were persuaded by Senator Hill's arguments in order to ensure that we had a registry of pecuniary interests in the Senate and we went along with the reinsertion of that requirement in the disclosure provisions. It is just extraordinary that Senator Hill could be so hypocritical as to come into the chamber today and argue that that particular provision is now redundant, is now meaningless.

I have to say that what we have saidâ€”some senators have made the point quite regular lyâ€”is that if a senator has properly and fully declared his or her interests in the register of pecuniary interests and if that register is up to date you can mount an argument that it is not necessary on every single vote or division before the Senate to make that interest known again if it is in the public arena in a document that can be accessed by all and it is an accurate record of the pecuniary interests. So you can mount that case, and some senators have argued that position consistently.

But in Senator Parer's case the fact is that he at no time has that as a defence because at no time during a vote or division, during the course of proceedingsâ€”whether it be on the native title amendment bill, customs and excise, the customs prohibited export regulations amendment, or other debates and divisionsâ€”did Senator Parer declare an interest and he did not declare his interest in the pecuniary interests register. So you cannot argue in the case of Senator Parer that he had complied with either the letter or the spirit of the pecuniary interest requirements in this chamber.

We have heard Senator Hill argue today in a very confused way that, because I said that Senator Parer was guilty as charged in relation to the issue of conflict of interest, this matter should not go to the Privileges Committee. What I said and what I stand by, and so does the opposition, is that Senator Parer has been guilty of conflict of interest. I note that Senator Hill now changes the definition of conflict of interest as the Prime Minister has changed the definitions included in his own ministerial code of conduct. But it is a changed definition. On 4 May 1992, the same Senator Hill said this:

We have no problem with the question of conflict of interest; that is quite clear. If one has a potential conflict of interest, we accept the obligation to disclose it. We will always do so and suffer the consequences of not doing so . . .
That was the hypocrite who now leads the government in this chamberâ€”Senator Hill.

talk.start.para: â€”Withdraw!

â€”I withdraw. The situation is this: Senator Hill comes in and says, `Oh, you can't take this motion seriously from Senator Brown because Senator Faulkner said that Senator Parer is guilty as charged. Senator Ray and other opposition senators have made comments about Senator Parer in terms of conflict of interest and the application of the Prime Minister's guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility to Senator Parer's behaviour as a minister.' That is high farce. The question before the Senate is the issue of breach of Senate standing orders. That is what is before the Senate.

speech.para: In relation to the issues of conflict of interest and the issue of the application of the Prime Minister's code, it is proper for parliamentarians and the public to reach judgment on them. I think the parliament has dealt with this issue very seriously. I have certainly reached a judgment in relation to conflict of interest and the application of the Prime Minister's code. I have to say that I think the public has too. You only have to read editorials in every major newspaper in Australia. So it is not just the parliament which has reached conclusions about this; the public has reached conclusions on this, and they are entitled to.

Why cannot we say that the Prime Minister's redefinition of his own code of conduct and the issue of conflict of interest in the way that Senator Parer has fulfilled or not fulfilled his obligations as a minister are not proper matters for parliamentarians and the public to reach judgment on? We have reached judgment on that, but that is not what is going to the Privileges Committee. This is how thin the arguments are of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What we would have before the Privileges Committee is whether Senator Parer knowingly failed to provide details of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests. That is the matter, and that will be a matter for the Privileges Committee to determine. It really hinges on the word `knowingly'.

It really is an open and shut case that he failed to do so, that he failed to respond to the letters on not one but two occasions following a statement by Senator Denman in the chamber. Senator Parer answered a question by me in question time and said, `Yes, it was a breach. Yes, it was a technical breach of the requirements.' The issue is whether he did it knowingly or not. It is an unarguable case that he failed to respond to those requirements. Not one person, except Senator Hill apparently, can come forward and put such an absurd statement to the Senate.

The difficulty we have here is that Minister Parer has failed to disclose shares he holds in his own name which he has held in his own name since before he became a minister in 1996. You cannot argue that he has not failed to disclose them. He admits it. He has failed to disclose them. The issue is: did he do it knowingly? Did he deliberately connive to fail to disclose those particular holdings for personal gain? That is the issue that has to be determined by the Privileges Committee, not whether he did it or not. We know what he has failed to do. We know about his failure to declare his shares in the trustee company of the family trust. Everyone knows that he has failed to do that. Did he knowingly fail to do that? That is a matter for the Privileges Committee. That is what the Privileges Committee has to determine.

We know about his failure to disclose shareholdings of his own family trust despite the warnings, despite the information and despite the correspondence he had. This is the issue for the Privileges Committee: can the Senate believe that this minister, who has just been defended by Senator Hill as such a competent, outstanding minister, missed not one but two letters and a statement from the chairman of the Registrar of Senators' Interests on a day when we know he was here because he was attending divisions? That is what we want to know. We do not want to know whether he did it or not; that is open and shut. Everyone in this parliament and in the Australian public knows he has failed to do it. We want to know why he failed to do it. What was his motive in failing to do that? Did he have a motive in failing to do that? Did he do it knowingly?

Isn't it proper that the Privileges Committee investigate that matter? Of course it is. This is a motion that is a proper application of the Senate's standing orders. This is not a question of hanging Senator Parer on these offences of breaches of standing orders, or of finding Senator Parer guilty on those mattersâ€”though I say that he is guilty of a conflict of interest and of breaching the Prime Minister's code; and not only I, but many others in this parliament, and almost everyone outside it, stand by that statement. This is an issue of whether he knowingly breached the standing orders of this Senate. It is proper in this circumstance that such a matter is referred to and investigated by the Senate's Privileges Committee. It is for that reason that the opposition will be supporting the question before the chair.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: â€”It is interesting that this motion has been put forward by Senator Brown, the same Senator Brown who holds a share in the Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd; who is also a director of the Australian Bush Heritage Fundâ€”a fund which raises money to both purchase private land and generally manage land; Senator Brown having participated in debates in relation to woodchips and voted on motions relating to woodchips on at least two occasions in this chamber since 3 October when the register disclosed his interest in those companies. I am sure Senator Brown would like the opportunity at some later time to explain why he failed to declare those interests and why, indeed, he is pursuing this matter.

speech.para: It is interesting that he has jumped on this particular bandwagon, because we know of his obsessions on these environmental issues. He has got absolutely no interest in matters of privilege and propriety. That is demonstrated by the fact that the motion itself is drawn in such terms that it is clearly designed as a fishing or trawling expedition. I am grateful to Senator Ellison for pointing out to me that paragraph 3 inquires:
Whether Senator Parer knowingly failed to provide details of registrable interests . . . and whether any contempt was committed in that regard.

In other words, it is utterly open-endedâ€”an invitation simply to go through everything under the sun and consider whether there might be any other basis on which you could conceivably find that there was a failure to disclose or whether a contempt was committed. That is the essence of a denial of natural justiceâ€”without knowing the matters with which you are charged, you go before a Privileges Committee which then gives itself the luxury of exploring mattersâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”You don't go before it, actually; just send along papers, usually.

â€”You don't even go before it. In other words, they are completely at liberty to wander around looking for anything else that they might possibly be able to come up with. It is interesting that Senator Faulkner should have resorted to this lineâ€”that somehow no-one has yet alleged that Senator Parer is guilty of any knowingly improper conduct; that there are simply a few matters on the record which are worthyâ€”
â€”What I said is: he has breached the standing orders. Did he do it knowingly? Don't tell lies.

â€”I will just continue, as I intended to, Madam Acting Deputy President. What Senator Faulkner is now trying to do is suggest that somehow the opposition has not come to a view on whether Senator Parer acted knowingly in this regard.
â€”Whether he was in breach of the standing orders.

â€”Just a minute. From day one, we had Mr Crean in the other place alleging an absolute conspiracy of concealment, which is the height of an allegation of dishonesty and impropriety. We had Senator Faulkner, on 23 March, saying the opposition has exposed his deceit in this matter. You do not have to be too smart, you do not have to look up a dictionary to know that deceit goes to the heart of an allegation of dishonesty. Deceit is not simply directedâ€”
â€”The issue is the matter.

â€”No, you have gone over the top. That is your fundamental problem. You have not simply said, `There is a failure to disclose and we want to know whether it was knowingly.' You have said, `The opposition has exposed his deceit.' In other words, he has deliberately done it, and you do not deliberately do it unless you know what you are doing. So you are on the record as having found Senator Parer guilty as charged, because there is no charge in this regard of mere failure. The offence arises and the contempt is committed if you knowingly commit the offence. If anyone for a moment thinks that anything could emerge from a matter being dealt with by the Privileges Committee, that would somehow get inside Senator Parer's mindâ€”
â€”You are prejudging the Privileges Committee on it, though.

â€”That would do anything other than proceed on what is on the public record to date, then I would be amazed. I will be interested to hear Senator Ray, as the Chairman of the Privileges Committee, conceding that point.
â€”I do.

â€”If that is the case, how can you possibly gainsay what Senator Parer has consistently said: that he did not do it deliberately; that at all times he has done his best to ensure that there was not a conflict of interest; that he rearranged his affairs upon coming to government; and that he distanced himself by resigning as chairman and director. In other words, all that is on the public record supports the proposition that Senator Parer did not knowingly fail to disclose information. If that is the case, how could the Privileges Committee possibly come to any other view. In other words, the material that is on the record now, and on which a judgment should be made about whether there is a case to investigateâ€”
â€”You are prejudging the Privileges Committee's thoughts on it.
â€”The Privileges Committee does not have any evidence on which it could come to any conclusion other than thatâ€”
â€”You don't know what evidence Senator Brown has got.

â€”I see. We are being asked to vote blind, are we? We are being asked to send it off there to have a bit of a trawl. In other words, there is nothing on the public record to date to suggest dishonesty or knowingly concealing, but you would like to send it off to the Privileges Committeeâ€”
â€”I don't know about that.

â€”Are you saying there is? Come on, you are in the big league; you want to run in the House of Representatives. Are you saying there is evidence that Senator Parer has knowingly concealed? Are you? Is that what you are saying?
â€”It's not up to you to determine whether there is or not. It's up to the committee.
â€”Why should the Senate vote blind to refer a matter to the Privileges Committeeâ€”
â€”Because it is in the standing orders, you drongo.
â€”Order!

â€”If Senator Faulkner honestly thinks that you are going to get a fair hearing from a committee chaired by someone who delights in referring to `hanging Judge Roy Bean'â€”it is now the `Bean committee' because it is chaired by Senator Robert Ray, who has spent the last two years in this place doing not a skerrick of work on policy but doing everything to actually pay backâ€”
â€”That's unfair.

â€”You do not have to take my word for it. What did you say when you were in the course of pursuing Senator Colston as far as you possibly could? You said, `I'm not a nice person.' As recently as only a couple of days ago, in another context, I think you said, `We play it pretty rough in this place. We dish it out in the chamber'â€”
â€”And we cop it.

â€”`And we cop it'â€”indeed you didâ€”`but it doesn't go outside the chamber.' In other words, what Senator Robert Ray is spelling out in absolutely black and white terms is that he will never ever let anything else prevail over party political advantage. He is in this joint for keeps, he plays the game to win and he will win by hook or by crook, but outside the chamber he is a good bloke.
â€”I would give you a fair trial on privileges. I promise you that.

â€”I would expect nothing less, of course. That would be the grand exception, if it ever occurred, I can assure you. Senator Robert Ray has an absolute commitment to the Labor Party going back very many years. He is imbued in the spirit of Labor, the `whatever it takes' syndrome. There is no way in which a committee chaired by Senator Robert Ray, or indeed a committee of which he is a member, could even begin to approach this with an open mind. You have Senator Robert Ray saying that, when you read Senator Parer's declaration, there is an admission of guilt.

speech.para: If Senator Robert Ray wanted to choose his words properly, what he would have been saying is, `There is a failure to disclose.' But you can only be guilty of an offence if you knowingly commit that offence. So to talk about admissions of guilt means you are implying that he has knowingly or deliberately acted in such a way as to be dishonest in his behaviour. You have used the term `admission of guilt'. Senator Cookâ€”of course, no-one would take him seriouslyâ€”said, `As the web of deceit is growing by the day . . . '. In his usual incomprehensible jargon, he managed to get out the words `web of deceit'.

It is crystal clear, even to a schoolboy, that the Labor Party is determined to get Senator Parer, in many respects because he has been such a success inside and outside this place. He has handled himself very well on every occasion. He is on top of his brief. He has the respect of the industry and he has the respect of his colleagues in this place. In other words, everyone knows he is an honourable man.

talk.start.para: â€”Good blokes don't actually ever get questions. Is that what you are saying?

â€”No, I am not saying that at all. He has had plenty of questions; he has handled them very well indeed. I am saying, in every respect he has behaved impeccably. He has looked after his portfolio in a way that you very much resent and you have been determined to get him. I am not saying that that is the only basis on which you try to get anyone. You will try to get anyone if there is half an opportunityâ€”rat up a drainpipe!â€”the Labor Party first, last and always. So the idea of sending something off to the Bean committee strikes me as the absolute height of absurdity.

speech.para: To be able to, in some way, embark on an inquiry into whether Senator Parer might have knowingly committed an offence when there would not be a single person on that side of the chamber who did not reach an adverse judgment on day one, I think, simply says it all. In terms of the letters that were sent out by the committee, which were essentiallyâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Did he breach the standing orders?
â€”No. The standing orders require you to disclose matters of which you are aware and, because Senator Parer did not see that correspondence, he was not aware. So there is clearly no breach.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order, Senator Conroy!

â€”You ought to appreciate that as much as anyone else. Senator Hill made a very important point that, if you were expecting senators to be bound by these matters, they would have come forward by way of resolution on which we would all have voted, and then you would have been able to say, `There you are, you cannot say that you were unaware of this because you actually participatedâ€”it's on the record.' But to simply have someone coming up with an explanatory memorandum a year or two down the track putting down a view contrary to the one which had prevailed until that time is simply not good enough. It is like saying, `The act says one thing, but because someone else wants to interpret it in a different way, the wording ought to be changed.' It remains as it is until the act is amended or repealed, and that is precisely what ought to occur here.

speech.para: Unless and until the Senate resolves in the same solemn way that it sets down the rules in the first place, then all you have is another contrary advisory opinion. On that basis, it is no surprise that Senator Parer would not have come across that material. I thought even Senator Faulkner was getting very close to suggesting once again that Senator Parer should not be believed. He said, `Can you believe he missed three letters?'

talk.start.para: â€”Two. Two letters and a statement.
â€”Two letters and a statement. In other words, a clear imputationâ€”`Why would anyone believe that?'

speech.para: In other words, he got themâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Why did you answer them?
â€”Well, I might have got them; he did not. I might have read them; he did not. What you are saying is, `Can you believe that anyone did not get them and read them?'

speech.para: I can.

talk.start.para: â€”The Prime Minister doesn't listen to your decisions, so you have time to read letters.

â€”Guilty as charged. The fact remains that not all senators read all their correspondence, quite often not through their own fault because it might not actually come to them. It might get lost in the post, it might not be passed on by staffers or it might go incorrectly to Senator Robert Ray's office instead of to Senator Parer's office. There are a multitude of reasons why you may, in very good faith, not see correspondence. Yet, Senator Faulkner is on his feet saying, `Can you believe that he missed these?' `Can you believe' is another way of saying `I don't believe it'â€”in other words, `I've made up my mind; this bloke shouldn't be believed.'

speech.para: It ought to be abundantly plain that what we are looking at here is a denial of natural justice. People are entitled to be tried by a tribunal free of bias. That is the essence of natural justice, and that is precisely what we do not have here.

talk.start.para: â€”You have not established any bias.

â€”I can remember people alleging that I had made up my mind in relation to the ABC committee of inquiry. We had that clown Loosley rabbiting on for days about the fact that somehow I had made up my mind and I should be sacked as chairman.

speech.para: The Labor Party has made up its collective mind. If anyone were ever tempted to wander onto the straight and narrow and actually come up with an unbiased view, I am sure Senator Ray would set them very straight and say, `I'm sorry. I understand your point entirely, but we have got an election coming up. You cannot in any shape or form diverge from the party line.' In fact, the rules say you get expelled from the partyâ€”or you get suspended, I think, in Senator Georges' case.

There would be no way in which Senator Bean or anyone else would contemplate going into that hearing with an open mind. I think this motion is exposed for what it is. It is an attempt to bring down a very efficient and honest minister, someone who has done his very best in all respects to try to ensure that he complies with the rules. But Labor takes the view that policy does not matter; the way to get through to the next election is to simply stay in the gutter, dredge up the dirt and run on the negatives day after day. With people like Senator Brown jumping on the bandwagon, it has been encouraged to think that the matter might actually go further.

It certainly should not go further, not only because you would not get a fair hearing from the Bean committee but because you could not possibly sustain the charge on the evidence that is on the public record. I simply say this is a remorseless pursuit by an utterly political operator and operation. It is not designed to seriously analyse the issues. We have had Senator Parer saying ad nauseam that he has not in any way sought to act dishonestly and there is no evidence to support that proposition.

I notice Senator Faulkner once again in this very debate running off at the mouth. He cannot help himself. I suppose that is what happens when you like to think you are smart enough to interpret a few things and you have got a bit of an understanding of the law because you have been around the place for a while and you have read a few shonky pieces of paper that you think constitute legal advice. Here he was again sayingâ€”
Senator Conroy interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Can I just tell you? This is what he said out of his own mouth about five minutes agoâ€”`You cannot argue that he has complied with the letter or the spirit.' It is one thing to say you have not complied with the letter because you have failed to disclose; the spirit of it goes to intent. The spirit of it is all about whether you did it deliberately or not. Right? That is precisely the trap poor old Senator Faulkner has fallen into yet again because he simply does not understand what he is saying.
â€”It is whether he knowingly did it; you know that. Read the standing orders. Are you incapable of reading the standing orders of the Senate?
â€”Exactly my point, clown. You cannot in any shape or form say he has failed to comply with the spirit without implyingâ€”
â€”Order! Senator Alston, it is not appropriate to call another honourable senator a clown.

â€”My apologies, Madam Acting Deputy President. I must have been looking a bit further afield. To talk about not complying with the spirit is clearly to suggest that he has acted improperly or dishonestly; in other words, not only that there is a technical failure to disclose but that he has acted dishonestly. That is the essence of the matter that is supposed to go to the Privileges Committee today, the Bean committee. Quite clearly, there is no way in which Senator Parer's position that is on the public record could get anything other than a no vote from the Labor Party. I, therefore, think it stands condemned as a shabby and grubby little political exercise.

â€”Senator Alston refers to the Privileges Committee as the Bean committee. I should at least declare that the Senate Privileges Committee is considering the leaking of a document from Senator Alston's office to the department of transport and communications. I assure him that we will take no offence and we will approach that issue in a totally objective way.

speech.para: I want to address a few of these issuesâ€”firstly, the President's ruling. Let us get it quite clear. The President has ruled that this matter has precedence. The only fact to come out of that is the President has ruled it is not trivial. The very giving of precedence by the President to this matter does not mean that the President considers that there is in fact a prima facie case here, only that it is not trivial.

Senator Brown has asked for two broad areas to be referred. The first one is failure to get up in this chamber and declare during a division or during a contribution that someone may have a conflict of interest. The head of power for this particular reference is section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, which then relates to the resolution carried by the Senate on 17 March 1994 as amended on 21 June 1995. Part 5 of that resolution directs a senator to declare a pecuniary interest. You would have to go back, however, to the Senate resolution on privileges of 25 February 1988, part 8 headed `Disobedience of orders', for that to have some validity to be before the Privileges Committee.

I have to say that I do not think it is as clearly expressed in all those standing orders and the Privileges Committee as to be not without at least some doubt in this part of the reference. There is some doubt about it because it links a whole series of powers, interlocking into each other, as to whether it could be regarded as a breach of privilege or a contempt of the Senate. But defying an order of the Senate is a contempt.

Nevertheless, that one is not as clear cut as the second part of the reference which really goes to standing order 22A and the provision of the resolution of the Senate on 17 March 1994. The key part of that goes to the question of what happens if a senator does not declare their pecuniary interest. It says:
(2) That any senator who:
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests by the due date;
(c) knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interestsâ€”
that is a prescription, but they also put a remedy in hereâ€”

shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly but the question whether any senator has committed such a serious contempt shall first be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report and may not be considered by any other committee.

The key to all this, frankly, is the word `knowingly'. The only smidgin of contribution that Senator Alston made in the debate was actually to go that point. I am disappointed that Senator Alston did not explore this in more depth. The whole point about the `knowingly' section is that it is up to the Privileges Committee to interpret, not this chamber. This chamber is talking about whether it will refer this matter to the Privileges Committee and the Privileges Committee is going to have to come up with an answer as to whether Senator Parer knowingly did this.

I have to say to Senator Brown that when you put your submission to the Privileges Committee you are going to have to lead some evidence that Senator Parer knowingly did this. It is a bit like proving a conspiracy theory. This will be a difficult task, I have to say, and the Privileges Committee would have to be satisfied that this was deliberate behaviour on Senator Parer's behalf and not accidental. That will not be easy to prove.

We do know, in outline, what Senator Parer has said about these matters, and there are really three areas to look at. Firstly, there is the 44 shares in ESP. He says he did not declare them from 1994 through to 1998 in the belief that these are akin to superannuation. That is Senator Parer's claim as to why he did not do it. His second claim goes to why he did not declare the knock-on effects of his family trust in terms of shareholdings and the companies it holds shares in. Senator Parer has said that he did not read the correspondence on this particular matter. Note, first of all, that it was one piece of correspondence. Later, it was shown that he had in fact missed two sets of correspondence.

That, of course, raises the question: does Senator Parer's office have a register of mail for all incoming mail? If so, he should be able to track down why he missed it. If he does not have that, he is not the competent minister that Senator Alston has indicated, because that is really the first rule of a ministerial officeâ€”to keep track of all correspondence and papers by way of a register. The odds of two letters going missing, especially if one was hand delivered, do not seem to me to be credible enough.

However, Senator Alston goes on to say that maybe a staff member has not drawn these matters to his attention, and that may well be a plausible excuse because I am sure that not every piece of correspondence is shown to a minister, nor should it be. But you really should have staff competent enough to know what should go to a minister and what should not. If it transpires that these two letters were sidelined by a staff memberâ€”I am sorry, I do not want to be harshâ€”but that is a pink slip job, isn't it, and you get a staff member who can handle that particular area.

Senator Parer, nevertheless, can put the argument that he did not knowingly do this because he did not read the correspondence. Even though the very gracious and dynamic chairman of the committee presented a statement here, I have got to admit, Senator Denman, that I was not following that statement at the time like Senator Parer. I have to say I am not sure what I was doing at the time but I missed it. I did read the correspondence when it came around. I put it straight in the bin, because I do not own any shares or family trusts or any other interests, so naturally it did not highlight my attention. So Senator Parer can run that argument.

The third argument Senator Parer can run, and I find it highly credible, is that he is a pretty vague sort of a bloke. He can earn the odd couple of hundred thousand or couple of million and not remember it. I think that goes to his credit in terms of this: his very vagueness on all these particular issues. He has not been on top of it at question time. He has not been able to answer any questions on this. He has been just totally confused.

What we have on the record is Senator Parer explaining why he did not declare the shares declarable in 1994 and why he did not declare the shares in 1997. The one missing link in this to me, though, is that Senator Parer has knowingly not updated the pecuni ary interest register in the last 15 days. These issues were raised on 11 March.

talk.start.para: â€”He's got 28 days to amend.
â€”Oh, Senator Alston disingenuously says he has 28 days to amend. That is when your circumstances change, Senator.
â€”Or when you become aware.
â€”Oh, when you become aware. He was aware, Senator. But wouldn't you have thought that just in the last 15 days he would have actually bothered?
â€”Well, he's had other things on his mind, thanks to you.

â€”Oh, he's had other things on his mind, has he? I think this would have been one of the basic building blocks but it just goes to the question that in this case he knowingly did not put these matters right for 15 days. Yes, Senator Alston, if he has been busy that may make an excuse as to why he has not done it.
â€”But doesn't he have 28 days from the time he becomes aware?
â€”He has been aware of ESP for five years, Senator.
â€”No, aware in your terms that it should have been disclosed. He did not have that belief.

â€”You are claiming that he did not have that belief and what I am saying is that the position is open on that: that you have to prove that he knowingly did not. But I would have thought that he would have actually corrected the record because what he now knows, Senator Alston, is that he was in error. He now knows he was in error. He has admitted that in this chamber. He was in error on the ESP shares, he was in error on the family trust and non-disclosure, and I think he should have corrected the record.

speech.para: The only contrary view that can be put on the `knowingly' thing, to prove that in fact he knowingly did this, is to go to motive. In trying to prove that he knowingly did this, as Senator Alston has saidâ€”and I agree with you on this part, Senator Alstonâ€”you have to go into Senator Parer's mind, and it is very difficult to do to prove one way or the other. The only way you could prove that he knowingly did it is by saying that he had a very strong motive for not declaring those shares.

It is possibleâ€”people have run that argument in this chamberâ€”that he did not want to disclose these matters because they were in conflict with the Prime Minister's code of conduct and that they may have been politically embarrassing to him. People have pointed out that having a separate superannuation scheme set up in 1994, when you are already in the parliamentary one, might be in fact a cause of embarrassment, and maybe that was the reason that he did not disclose. People have pointed out that owning $2 million worth of coal shares when you are the coal minister might have been embarrassing. Those sorts of motives come forward to suggest that maybe he knowingly did it, but it is going to be very difficult to prove, in my view. It is like proving a conspiracy theory, and therein lies some of the nub of it.

None of this goes against Senator Brown's motion. Senator Brown is abiding by the principles of the standing orders that actually set out that it is the Privileges Committee that should examine and resolve these things. No other committee should. After all, the standing orders say that, in terms of non-disclosure, it is not a contempt of the Senate, it is a severe contempt of the Senate. Therefore, that is the appropriate course.

We had Senator Hill come in today with all his guilty as charged quotes, all of which refer to Senator Parer's conduct in terms of the prime ministerial code of conduct.
