question.para: It is vital that ministers and parliamentary secretaries do notâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I raise a point of order. There can be no relationship between what is being asked now and the answer that was given. A supplementary can only relate to the answer that was given. He is seeking to raise another issue and he should give that question to the next one in line.
â€”Senator Carr, there is nothing supplementary to the answer or even the question.

â€”On the point of order: I am halfway through the first sentence of my supplementary question. I find it an extraordinary proposition that you would rule out of order a supplementary question that goes to the Prime Minister's ministerial guidelines which state that ministers, by their conduct, should not undermine public confidence in them or the government. What I seekâ€”
â€”Madam Presidentâ€”
â€”He's on a point of order. Sit down!
â€”Order! Senator Hill, I wish to hear the question first. Finish giving your question, Senator Carr.

â€”What I seek to ask the minister as a supplementary question is: in view of the Prime Minister's ministerial conduct code, how many battlers in this country have access to a superannuation scheme in which their 12 cent original investment, by the minister himself, can grow on the same day to a figure of $12,000?
â€”It has nothing do with the minister's portfolio. I do not requireâ€”
â€”You took all that time to say that!
â€”I am speaking. The question, as I have heard it, does not relate to the minister's portfolio.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, are you aware that your Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs considers it `a badge of honour' to have a vote of no confidence passed in him by ATSIC? Do you recall Senator Minchin's answer to my question yesterdayâ€”

question.para: Government senators interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Senators on my right will cease interjecting!
â€”Do you recall Senator Minchin's answer to my question yesterdayâ€”

question.para: Senator Abetz interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Senator Abetz!
â€”Can I start again?
â€”Yes, please.

â€”Thank you. Minister, do you recall Senator Minchin's answer to my question yesterday when he deliberately misrepresented and virtually dismissed the role of the National Indigenous Working Group in the whole Wik debate?
â€”Madam President, I raise a point of order. You cannot ask a question that suggests in bald terms that someone deliberately misrepresented. That is a clear breach of standing orders.
â€”I agree. Senator Woodley, the question will have to be rephrased to put it within the terms of the standing orders and not cast imputations on a senator.

â€”Thank you. Minister, by their recent statements, is it not obvious to you that both of these ministers are escalating tension between black and white Australians and are therefore unfit to lead the government in the vital national issues of native title and reconciliation in Australia?
â€”On a point of order, Madam President; I have been misrepresented in the question.
â€”That's not a point of order.

â€”Yes, it is. Madam President, if I could elaborate on that. From the Hansard yesterday, I said that if I am being `criticised by the ATSIC board . . . because I am on about accountability, and the government is on about health, housing, education, economic opportunity and the future of the Aboriginal people . . . I wear that as a badge of honour.' I did not say that I regarded it as a badge of honour because I had beenâ€”
â€”I have been misrepresented in the question. I would ask you to look at the Hansard , and I would ask Senator Woodley to withdraw the question because I have been misrepresented.
â€”Order! Senator Hill, do you have anything you wish to say on this matter?

â€”I thought Senator Woodley might like to withdraw the question. But if he is not withdrawing the question I will say something. The first thing I would like to say is what an excellent job Senator Herron is doing as Aboriginal affairs minister. Why? Because Senator Herron is interested in the real issues facing Aboriginal people in this countryâ€”issues of education, issues of jobs, issues of housingâ€”
â€”Health.

â€”Issues of healthâ€”the substantial issues that were neglected by Labor in its 13 years of government. Finally there is a government in power and a minister in office who has a serious interest in these issues and knows that we have a responsibility to provide a better future for Australia's Aboriginal people in these critically important areas of health, education, jobsâ€”
â€”And housing.

â€”And housing. So I will make no apology on behalf of Senator Herron. I think he is doing an excellent job. If there may be a little bit of creative tension from time to time between Senator Herron and ATSIC in its political role, then so be it. That is all part and parcel of politics, and I am sure both ATSIC and Senator Herron can handle that.

answer.para: In relation to Wik, again the honourable senator seems to miss the point. What we are seeking in the legislative response to Wik is something that not only gives greater certainty for all Australians but is fair to Australia's Aboriginal people. We have gone to great pains, made great effort, through a long period of consultation to find that correct balanceâ€”something that is fair and reasonable for Australia's indigenous people whilst at the same time providing greater certainty for all other interests within Australia, whether they be the pastoralists, mining interests and all others who have a concern and are affected by the Wik judgment.

We believe that we have the balance right. We trust next week when the Senate for the second time addresses the government's response senators around the chamber will accept that the package that we have put down is fair and just, that they will pass that legislative package and then allow the Senate to move on to other issues.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Woodley made an imputation. He should be asked to withdraw it.

â€”He rephrased his question, as I understand it. The amount of noise in the chamber is such that it is almost impossible to hear. It was my impression he had withdrawn it. If you did not, Senator Woodley, I ask you to do so.
â€”Madam President, if there is any problem with any of the words I used, I certainly withdraw them. I am not sure of what it was I needed to withdraw.

â€”Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, today Senator Minchin told the Australian public on Radio National that the Democrats had not responded to his offer of talks on the Wik legislation. This is not true.
â€”This is not a supplementary question.
â€”Senator, what is your question?

â€”Is the minister aware that I attended talks with the staff of Senator Minchin's office on the Native Title Amendment Bill on 27 February this year? The Democrats expected him to be present but he did not turn up. We are used to these kinds of statements from Senator Minchin. Minister, do you consider it acceptable behaviour for your minister to tell untruths to the Australian public to advance your government's dubious solution to the High Court's Wik decision?

â€”The government is willing to provide whatever briefings are necessary to help the Democrats in their decision. But the real opportunity is now before the Australian Democrats. They have a chance to do something really worthwhile in the interests of all Australians, including indigenous Australians, and that is to acknowledge that the package that we have put up on Wik is just, fair and reasonable. Let it pass the Senate. Let us provide the certainty that all Australians expect and reasonably demand and then allow the Senate to get on with some other business.

answer.para: Senator Alston interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”I heard that, Madam President, and perhaps Senator Alston might be encouraged to withdraw. My question is to Minister Herron representing the minister for health. Minister, on what basis has the Prime Minister claimed that his Medicare agreement offered to the states would provide a 15 per cent real increase in health care funding? Isn't it the case that, when you take account of the money already in the forward estimates and the money you are double counting for mental health and palliative care, plus the $800 million you took from public hospitals in the 1996 budget and the $400 million you took from the states by abolishing the dental health program, you are doing nothing more than putting back the money you have already taken away?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”I thank Senator Crowley for the question because it gives me the opportunity to clarify the mathematics for her. Despite what the premiers are claiming, the position of the Commonwealth put to the states at the Premiers Conference on health funding was very generous indeed.
â€”It isn't what Borbidge said.
â€”The existing forward estimates based on the current Medicare agreements negotiated by the last Labor government provided for spending over the next five years of $27.3 billion.
â€”It's not what Court said.
â€”That was the agreement negotiated with the states by the Labor Party when they were in government.
â€”Why are all the Liberal premiers against it?
â€”Senator Schacht, cease interjecting.
â€”I was trying to help him.
â€”You are not helping; you are just hindering and persistently interjecting.

â€”Our offer increased the amount available to the states to $30.2 billion. As well as a $1.5 billion increase in ongoing funding, this included $120 million for waiting list reduction in 1998, $500 million for projects designed to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the acute health system, and $750 million to meet the full cost of treatment of entitled veterans. Total real growth for next year will be 6.9 per cent and total real growth over the five years will be 15.4 per cent, Senator Crowley.

answer.para: Furthermore, the government proposed to increase funding by $83 million each time the private health insurance participation rate dropped by one percentage point. Madam President, I remember telling Senator Crowley the other day that, in her government's five-year agreement, it was to be renegotiated after every two per cent drop. They reneged on it. They did nothing about it, Senator Ray. It was in the health care agreement and they did not do anything about it. That is how you have Labor Party agreementsâ€”you just do not take any notice of them.

However, the states are persisting in arguing for a $1.1 billion increase in base funding next year, an increase of over 20 per cent, and a total of $5.5 billion over five years on top of the Commonwealth offer. The hollowness of their demands can be seen by the fact that they have not altered it since December last year, since when the Commonwealth has put an extra $1.2 billion on the table. As far as the states are concerned, the answer is always the Commonwealth offer plus $1.1 billion each year. It is simply impossible to negotiate with people holding such a position.

Madam President, you will recall that when we came into government we had a black hole, the Beazley black hole, of $10Â½ billion. We have to take that into account in our forward estimates, and we will look forward to where we are with the budget this year. As Dr Wooldridge said, this amount of money would fund over 300,000 admissions and there simply are not that many extra people needing treatment.

The facts of the matter are that this occurs on every occasion. The states come to the Commonwealth with their hands out and say, `Give us more money. Give us more money.' What has happened in the past is that they have reduced their own amount of funding. I am pleased to say that, in my own state of Queensland, the coalition government has increased the capital funding going into the public hospitals by a large sum of money and are making up for the defects that are occurring.

talk.start.para: â€”Borbidge still reckons you're crook. Why is Borbidge complaining?
â€”Senator Schacht! Cease interjecting.

â€”And that was due to the Labor Party running down the amount of funding that went in the capital funding of the last Medicare agreement. It went down to less than three per cent. So the deficit has to be made up by the present coalition government in Queensland, and they are doing a great job. But that does not stop them coming to the federal government and saying, `Give us more money. We will spend it.' Of course there are deficits occurring. The Labor Party's attack on the private health care system meant that the number of privately insured in my own state of Queensland went from 80 per cent to less than 30 per cent. That was an effect of the withdrawal of the bed day subsidies from private hospitals and the increasing escalation of the cost of private health insurance.

answer.para: It increased over 100 per cent while the Labor Party was in power and there is the fact that technology is increasingly in use and the ageing of the population. There are many factors here. But it is a standard procedure, as Senator Crowley well knows, for the states to come to the Commonwealth. Where are the Labor Party's policies in relation to health care? Where are they? Have we heard what they are going to do about this? What is their answer? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister completely failed to address the question I put to himâ€”that is, are you doing nothing more than putting back the money you have already taken away? Further, why is it that your government, Minister, is so inept at working cooperatively with the states? You were bad when it came to education, but you have reached dizzy new levels of ineptitude with health. Don't Australians have a right to expect that, at least in an area as important as health, a conservative federal government should be able to get its act together with so many conservative state governments?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”I draw Senator Crowley's memory back five years, if she can go back that far, to when the Labor governments in the states came to the federal Labor government with the same arguments and the same story. I pulled out a speech that I made five years ago; all I had to do was transpose `Labor' and `coalition' and the same old story went on. Senator Crowley, I will drag out your speeches. In fact I was told to do thatâ€”

answer.para: Government senators interjectingâ€”No! No!

talk.start.para: â€”My colleagues have told me not to. Senator Crowley, it might be an interesting exercise for you to do it yourself. Drag out your speeches of five years ago, and I guarantee that you could substitute `coalition' for `Labor' and you would get the same result that you are getting with your questions this afternoon.

â€”My question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister. Was I right in pointing out to the Punuba people in the Kimberley whom I met and canoed with down the Fitzroy River three or four weeks ago that in relation to the dam proposed for the Kimberley, the proposed 300-kilometre canal from that dam and the hundreds of thousands of hectares of cotton crops resulting from that to prospectively be laid out east of Broome, the indigenous people will have no right to negotiate on the dam, the canal, the cotton crops and other infrastructure? Was I right to point out that under a Labor government the indigenous people would also have no right to negotiate? I also ask the minister: when you spoke with Fran Kelly on ABC radio this morning, were you referring to this stripping of the rights of Aboriginal people to a say in their land when you said:

question.para: . . . we are discussing with the officials of the Labor Party and Senator Harradine . . . different ways of skinning the cat.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: â€”I must confess I am not an expert on the dam proposal, so I cannot say with any confidence over what title that dam is proposed. I gather it has not got to a particular stage where it is even likely to occur. As I understand it, it is a feasibility proposal. Whether the right to negotiate would apply to that proposal, should our bill become law and should that proposal proceed, depends on whether the land over which the developments are proposed is vacant crown land, Aboriginal land or pastoral lease land.

answer.para: If it is vacant crown land or Aboriginal land, the right to negotiate will be maintained by our bill for Aboriginal people if the proposal involves either mining or the compulsory acquisition of native title. We maintain the right to negotiate on 39 per cent of Australia, as was intended and put down by the then Labor government in 1993 in the Native Title Act. We are not winding back the right to negotiate where it applied when the Native Title Act was first passed. It is one of the furphies perpetrated by your side of politics that we are somehow removing the right to negotiate altogether. That is an absolute nonsense.

As far as pastoral lease is concerned, if there is any land on which the proposal proceeds that is pastoral lease land, may I repeat again: the right to negotiate was never intended to apply on pastoral lease land because the Native Title Act was passed on the presumption that native title had been extinguished on pastoral lease land. So it was never designed to apply on the additional 42 per cent of Australia that is pastoral lease land.

What will happen on pastoral lease land under our bill in relation to mining or proposals involving compulsory acquisition for third parties is that the native title claimants and holders will be granted exactly the same procedural rights as the lessees of that land. We insist on equality of treatment for coexisting titleholders. We are not going to put up with a situation where one group of people, based on their race, gets a different and more generous set of procedural rights than other people coexisting on that land. If you insist on perpetrating that sort of nonsense, you will end up with an awful situation on the ground. You ought to realise the impact of such a nonsensical proposition on the ground where you have coexisting titleholders.

We have accepted that native title may have survived on pastoral lease land. We accept the Wik decision; we are giving effect to the Wik decision but, as to the procedural rights that attach to the native title on pastoral lease land, the only tenable, sustainable and fair proposition is that there be equality of treatment for the coexisting titleholdersâ€”that is, for the families who are farming that land and for the native title claimants or holders. It is outrageous for the other side of politics to be insisting on legalised discrimination against pastoral lessees based on race. It is an untenable proposition which we cannot accept. If there are Aboriginal people involved on pastoral lease land and this development proceeds, as any other development on pastoral lease land, they will get the same procedural rights as anybody else.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to explicitly answer the question as to whether indigenous people will have a right to negotiate on a massive extension of cotton crops across pastoral lease lands in areas where they have a claim in the Kimberley or anywhere else. I also ask the minister: in the negotiations reported in the media to be proceeding between himself and other parties, is the Labor Party's spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, Daryl Melham, still involved in those negotiations or has it passed to other people in the Labor Party who may not be taking such a strong line on behalf of indigenous interests?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: â€”If Senator Brown wants to have a go at the Labor Party, he ought to ask them a question, not me. You are free to ask Senator Bolkus what the situation is in the Labor Party, and that is too complicated for me. Our dealings with the Labor Party are at the official level, and we are seeking to persuade officials of the Labor Party of the wisdom, fairness and good sense of the propositions that we are putting.
â€”And it's not working!

â€”It is very difficult to get through the thick heads of some on the other side as to how fair our propositions are. As to any potential upgrade of leases to accommodate agricultural activity, where that is done for a third party, the native titleholders will have exactly the same procedural rights as other titleholders on that land. We will treat Australians equally; we will treat them fairly; we will not discriminate.

â€”My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Minister, when the private health insurance incentive scheme was announced in the 1996-97 budget, did the government claim that the scheme would increase the level of membership in private health funds to 34 per cent by 1997-98? Is it also the case that in a press release on 29 August 1997 the Minister for Health said:

question.para: We are confident that the cash incentives will attract many thousands of people to take out private health insurance.
Minister, given that the level of private health fund membership has now dropped to 31.6 per centâ€”the lowest level everâ€”will you now concede that this $1.7 billion scheme is a total failure?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”No, I do not. If you look at the graph of what occurred under the Labor Party, it was disastrous. It was in free fall. The former Labor Party minister, Senator Graham Richardson, had an argument with his caucus and with Mr Keating at the time. You will recall when Mr Keating said that he was going to stand on the necks of the private health insurers and that he was not prepared to take out private health insurance because he wanted everybody to be in Medicare so that it would be totally available to everybody in the country; whereas, the then Senator Richardson arguedâ€”and it is on the public recordâ€”that he thought that wealthy people should have a premium on them if they did not take out private health insurance. We brought that in, Madam President. That was one of the steps that we took to try to stop the free fall that had occurred.

answer.para: Madam President, we came into government, you will recall, a little over two glorious years ago. It has been a delight to be here because we are trying to fix up the effects of Labor after 13 years in government and to stop the free fall in private health insurance. As I was explaining to Senator Lees the other dayâ€”whom I thought would understandâ€”when we had the system of about 50 per cent of the population in private health insurance and 50 per cent in the public hospital system, there were not the demands that are occurring today because of the people who have been forced out of private health insurance by the previous Labor government. What we did after the last election was to bring in an incentive scheme, $450â€”

talk.start.para: â€”I know that; answer the question.
â€”Senator Forshaw says he knows it. He seems to have forgotten again, because that was designed to help people take up private health insurance, particularly the younger members of society.

answer.para: Since we have been in government, I am pleased to say there have been a number of things that have occurred. The immunisation program, for example, has helped keep people out of hospitals. Under the Labor Party, we reached a level of immunisation in this countryâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”On a point of order, Madam President: I have sat and listened to the minister for a while. He has about two minutes to go. He has not yet addressed the point of the question. When they came to government, they said it would reach 34 per cent. It has now reached 31.6 per centâ€”it's gone in the other direction. I ask the minister to direct his answer to the question: isn't that a failure? I was not talking about immunisation. That had nothing to do with it.
â€”On the point of order, Madam Presidentâ€”
â€”There is no point of order.

â€”Madam President, I was going to speak on the point of order; I will finish the answer in any case. But on the point of order, I answered the question right at the beginning. I said I did not agree in my first sentence. I answered his question. I did not agree with him. So now to jump up on a spurious point of order is not correct.

answer.para: Madam President, it was designed to stop the free fall. I remember Dr Wooldridge saying that he could not predict, nor can anybody predict, the outcome of these measures. But they were designed to stop the free fall and they have stopped the free fall that was occurring under the policies of the previous Labor government. They have slowed down the rate of decrease. In fact, for one monthâ€”Senator Forshaw, you are probably not aware of itâ€”it went up 0.1 per cent. We do not recognise that as valid because it has to be over at least a three-month period and it will be after the end of the financial year before we can find out whether the effect of the premium increase on people of higher income has had an effect.

For Senator Forshaw to jump up and down is the height of hypocrisy. It was his government that produced this free fall in private health insurance. We will not be able to give an answer in relation to that Senator Forshaw, and you should know that because it will not be until after the end of the financial year when the taxation returns come in that we get the adequate numbers to see what occurred. I can tell you Senator Forshawâ€”you are probably not aware of it, but my Queensland friends in the gallery would be aware of itâ€”that it has plateaued in Queensland, where it has been about 30, 29 or 28 per cent for 13 years, and because of the fine private hospital system which has catered for about 40 per cent of the population for as many years as I can remember.

Senator Forshaw, I cannot predict what will occur; nobody can. At least we have brought in measures that will slow down the rate of fall in private health insurance because that is the only answer for this country for a viable system, not the socialised public system that you on that side want and the Democrats want by increasing the Medicare levy.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you may think it is not a failure, but all the state premiers think it is a failure.
â€”Your question, Senator Forshaw?
â€”You may not be able to predict what the figure would be, but Minister Wooldridge predicted it would be 34 per cent; it is now 31 per cent.
â€”What is your question, Senator Forshaw?

â€”My supplementary question is this. In his press release of 20 August, Dr Wooldridge said that his measures on private health insurance were designed to assist the battlers. Minister, given that health fund premiums have risen by over 20 per cent since March 1996 and funds will further increase premiums by between 10 and 14 per cent this year, is it not the case that the tax rebate has already been eroded by the extent of premium increases? Minister, do you agree with Premier Court and the other premiers when they say, `This scheme is a dud; this scheme is a failure'?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I do not agree with those premiers. It is the height of hypocrisy when the other side talk about premium increases. Do you know what the percentage of premium increases were when the Labor Party was in government?
â€”What were they?
â€”They were over 100 per cent in the time that Labor was in government.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Now to start talking about premium increases and blaming it on us, Madam President, I ask you: if that is not hypocrisy of the highest order, what is?
â€”Talk about on an annual basis.
â€”Order! Just a moment, Senator Herron. Please continue, Senator Herron.

â€”Even the coalition government cannot stop the ageing of the population. We can do practically everything else but we cannot stop the population ageing and the fact that two-thirds of the health care dollar is spent on people over the age of 65. I am delighted to say that, under the coalition government, the fastest growing segment of the population is that of people over the age of 75. That segment will double from 350,000 to 700,000 people by the year 2006. I do not even take responsibility for that. (Time expired)

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, what will the consequences be of the failure of the Senate to pass the amendments to the Workplace Relations Act yesterday on the government's job creation program, and how rapturously will it be adopted by small business trapped in the position where they cannot recruit people because to fire them it might cost anywhere between $15,000 and $50,000 for non-performers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: â€”That is a very good point made by Senator MacGibbon. You do not have to take our word for it. COSBOA, the council of small business associations, estimates that up to 50,000 jobs will be lost as a result of that decision. The New South Wales Chamber of Commerce has conducted a survey which shows that 85 per cent of small businesses have nominated unfair dismissals as a key factor affecting small business and over 42 per cent believe that the prospects of unfair dismissal claims are a deterrent to employing more staff.

answer.para: There is only one party that is in the slightest bit interested in the welfare of small business. We have already introduced capital gains rollover relief. We have reduced red tape. We have introduced an innovation investment fund. We have reduced the provisional uplift factor for provisional taxation. In other words, we have done all the things we promised to do and more. If you want an example of the extent to which the Labor Party hates small business, you only had to be listening to Kim Il Dinosaur.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator, address senators properly please.

â€”Madam President, I was simply adopting a term used by Mr Brumby in referring to Senator Carr. What he said today is a classic example of the class hatred and envy that permeates certain sec tions of the Labor Party. He asked Senator Parer whether or not there was something inherently unfair about the battlers in the western suburbs of Sydney not having access to more generous superannuation funds than they did. In other words, what he was saying was that he bitterly resents any small business that actual manages to accumulate some reserves, any small businessman or woman who manages to build up a retirement nest egg, a superannuation fund, that happens to be a bit more generous than his trade union. That is what he is on about. It is the politics of hatred and envy.

answer.para: They are not in the slightest bit interested in the welfare of small business. They want to pull it down, not build it up. We are not going to tolerate that sort of nonsense. They have come up with absolutely no policies at all. It has all been said. We know he cannot get a job on the frontbench, but nonetheless he is allowed to run rampant. He can get out there and write a newspaper article in response to a comment from Mr Brumby in which he defines `renewal' as the right of members of parliament representing the Labor Party to represent the ALP itselfâ€”nothing to do with representing constituents. That is what renewal is about. Renewal is about getting in there and fighting the class war on behalf of those who put you in power in the first place.

It is an absolute disgrace. They do not know what small business is about. They are not in the slightest bit interested in representing its interests. They are there for themselves. They are there to look after their mates. They are there to pay back their dues. They are there to make sure that this massive conflict of interest on the other side continues to be a running sore. The Australian public understand it. The small businessmen and women of Australia understand it. They know that not only won't they get any relief from that mob but they will actually be penalised and crucified by people who resent their very success.

That is the nub of the problem. That is why we are so committed to small business and to the jobs generated. That is why they hate them so much, because they are actually earning a bit more than they are.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, I refer you to the Attorney-General's recent criticisms that the courts were not doing enough to reform themselves. Minister, given that Australian courts are world leaders in respect of a number of major reforms of judicial process, such as the Federal Court's use of video conferencing and the Family Court's counselling and mediation service, what specific practice is it that the government believes the courts are engaging in which is inefficient? Exactly which specific reform is it that the government says the courts should adopt which they are not now adopting? Or is it, as the Chief Justice of Victoria, Justice Phillips, has put it, just one more ill-informed criticism?

â€”I thank Senator McKiernan for the question. Senator McKiernan, you would have had some experience on the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee of this place when you, Senator Cooney and I were involved in the cost of justice inquiry. Through that experience you would have, I am sure, a clear understanding of the sensitivities involved in suggesting there should be reform of the legal profession. Whenever there is a suggestion that reform should come or should move at a more rapid pace in one direction or anotherâ€”whether it relates to technology used by the courts, whether it relates to the rules and regulations and their procedures, or whether it relates to something one might consider the profession ought to doâ€”one necessarily meets with some response and some inertia to the criticism.

answer.para: There is the opportunity, of course, for misunderstandings and misreportings. Then when you get someone commenting on the misreporting, the story in a sense gets out of hand and becomes a very pale version of what it was in the very beginning. It is regrettable that some judges have responded in a defensive manner to the comments that the Attorney made. It is clear that some judges may have misunderstood the Attorney's comments.

In referring to the lack of further resources being available, the Attorney was referring to legal aid funding. His comments were not directed to the courts alone. The point he sought to make is that reform is largely in the hands of the judges and the hands of the legal profession. The Attorney is there not to simply protect the judges and to protect the profession but to be the first law officer of Australia for the Australian people. These were appropriate remarks to make in that respect.

I can give you an example, Senator McKiernan. You well know that some states held on tenaciously to what was referred to as the two-counsel ruleâ€”where, if you had a silk appearing on your behalf, that silk could not appear unless junior counsel came along as well. I think, Senator McKiernan, this is a good example of the role that judges can play. If you chose to have a silk appearing on a small matter, the cost to you would be quite extensive because the legal profession's rules required you to have a junior there.

Senator McKiernan, Senator Cooney and any lawyer in this place know that, if a judge had consistently and politely said when two counsel had appeared and it was not required, `Nice to have you in my court, Mr or Miss So and So. I am always pleased to hear your erudite contributions. Isn't it a shame that your profession's rules require you to have two people here at vast expense to your client when you and I know, Mr or Miss So and So, only one counsel is required?'; if a judge had been prepared to do that, how long do you think the two-counsel rule would have lasted? How much more quickly would the two-counsel rule have disappeared? How much more quickly would Australian litigants be able to go to court and have only one counsel when they needed only one?

In summary, Senator McKiernan, it is important to understand the role of the Attorney. He is the first law officer of Australia for all Australiansâ€”not just for the judges, not just for the legal profession, but for the litigants as well. Sometimes people do get a bit sensitive when they are criticised and over-respond. But the Attorney will not walk away from reform of the courts and of the legal profession in the interests of all Australians.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Thank you, Minister, for your answer, as far as it went. Unfortunately, I did not have the honour of serving with Senator Cooney and you on the cost of justice inquiry. I came to the committee later. Minister, why is the Attorney blaming the courts for the effect of his decision or the government's decision to cut legal aid funding? Hasn't it always been inevitable that the legal aid cuts would result in more Dietrich applications with the guilty walking free and the innocent unable to clear their names? How does the government believe that the Dietrich principle should be softened to enable cases to proceed to trial, and why is the government's view inconsistent with the right that every Australian should have a fair trial?

â€”Senator McKiernan, I think you perhaps may not have the benefit of the full extent of the Attorney's remarks and I will endeavour to get them from him so that you can put it in proper perspective. I accept there is no malice intended on your part. You can only ask questions on the basis of what you have read in the paper if you don't have the full content of what he said. But the Attorney is not seeking to blame the courts for any government decision whatsoever. I think that is a gross misrepresentation of the Attorney's intention. I will get such remarks as he can make available to clarify the situation for you.

â€”My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, yesterday Senator Minchin said that the National Biodiversity Council had no idea what it was talking about when it said the Native Title Amendment Bill will have profoundly negative impacts on Australia's biodiversity. Minister, considering that it is your advisory body, is this your view too? Is it not the case that your government's Native Title Amendment Bill allows the states to bypass native title and change land use by upgrading pastoral leases? Do you, at least, recognise that this is what the National Biodiversity Council says will have a significant impact on the environment? Do you intend to correct Senator Minchin today, or are you happy to again be rolled in your obligations to protect the environment?

â€”I was surprised that I did not get asked the question yesterday. I welcome it today because the Biodiversity Council is unfortunately under a misunderstanding in this matter and we might be able to help them out.

answer.para: The bill allows state and territory environmental land management to continue unhindered by the unintended consequences of the operation of the existing Native Title Act following the Wik decision. It does not add to the rights of leaseholders, nor does it upgrade pastoral leases. Pastoralists will only be able to carry out those primary production activities permitted under the terms of their leases or under government permits, regulations and legislation. There is no new provision to upgrade existing pastoral leases and the bill will not mean massive freeholding of pastoral lease land.

Under the existing Native Title Act, states and territories, of course, can already acquire native title rights. If they do it through non-discriminatory means, this will continue. Environmental, land management and other laws and regulations remain in force and must be complied with by leaseholders.

Further safeguards are provided by government amendment during the bill's debate in the Senate, ensuring that on large pastoral leases, that is, over 5,000 hectares, new primary production rights cannot be granted over more than 50 per cent of the lease. The bill ensures that governments cannot convert a pastoral lease into a freehold or other exclusive tenure simply by granting additional primary production or associated rights.

State and territory governments have told the parliamentary joint committee that there is no intention to change current lease management practices. The Commonwealth government considers that environmental management is important in its own right and is not an appendage to the Native Title Act. Of course, the Commonwealth's commitment to the Natural Heritage Trust of $1.25 billion demonstrates the priority this government places on effective environmental management and conservation.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Minchin also said yesterday, and I quote:

question.para: The Prime Minister . . . has decided not to designate a proponent under the administrative procedures approved under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 in relation to the decision to proceed with legislation to implement the 10-point plan.

Was it your advice to the Prime Minister regarding the environmental impact of potentially downgrading the protection of natural habitat, accounting for 42 per cent of Australia's land surface? Will you table that advice? Will you continue to ignore the advice of this eminent council, just as you have ignored ATSIC, conservation groups, constitutional experts, the Law Reform Commission and the Reconciliation Council, together with churches, in this debate?

talk.start.para: â€”The answer in relation to the EP(IP) Act is that the parliament is deciding whether to take this legislative course of action. This is in the hands of the parliament. It is not as if it is a normal type of development proposal where consideration has to be given and it does not come for parliamentary consideration. Some might humbly say that the course of this parliamentary process is the most thorough evaluation of these matters that might be possible. It gives the Democrats, for example, the opportunity to argue their position on the public record and for us to put a counterview. So that is why, I presume, the Prime Minister considered that it was inappropriate in these circumstances to invoke that act, because it is being addressed through a parliamentary process.

answer.para: Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”Madam President, on 24 March Senator Harradine asked me a question about imported blood products. I have received an answer from Minister Wooldridge and I ask that the answer be incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

SENATOR HARRADINE: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can me minister confirm that the CSL and the department are negotiating a lucrative arrangement which would be quite financially favourable to the recently privatised CSL? Will the arrangement involve the importation of plasma into Australia to allow CSL to establish a large blood products pool? If so, how can the government provide an absolute guarantee of protection for those Australians who are to be treated with products derived from plasma imported into Australia by CSL?

Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could you confirm there are negotiations going on for the establishment of the large blood products pool by CSL? If so, then what consultations have actually taken place with blood transfusion services, hospitals, consumer organisations, relevant members of the medical profession and others? When is a final decision on this particular matter to be made?

Minister Wooldridge has provided me with the following answer. There is no intention to establish a large pool of blood or plasma products manufactured from foreign plasma for general use. From time to time small amounts of finished foreign product are imported into Australia for individual use when domestic products are not available or are clinically contra-indicated. In addition, between 1995 and 1997 an overseas Rh(D) immunoglobulin was imported to supplement a shortfall in domestic production

However, because demand for most plasma products is increasing faster than the Red Cross can collect plasma, there are currently no significant reserves of key plasma products. The Australian health care system, like many overseas counterparts, is vulnerable to a crisis that results in a major but temporary reduction in domestic supply or production. Patient lives can be put at risk if alternative products are not readily available. Therefore, contingency plans are being considered, including the establishment of a minimum national reserve of key products (which could be made from foreign or domestic plasma) and encouraging foreign manufacturers to register products for use in Australia in such circumstances.

Whatever strategy is adopted to deal with a critical shortage, the welfare of patients will be paramount and the use of foreign products, or products made from foreign plasma, will only be considered where the Therapeutic Goods Administration is satisfied that the products are safe and efficacious.

Consideration of the options is at an early stage and a decision is not expected in the near future. Once the options have been fully developed, key bodies such as the Red Cross Society, State health authorities and medical colleges will be consulted. Minister Wooldridge would be happy to arrange for the Department to provide a more detailed briefing for Senator Harradine as the options are developed.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the financial interests of Senator Parer.

Today, of course, we have had a very significant change of tactics from Senator Parer and the government. He just cannot answer the questions. So now have the new tactic from the government: Senator Parer will not even try. It has just got far too hot now for the government.

For the past couple of weeks we have had a different tactic from Senator Parerâ€”that is, evasion and non-answer. It has been pretty difficult because there has not been a ready answer to most of the questions that have been asked without admitting to a breach of the standing orders, a conflict of interest or a breach of the Prime Minister's code on ministerial responsibility. That has always been a bit too hard for Senator Parer and for the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and his government.

Today we see the new government tacticâ€”that is, total refusal to answer. He will not even try to answer the questions that are put before him. The suggestion has been made by the minister, `I do not have to answer these questions. It does not matter that I have misled the Senate on no less than eight occasions.' It does not matter that he has failed to comply with the standing orders of the Senate and the requirements that each and every other senator has had to comply with. He does not have to answer any questions about that.

He does not have to answer any questions about the fact that he has failed to comply with the Prime Minister's code of conduct. Senator Parer cannot be expected to answer any questions about the fact that he has been the minister responsible for seeing a redefinition of the Prime Minister's code of conduct. Senator Parer cannot be expected to come into the Senate and answer questions about a conflict of interest. That is far too difficult for Senator Parer. He cannot be expected to answer questions which have meant that the government has been involved in redefining the concept of conflict of interest.

Minister Parer is now really saying to the Senate and to the Australian people, `It's too hot. It's too difficult. It's too hard.' He cannot answer the questions so today, the last day of the sitting week, he comes up with a new tactic of he is not going to try to answer.

The questions that Senator Parer refused to answer today are questions about his own area of ministerial responsibility. These are questions that he is required to answer. In failing to answer them he has been engaged in yet another breach of the Prime Minister's Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility. The code basically makes the point that ministers are required to answer questions. The code states:
In general, questions asked at question time are answered fully by ministers.

It does not say what when it gets too difficult or too hard or too hot that ministers, like Senator Parer, can duck out. There is a new tactic from the government in relation to Senator Parer. Senator Parer might be going to say that questions asked about mining companies that he is involved with and that have interests in coalmining and other resources which he has ministerial responsibility for in this country are not relevant, and he is not going to answer them, but I think the case has been proven that they are relevant. We intend to continue asking this minister for answers to questions. We intend to continue to keep the pressure on this minister.

talk.start.para: â€”Monday is another day.
â€”Monday might well be another day, Senator Ray, but even the weekend and Friday will be another day.

speech.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”I promise you that even tomorrow is another day, Senator Campbellâ€”just wait. A minister is required to come in here and answer questions. He cannot duck his ministerial responsibilities. It is not acceptable conduct and, for the opposition's part, we intend to hold the government and the minister responsible. I can guarantee Minister Parer, the Senate and the government that we will be back next Monday and demanding answers to questions of this minister. (Time expired)

â€”Here we have the same old cracked record about Senator Parer going on day after day. It is becoming entirely irrelevant and the truth is that no-one is listening any more. No-one is listening to this nonsense that we are hearing day after day in this chamber. People are heartily sick of it.

speech.para: What they want to hear from the Labor Party is a bit of policy. They want to know what the Labor Party is going to do about some of the problems facing this country like tax reform, for instance. They neglected it for 13 years and all of a sudden, because they think they might be able to embarrass Senator Parer, they are raising the issue of trusts and everything else.

If we look at the facts, what has happened? It was during the life of the Labor government that the use of trusts escalated. Need I remind them that between 1991-92 and 1995-96 the use of trusts grew from some 300,000 to 398,000â€”a growth of about 32 per cent. They did nothing about it. What they fail to recognise is that the real reason for the growth in trusts was that they did nothing about the urgent need for tax reform.

We have seen the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Gareth Evans, since they have been in opposition ignore the tax problem. He said repeatedly that there is nothing wrong with the tax system and it does not need changing. I remind opposition senators of what Gareth Evans said on the Sunday pro gram on 17 August last year. He said, `Those who say that the tax system is broke are really being quite a bit absurdly breathless.' He told the National Press Club that tax reform is a second or third order public policy economic issue.

Mr Evans has been saying in the past that there is no problem with the tax system. What did he say only a day or so ago? He walked into parliament and when doorstopped he said, `We've got a big tax problem.' What hypocrisy and inconsistency we have seen from the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Opposition. A few months ago he was saying. `There is nothing wrong with the tax system. It ain't broke, don't fix it.' Now he is saying that we have a big tax problem and it needs fixing. It is this government that is doing something about fixing the tax problem.

talk.start.para: â€”No, it's not!

â€”Yes, it is indeed. You are attempting to obstruct it, Senator Cook. Let us have a look at this hypocrisy. We have seen their hypocrisy on the issue of tax; let's see their hypocrisy about the declaration of interests. Need I remind the Senate that section 5 of the senators' interest orders states:

speech.para: (a) at the beginning of his or her speech. . .
and
(b) as soon as practicable after a division . . . if the senator proposes to vote in that division

Inter alia, senators must make a declaration of their interests. The fact is that there are some 14 Labor Party senators who have not declared relevant interests when required to do so under that provision.

talk.start.para: â€”Is Cookie one of those; is he okay?
â€”No, I think Senator Cook might be okay.
â€”No, he's got the yacht.

â€”That's rightâ€”the yacht, but there is a number. Senator Bishop, sitting over there, under his register of interests he shows that he has shares in BHP. Yet, on 29 May last year, Senator Faulkner proposed a disallowance of the Customs (Prohib ited Exports) Regulations Amendment which removed the export controls on four resource commodities, including coal and liquefied natural gas. But Senator Bishop did not declare his interest in BHP after the division was called, as required by the order.

speech.para: What about Senator Crowley? As we know, she has a whole range of shares. Senator Crowley is a very wealthy woman. Among the shares which she owns are Qantas shares. This was added to the register on 29 August 1995. Qantas is a major lessee at airports throughout Australia. Its continued access to those major airports and the level of landing fees are key business issues for Qantas. But Senator Crowley completely failed to declare her Qantas shares when she voted in the second reading division for the Airports Act 1996, which establishes the framework for leasing FAC airportsâ€”a second example.

Senator Denman owns shares in CSR, a sugar milling and mining company. The Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1997 removed the tariff on imported sugar, but Senator Denman did not declare her interest in CSR at that time when she voted on the division. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”This government can run, but it cannot hide. Every editorial writer in Australia has shrieked in their editorial columns that Senator Parer should resign or the Prime Minister should sack him. That is what they have said. It is a matter of notorious public controversy. Question time is one of the few occasions in the parliament when the opposition has an opportunity to grill the government about its conduct of public administration and its conduct of its private affairs. This is the time in which the government is accountable. What we have had from the government is the old trickâ€”dodge and evade; never answer the question. A direct question gets evasion and dodging, but today they got worse. They were trying to run away even further. They put up the stone wall and refused to answer questions relevant to the public debate and, I contend, absolutely relevant to the conduct of the affairs of this minister in this portfolio.

speech.para: We are led in this nation by a weak, insipid, indecisive Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister had the guts and the courage of his convictions, he would have dismissed this minister ages ago. That is what he would have done. But look at his behaviour. Today in the House of Representatives he was asked a question by my colleague Simon Crean. Let me read that question to the Senate:
Does the Prime Minister recall his argument of Tuesday in relation to the QCMM (ESP) sale of its Pan Australian shares to Lacetal Pty Ltd?
And this is a quote from the Prime Minister. He said:
. . . the purchaser of the shares had no relationship at all to the minister or to the Parer family.
Let us get very clear what the Prime Minister said:
. . . the purchaser of the shares had no relationship at all to the minister or to the Parer family.
The question goes on:

Is the Prime Minister aware that, at the time of the Lacetal purchase, Mr Harold Shand was a director, the same Harold Shand who is secretary of the Parer family trust and Director of Queensland Coal, Kiskin and AQRM, and the same Harold Shand who is a long-time friend, legal adviser and golfing partner of Senator Warwick Parer?
It concluded:

Prime Minister, how could you claim the purchaser of Pan Australian shares `had no relationship at all to the minister or to the family trust'? Hasn't Senator Parer caused you to mislead this parliament?

There is a clear proposition, pointing the Prime Minister to the words he uttered, setting the facts on the record, and asking the Prime Minister whether he unwittingly or wittingly misled the House on this occasion?

Madam Deputy President, that is an open and shut case. What did the Prime Minister do? What did this weak, insipid Prime Minister, this indecisive Prime Minister do when confronted with that very clear example of a breach? He sought to mislead the debate. He tabled a letter. The letter is to the Prime Minister. It is signed by the same Mr Harold Shand, I am advised, although the signature is indecipherable. The letter says:
Dear Prime Minister,
I understand the question has arisen as to whether Senator Parer or any company associated with him or his family has now or ever had an interest in Lacetal Pty Ltd. The answer is no.
The question, answered here in this letter, is: has Senator Parer had an interest in Lacetal?

The Prime Minister was asked: is it true that Mr Shand, who is a director of the minister's trust, is in fact associated with the purchaser? Well, of course, he is. This letter does not answer that question. This letter draws a red herring across the path. This letter answers a question that was never put. This letter is used to confuse and mislead. Here is a clear case of where the Prime Minister has misled the parliament of Australia. In response to the straight evidence on that pointâ€”indisputable evidenceâ€”what does he do? Does he answer it? No, he does not. He seeks to muddy the waters, to mislead the parliament further, to draw a red herring across the path. In fact, you have to come to one conclusion: the Prime Minister himself has now dishonoured his own code of parliamentary practice. It was a dead letter yesterday when he refused to enforce it; it is an even deader letter today. If this code means anything over the carcasses of Senator Gibson, Senator Short and Mr Prosser, if it means anything at all, then the Prime Minister should now resign as well. He is in breach of his own code of parliamentary standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”The questions directed to Senator Parer that we are considering during this debate on a motion to take note of answers had as one of their themes today why Senator Parer had assets in a trust. There seems to be this attack on the concept that Australians, law abiding citizens, should hold assets in trusts. In fact, the Labor Party have sought to paint the establishment of family trusts and other trust structures as something that they regard as immoral.

speech.para: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), as recently as yesterday, drew to the attention of honourable members in the other place that the use of trusts was not only legislated for during the previous 13 years of the Australian Labor Party government, under Mr Keating as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister, and also with Kim Beazley, the now Leader of the Opposition, as the finance minister, but also during that period there was one of the greatest growths in the use of the trust structure in Australian financial historyâ€”in fact, I suspect the greatest growth of the use of the trust structure.

There is something that the people of Australia should know when the Australian Labor Party try to paint the use of trusts as something immoral or unethical. I think Senator Carr talked about people in western Sydney being able to use trusts or being able to use these superannuation vehicles, and whether they would be able to access the same sort of vehicles as these for their own benefit. The reality is that a lot of small businesses, a lot of battlers, do use family trusts and trust structures to ensure that they provide for their future and for the needs of their families.

talk.start.para: â€”Buy a share for one cent. Make it into $1,000 in a day; that's real good stuff.

â€”Senator Carr does not like a few things in life. He did not like Premier John Cain and he knifed him off. He does not like small businesses and he wants to knife them off. He does not like Australians who choose to invest in Australian companies, such as the Commonwealthâ€”
â€”It's a scam; it's just a scam.

â€”Senator Carr says that people who invest in great Australian companies like the Commonwealth Bank are investing in a scam. He reflects on his colleague Senator Crowley, who has invested in things like Qantas. People who invested in Qantas or the Commonwealth Bank and, recently, may I remind him, Telstra, have made significant capital gains and significant investment benefits, as has Australia, out of investing in these entities. People who put money in trusts were abiding by the tax laws of Australia that were presided over by the Keating government, by Kim Beazley as finance minister, over the past 13 years. So they abided by laws that Labor presided over. These are law abiding citizens doing the right thing by their nation and abiding by the laws of the nation.

speech.para: Those opposite seek to attack small business. It is small businesses which are the biggest users of these trust structures in Australia. You saw only recently, Madam Deputy President, that the opposition were not prepared to allow rollover relief for capital gains for small businesses. They wanted to ensure that the savings of small businesses and the benefits that small businesses would hand on to their families from building up a business could not be rolled over. They opposed those measures.

They claim that this government has done nothing about tax avoidance, yet for 13 years they did absolutely nothing about trusts. As the Prime Minister said yesterday, they keep saying, `We would have fixed up all these trust problems; all these loss transfers.' They had 13 years to do it and it took the Liberal Party and the coalition government to come into power and enact the trust loss legislation.

These people were failures as far as tax reform goes. The process of tax reform basically came to a grinding halt under Labor when Paul Keating did not get his way at the tax summit about two years after coming into government. Their idea of tax reform is to introduce a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax and a whole range of new taxes, even a gold tax. That is their idea. They have to have their idea of tax reform because they have to spend so much money. They have already announced spending plans for a further $6 billion, so we ask the Labor Party what new taxes they will introduce when they are re-elected to power. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Today we had the unedifying spectacle of a minister taking his bat and ball and going home. We saw Senator Parer simply fail to answer questions, no doubt on advice, because after all, his performance here during the last six question times has been that of a bewildered and befuddled individual, taxing his memory, as he says, trying to remember his past, trying to order it in such a way that he will not reveal anything that could do him damage. All we have seen is a trail of misleading statements in the Senate that has left everyone totally confused, so that when we actually directed questions to him to try to clarify these areas, all we got today was, `I'm not going to answer any questions.' It is like the captain of a cricket side, in the fourth innings, 400 runs behind, declaring, and off he has gone back to his home state. As Senator Cook said, `You can run, but you can't hide.'

speech.para: These questions were in order. Going to the credibility of a minister has always been a question that could be raised in this chamber. I can remember back in 1990 or 1991 former Senator Baume, now the Consul-General in New York, asking me a question on immigration when I was defence minister and not even representing the immigration minister in this chamber.

On the basis of Senator Parer's attitude today, I could have refused to answer the question. I did not. I thought I might as well answer it, get rid of it and settle the matter there and then. But going to the credibility of a minister, both in his past performance and the links into the present, is totally in order.

I say this to Minister Parer: if he is not willing to answer questions here, if he is not willing to stand the heat in the kitchen here, then he should pack up and go. He should have gone, anyway, to save his Prime Minister (Mr Howard) embarrassment. He should have gone so that the code could live on. He should have gone because his very presence here dishonours the decision made by Senator Short and Senator Gibson to resign. He is, in fact, telling them that even though he is in exactly the same circumstances, his career, his persona, his income, are more important than their honour. That is exactly what he has done.

This is not the first time that Senator Parer has not answered questions. He started on Thursday last week when he called a press conference in Brisbane to explain himself. What happened at that press conference? First, all radio and print journalists were excluded. We know the reason for that: they might have asked hard or difficult questions, so his media adviser only invited representatives of the electronic media. When a photographer turned up, he was thrown out. Then the media adviser turned to the electronic media reporters and said, `If you show footage of him being thrown out, you're barred in future.' This pathetic performance by Senator Parer today began exactly a week ago in Brisbane when he would not face the music.

Senator Parer said here the other day that he would take on anyone. Remember that statement? `You're fighting on my ground,' he said. He was not fighting on his ground today; he jibbed it, and jibbed badly. This is part of a strategy. Senator Parer's media adviser has been going around the press gallery this morning threatening everyone. I do not mind if Senator Parer issues writsâ€”that is his rightâ€”but they have gone the extra step. They threatened that anyone who in future writes on these particular matters better watch out because they are going to sue. He will need very deep pockets to deal with that matter, I suggest.

talk.start.para: â€”I think we have established that he has got deep pockets.

â€”Yes, Senator. To quote Arthur Daly, `He's been on a very nice little earner, hasn't he?' It has been a regular little earner when you consider how much money has flowed in from activities that he engaged in, not activities related to his experience in his previous career but activities related to when he was a full-time senator.

speech.para: The other part of the government strategy is to say to the opposition, `Hey, where's your policy?' Is this the same party which, between 1993 and 1996, would not produce one policy until the election period? They closed down all discussion so there could be no scrutiny of their future policies and kept saying, `We'll announce them in the election period.' Even then, they only announced about half of their policies because they had to censor other people so it could not be applied to scrutiny. Do not let them come into this chamber with their double standards demanding that we produce all our policy when they refused to do so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”That was another nice attempt by Senator Ray to rewrite history. The Labor Party is pretty good at that, and Senator Ray is one of the experts. Those who have been here for the last two and a bit weeks know that Senator Parer has been subjected to the most consistent and rigorous questioning that we have seen for a long time.

speech.para: On each occasion, Senator Parer has very clearly, concisely and forthrightly answered those questions. He has done it in detail. He has tabled documents. There really is nothing further that he can say, but the Labor Party senators are so bereft of any new and different ideas that they keep asking the same questions day after day, after day, after day. They are too stupid to understand the answers that Senator Parer has given.

Today, when Labor Party senators yet again asked exactly the same questions that they had asked yesterday, Senator Parer rightly said, `I don't want to waste the time of the Senate. I don't want to stop the Senate from dealing with the real issues of tax, health and Aboriginal affairs, so I will simply say, "Read yesterday's Hansard if you want an answer to today's question because you asked the same question yesterday and I would only give you the same answer today".' Those answers have been clear and forthright. They have now gone on for what was itâ€”10, 12 or 15 days? Senator Parer really has nothing further to answer.

Senator Faulkner tells us that they are going to keep going. This is typical of the Labor Party. It is not interested in the real issues, the ones that most Australians are interested inâ€”things like health and the huge increase in money that the Howard government has made available to states for the health of Australian citizens. The Labor Party is not interested in the matters that Senator Herron was talking aboutâ€”the matters of Aboriginal health and the way that Senator Herron is determined to ensure that the money made available for Aborigines in Australia is directed to their education, health and housing. The Labor Party is not interested in the welfare of Aborigines. It wants to continue asking the same old questions it has been askingâ€”with noth ing new, nothing interesting and no new facts coming forward.

I note that it is the same old Labor Party team day after day. Obviously, no-one on the other side is interested apart from Senator Faulkner, Senator Ray and Senator Cook. Senator Cook, I think it was, used the argument that because the editorial writers are saying something then that should happen. If that were the criterion by which this parliament operated, Senator Bolkus would have resigned from the parliament some weeks agoâ€”that is, when all the editorial writers were saying that you cannot have the alternative Attorney-General leaking confidential court documents so that a criminal, a person who has broken Australian law, can escape Australian law. Yet those confidential documents were released by the supposed alternative first law officer of the country.

If we were going to do what the editorial writers are saying, we would have seen the last of Senator Bolkus a week or so ago. If we were going to do what the editorial writers said, we would have had a GST by now, but that does not seem to be on the Labor Party's mind either. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his total lack of leadership and the total failure of his Government's health policies, as evidenced by:
(a) the rejection by all States and the Northern Territory of the inadequate funding proposals for a new Medicare agreement;
(b) the reduction in funding for public hospitals of $800 million;
(c) the failure of the private health insurance incentive scheme to increase levels of private health insurance;
(d) the increased cost of necessary pharmaceuticals due to the Therapeutic Group Premium changes;
(e) the abolition of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program;
(f) reduced funding for the Public Health Program; and
(g) the reduction in funding for medical research.

We just heard, prior to this debate coming on, remarks by Senator Ian Macdonald in respect of taking note of answers. During his diatribe, his vitriol, he claimed that the opposition was not directing its attention to the real issues that affect ordinary Australians today. I want to take up that challenge because that is totally untrue, as are his other remarks that the supposed unimportance of questions of ministerial propriety are not issues that affect and interest ordinary Australians todayâ€”they certainly are.

As we on this side of the chamber acknowledge, issues such as health, industrial relations, education and taxation are all matters that Australians are vitally concerned about. They are also matters that we have been debating in this chamber and in this parliament this week. Indeed, today in question time Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services in this chamber, was asked questions in regard to the failure of this government's health policies. He was asked particular questions in relation to the abject failure of the private health insurance incentive scheme; a $1.7 billion scheme implemented by this government, supposedly to increase the levels of private health insurance in this country. But, in fact, we have seen a reduction in funding in the last two years to its lowest level ever.

Senator Herron was asked a question in regard to the stalemate between the federal government and the state health ministers and premiers with respect to renegotiating the Medicare agreements. This is a most important issue. It is a matter that has achieved a great deal of public and editorial comment in this country over the last few weeks. It puts the lie to Senator Ian Macdonald's allegation that the opposition is not concerned. We are deeply concerned and we have been making our concerns known in this parliament through, as I said, questions to the minister at question timeâ€”questions which he absolutely failed to answer. When you ask this minister a question about private health insurance or about renegotiating public hospital funding, he talks about immunisationâ€”a most important issueâ€”but he cannot answer the question he is asked. He has to go off and talk about a totally separate issue.

Also, only yesterday we had a matter of urgency debate in this parliament with respect to health funding issues. Today we put on the notice paper, and we are going to debate, this very important issue: the failure of this government's health policies. I turn to the notice of motion I have moved, which states:
That the Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his total lack of leadership and the total failure of his Government's health policies, as evidenced by:
(a) the rejection by all States and the Northern Territory of the inadequate funding proposals for a new Medicare agreement;
(b) the reduction in funding for public hospitals of $800 million;
(c) the failure of the private health insurance incentive scheme to increase levels of private health insurance;
(d) the increased cost of necessary pharmaceuticals due to the Therapeutic Group Premium changes;
(e) the abolition of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program;
(f) reduced funding for the Public Health Program; and
(g) the reduction in funding for medical research.
Here we have at least seven indications as to where this government and this Prime Minister, because of his lack of leadership, have failed the Australian people.

Let us go back to what was said by the minister for health and the Prime Minister at the time of the last election. They made solemn promises to the people of Australia that they would maintain Medicare. But what have we seen? We have seen an impasse reached in negotiations between the Commonwealth and the states on the most critically important aspect of Medicare, that is, the funding to be paid by the Commonwealth to the states to maintain the Medicare system, to maintain the public hospital system.

The situation is that negotiations have now been going on for 12 months or so. The health ministers in every single state, the six states of this countryâ€”five of which, I remind senators, have governments which are not governments of the Labor Party persuasion, but governments of the coalition partiesâ€”together with the New South Wales Labor government and the Northern Territory government, a Country-Liberal Party coalition government, all said to this government, `Your offer is totally inadequate.' They said to this government, `We do not believe your figures when you claim that you are increasing in real terms the amount for the health budgets for the public hospital system.'

That is the position we have reached. This is the greatest crisis in the health system in living memory. Here is a situation where not only did the negotiations between the ministers for health, state and federal, reach a total impasse but also the matter had to be referred to the Premiers Conference, which took place last Friday. What happened at the Premiers Conference last Friday? All the state premiers and the leader of the Northern Territory government walked out of that conference. They walked out as a unanimous show of protest and demonstration of the absolute contempt in which they hold this government with respect to health policies.

Premier Jeff Kennett, no friend of the Labor Party, Premier Court in Western Australia, Premier Olsen in South Australia, Premier Rundle in Tasmania and Premier Borbidge in Queenslandâ€”all coalition supporting premiersâ€”took the last possible stance at the Premiers Conference when they walked out. They went on strike, as it were, against this government over health policies. If that does not send a message to this government, nothing will.

What was the Prime Minister's response? He accused the premiers of adopting kindergarten tactics. The premiers were saying to the government that its offer of an increase in funding for public hospitals over the next five years is simply inadequate. Furthermore, as we have pointed out time and time again in debates this week and previously, the offer that is on the table for the statesâ€”about $2.9 billionâ€”is mostly the money which was taken out of the health budget by this government over the last two years.
