As we have pointed out, in its last two budgets, this government took $800 million out of funding for public hospitals. They are putting some money back in and claiming it is an increase.

This government abolished the Commonwealth dental health program, a program that involved expenditure of $400 million to ensure that the aged and the needyâ€”Commonwealth health card holdersâ€”could have access to dental health care when re quired. That dental health program did wonders in terms of reducing the waiting lists for people who needed dental health care and were unable to afford private dental services. This government abolished that scheme. We now have evidence before a Senate committee that waiting lists have grown back out to two years in some cases. It is the aged and the frail particularly who are suffering because of that.

Through their actions and through their refusal to buckle, to kowtow to the threats made by the Prime Minister, the premiers have been saying to this government that it simply is not good enough. They require an extra $1.1 billion in increased funding per year to maintain the public hospital system in this country, a system that has a reputation of being one of the best public health systems in the world. But it is at risk now because of the attitude of this government. It is an attitude which is typified by this government on the one hand boasting the claim that they will return the budget to surplus this year but at the same time starving the states of the money they need to maintain a viable public hospital system.

We have a situation in the states where waiting lists are growing, but they are growing because of the increasing demand on the public hospital system. That has to be funded. Ultimately, it has to be funded by Commonwealth revenue because, clearly, the states are not in the position of being able to raise the finances to meet that demand.

You will hear Senator Herron get up shortly and talk about private health insurance. Let us have a look at private health insurance. When the Labor government came to office in 1983, there was no Medicare. Notwithstanding promises made by previous Liberal governments, they abolished Medibank, as it was known at the time. Remember also that the current Prime Minister, when he was Leader of the Opposition back in the late 1980s, said that he would set out to dismantle Medicare. That was a promise he made. He promised he would abolish bulk-billing.

When he was honest enough to tell the people that is what he wanted to do, the people said, `No way, John. We're not going to cop that. Medicare is too important to us for you to abolish it or dismantle it.' So when it came to the last election, what did John Howard say? He said, `I will retain Medicare because it is something that the people of this country want and understand is important. It is something that delivers them universal access to health care.' That is what he said. But when we came to government, as I said, back in 1983, there was no Medicare and 30 per cent or more of the Australian population had no health coverage, none at allâ€”no private health insurance and no public health cover through Medicare.

So when you hear Senator Herron talk about declines in the level of private health insurance, understand all the facts. You should understand that, under their regime, 30 per cent of people in this country had no cover. Today, 100 per cent of people in this country have cover, firstly, through Medicare and, secondly, through private health insuranceâ€”around 31 per cent of people have private health insurance.

It is clear that that level has been falling. Why has that level been falling over the years? As I have admitted this on a number of occasions, I have had private health insurance all my life and I have not dropped out. However, people do drop out. People drop out of private health insurance because they cannot afford to pay it in many cases because they get charged up to $2,000 a year, or around about that figure, for family cover. If a member of that family goes into hospital, notwithstanding Medicare and notwithstanding their private health insurance, in many cases they have to find significant amounts of money to cover the total costs of the medical bills.

Premier Kennett himself acknowledged that last week. I have the quote here but I will paraphrase. He pointed out that for many people it just was not economically or financially worth while if at the end of the day you still had to fork out $1,000 of your own money for an operation even after you had paid your health insurance of $2,000 a year and even after Medicare had provided its part of the schedule fee. He said that people were fed up with the gap. So we have had declining levels of private health insurance.

This government came into office two years ago and it said, `We've got the answers to that. We're going to fix it.' Minister Wooldridge said he would implement a scheme whereby Australians would get back a tax rebate of $450 per annum if they took out private health insurance, and if they did not take out private health insurance they would pay an increased levy on their Medicare levy if they had an income higher than $70,000 per year, I think it was. This scheme would cost $1.7 billion over three years, which was around about the amount that the government took out of the public health system from the hospitalsâ€”the $800 million plus, the $400 million out of dental and money out of other programs such as public health programs and others that I know my colleague Senator Crowley will talk about.

They implemented this scheme and Minister Wooldridge saidâ€”and I asked Senator Herron this question today and he could not answer it; he talked about immunisationâ€”that by the end of this financial year, only about three months away, coverage would increase to 34 per cent. That is what you said.

talk.start.para: â€”I didn't say that.

â€”But the result of the decision is, Senator Herron, that today it is at 31.6 per cent, which is lower than what it was when you came to office. So when you talk about trends you were the people who said that you had the answer to get private health coverage to go up, but in fact it is going down. It has reached its lowest level ever. All of this will cost $1.7 billion that you have ripped out of the system.

speech.para: People are still dropping out because, at the same time, what has been happening? Any value that could have been there out of this rebate of $450 a year is being eaten up by increased premiums in excess of 20 per cent in the last two years. The health funds have put their premiums up. It has become automatic now. They are now going to increase their premiums on the same day every year. This is a little deal they did with the government, so that the government did not get embarrassed when every few months another fund would increase their premium. The government got the funds to agree that they will all put their premiums up on the same day. I wonder what the competition commission would think about that. People are being offered $450 as a rebate but in order to get the $450 they have to spend $2,000 or more. There is a whole range of other issues, and I am sure other speakers on the opposition side will go to them.

I will just close on a couple of other points. This government said that it would maintain Medicare. What have they done? They have closed 44 Medicare offices in the country. They have closed all of the Medibank Private offices. Here is a government that says that they encourage private health insurance but they have closed down the offices of the government's own private health insurance fund, Medibank Private. They have severed the connection with Medicare offices. They have ultimately reduced the number from around 240 to 70 offices around the country.

In closing those 44 Medicare offices, it is very interesting how they worked out which ones should be closed. This demonstrates the ideological bias of this government. In the state of New South Wales, my home state, they closed 14 Medicare offices in the Sydney metropolitan area. Of all the seats in the Sydney metropolitan area exactly half are held by the Labor Party and half by the Liberal Party. So you would think maybe on a rough average half the offices would be in Labor electorates and half in Liberal electorates. But, noâ€”out of the 14 offices that have been closed in Sydney, 10 of them are in Labor electorates and only four in Liberal electorates.

As Madam Deputy President West would be aware, as someone living in a rural location in New South Wales, in addition three offices were closed in regional New South Wales each of them in Labor electorates in Newcastle and Wollongong. That is the ideological bias of a government which is committed to destroying Medicare. (Time expired)

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”I will follow on from where Senator Forshaw left off. He talked about private health insurance. You will recall that during question time I said that private health insurance premiums had increased over 100 per cent and Senator Forshaw called out to me and said, `Tell the truth. Tell the truth.'

speech.para: I am pleased to tell him the exact figures. Between 1984 and 1996, Labor averaged 12 per cent a yearâ€”144 per cent. That is 144 per cent, Senator Forshaw. That is the truth. That is 12 per cent per annum for the 12 years between 1984 and March 1996, when we came to office. In one catastrophic two-year period between 1986 and 1988, premiums increased by 40 per cent. It is the height of hypocrisy for the Labor Party to now start crying about the cost of private health insurance. I am pleased that Senator Forshaw has it. It shows that he has more intelligence than most of his other colleagues to be covered by private health insurance. He has the opportunity for selection of his doctor and the selection of his hospital bed. But, Senator Forshaw, it was 144 per cent under Labor, not 100 per cent. I apologise for that inaccuracy. In one two-year period it was a 40 per cent increase when the Labor Party was in power.

We recognise that we have to take into account the fact that there is an ageing population, as I mentioned, and that the cost of technology is increasing. That would occur whether the Labor Party was in power or whether the coalition was in power. It is a fact of life that technology is improving dramatically and that it is more costly. But that has a converse. The converse is that the bed stay has gone down. People come into hospital, as you know, for day surgery now. Forty per cent of surgery is day surgery. They are only in for a day. Bed stays have gone down by a third in the last five or six years.

It is all very well for the states to come along and complain and reject what they call the inadequate funding proposals of the new Medicare agreement. One thing I learnt about health care in the 40 years or so that I have been involved in it is that it is continually changing. I always remember one of my teachers when I was a medical student saying to our class, `Get used to the sound of jackhammers in your ears, because for the rest of your professional lives you'll be hearing them as hospitals change because of increasing demand and increasing changes in technology,' and that has occurred over the last 40 years of my professional life. So there is nothing new. Change is constant.

The delay in the production of statistics, Senator Forshaw, is about three years at least. If you look at the statistics at any one time you will see that, by the time the statistics are available, they have been bypassed by the dynamics of what is occurring and changing in the health care system. All that we can address is what is occurring. What we can see and what we can be factual about is what is occurring at present in the statistical figures.

I turn now to the health care agreements. If you look at what has occurred between 1993-94 compared to 1992-93, you will see that state spending in New South Wales went down by $50 million, by $53 million in the Northern Territory, by $92 million in Queensland, by $9 million in South Australia, by $32 million in Tasmania, by a whopping $205 million in Victoria, and by $75 million in West Australia. The only one that increased its spending in 1993-94 compared to 1992-93 was the ACT where $17 million extra was spent. In the previous year, again the ACT increased its spending.

When you compare the figures overall for state own spending on the health care systems in that periodâ€”and the 1993-94 figures are the latest figures available as a proportion of 1992-93â€”the ACT had a 13.5 per cent increase while all the other states decreased their health care spending. Senator Forshaw did not refer to that. Senator Crowley did refer to the fact that, when she was in government, the states decreased their spending. As I mentioned in question time this afternoon, I will have great pleasure over the next few days getting from Hansard Senator Crowley's speeches when she mentioned the Medicare agreement over the last five years. I know my colleagues do not want me to do it, but I will look forward to that.

If you compare those figures in that period, New South Wales decreased their spending on health care by 4.9 per cent, the Northern Territory by 43.9 per cent, Queensland by 14.9 per cent, South Australia by 3.3 per cent, Tasmania by 24.9 per cent, Victoria by 22.7 per cent, and West Australia by 16 per cent. That is an average overall decrease of 12.9 per cent. For the states to come along and now say that they need more money when they have decreased the proportion of spending in their own health care system but have instead come to the taxpayers and said, `Give us more money,' is the height of hypocrisy.

It is an even worse height of hypocrisy from the Labor Party opposite because they were the ones that deliberately set out to destroy the private health care system of this country. It was a deliberate move, resisted, I am pleased to say, by the then health minister, Graham Richardson, who tried within his own caucus to tell them what was occurring, but because of ideological and philosophical reasons they would not accept it. Then we had that free-fall in the health care system over private health care insurance rates.

I reject completely the states arguments at the moment. As I said previously, the same arguments were used in a contrary fashion by the Labor Party at the time when they were in power. As well as the growthâ€”that is something we should all be pleased aboutâ€”and ageing of the population, there is the increase in cost in providing health care services. We recognise that. That is going to occur regardless of whichever government is in power. What has happened is that we have slowed the fall in private health insurance because of the actions we have taken. In fact, for one month only, regretfully, there was an increase of 0.1 per cent in the September quarter because of the actions we took. The participation rate is still higher than it would have been had the government not introduced those incentives.

I am quite confident in predicting that, because of the effect in my own state, it will plateau. It seems that certainly in Queensland, which has preceded the other states in the decline in private health insurance, it will plateau in the region of 29 per cent or 30 per cent. It has done so for the last 12 or 13 years. There is an irreducible minimum of people who are prepared to take out private health insurance so that they can have their choice of doctor, their choice of hospital, immediate admission and not have the waiting lists that occur in the public system. That will stay. I believe that it looks as though it is reaching that stage because, overall in Australia, private health cover is now 32 per cent, down to 31.6 per cent in the latest quarter.

The remedial action that was taken in relation to private health insurance of the higher income earners, as I mentioned in question time, will not be available to us until probably September-October. There is no reliable prediction at the moment as to what that plateau will be, but plateau it will.

There are increases in underlying demand. All of us are aware that a few years back the most common surgical procedure done in this country was a coronary bypass procedure. But now we have gone beyond hip replacements, knee replacements, elbow replacements, finger joint replacements for rheumatoid arthritis, insertion of cartilage to rheumatoid arthritic joints. Instead of joint replacements we are now putting in cartilage which belongs to patients themselves, so there is no rejection of cartilage in joints. Instead of just the correction of joints, pain is also relieved by micro-surgery and the insertion of cartilage.

talk.start.para: â€”Is this a debate or a consultation?

â€”This is going to cost more. The point is, Senator Forshawâ€”all of this is going to cost moreâ€”and even you, Senator Forshaw, when you get an arthritic joint as you get older would be prepared to do it.
â€”That is why you ought to give the states more money.

â€”Unfortunately, younger people are dropping out of private health insurance and you have got the double effect then of not only increasing demand, but replacement of younger people with older people in the private health insurance system, and it is no wonder that private health insurance premiums increase. There has to be flexibility in the system. Overall, there will be better results for patients because they will be receiving the right treatment at the right place.

speech.para: In addition, the Commonwealth is also offering funding of $500 million for projects to improve the health care system, particularly in integrating care across all sectors. We are continuing funding of around $500 million for mental health care reform and palliative care service delivery, and funding of almost $700 million to reward quality service providers. The Commonwealth is also offering $120 million to address waiting list issues to states as they sign the agreement. We are also moving to full cost purchasing of services for entitled veterans provided in public hospitals. In other words, they can choose the hospital and the provider and, on the basis of current service provisions, that will add another $150 million to state revenue.

We understand the pressures that are occurring on the state governments, and we are taking action to help them remedy those. At the same time, we recognise that they have to put in their fair share of money. It is all very well to cost- shift. As you know and I know, Madam Deputy President, cost-shifting was a difficult factor since you were in government. By that I mean that the community affairs committee, for example, received evidence that public hospitals issued prescriptions on a Medicare basis, and x-rays were ordered from public hospitals which were done through the private system and then claimed against the private system. Those are just a couple of examples.

It is interesting that the ACT has already signed the agreement. It is interesting, in retrospect, when you look at spending in the ACT. Over that period of time that I mentioned previously, they had increased their own spending by 13.5 per centâ€”so it is no wonder that they were returned with a majority in the last ACT election and the Labor Party went down to 27 per cent.

The government will not agree to the requests of the states in relation to the current Medicare agreements because, in effect, they want the Commonwealth to increase its contribution to hospital funding by around 10 per cent. Under the previous Labor government, that is what they did. They decreased their funding, as I mentioned, in that period of time. None of the Commonwealth's addi tional money in that periodâ€”over the three yearsâ€”found its way into health. State funding took three years to return to 1992-93 levels. If the Commonwealth increased funding by the $1.1 billion sought by the states for year one, and if the states maintained their own source spendingâ€”and given their past history, that is a pretty heroic assumptionâ€”resources available to hospitals will increase by at least 10 per cent in 1998-99. That would be enough to pay for over 300,000 more admissions. There are not 300,000 more admissions required in this country at the moment, so it is fatuous for them to ask for that amount of funding.

I have dealt with the public hospitals funding, the private health insurance rates, and the failure of the private health insurance incentive scheme, as alleged by Senator Forshaw, to increase levels of private health insurance. My confident prediction is, of course, that it will plateau. I am happy to table graphs in relation to the growth in own source recurrent hospitals expenditure, between the Commonwealth and statesâ€”indexed to 1992-93 dollarsâ€”which support the arguments that I have already put. Those graphs clearly show the states' record compared with the Commonwealth's over the last five years of the present Medicare agreement. They are based on Commonwealth Grants Commission and state budget data as well as the projected increase in base funding over the next five years under the Commonwealth's proposals. Those graphs compare the 12.9 per cent cut in state-owned spending in 1993-94 with a 12.6 per cent front-ended increase in Commonwealth spending. They show that state-owned spending did not return to the levels of 1991-92 until 1995-96 and that, under the Commonwealth proposal, there will be a significant, sustained rise in base funding every year over the five years of the agreement. I completely reject the proposals put in Senator Forshaw's motion in that regard.

talk.start.para: â€”Minister, are you tabling those documents?
â€”I am happy to if they want me to. They may not want to see them; it will refute their argument.
â€”I think the usual procedure, Senator, is that if you are tabling it, you do not need to but, if you are asking to incorporate it, we do need to see it.
â€”No, I did not. I said I am happy to table them if that is requested.
â€”To assist Hansard , I am trying to find out if you are going to table them or not.
â€”If the Labor Party would like them tabled, I will table them.
â€”They are tabled? Good.
â€”Because it completely destroys their argument, I will table them.
â€”If you can't figure out whether to table or not, how can you figure out the funding?
â€”I am happy to table them, Senator Forshaw. I thought you might like to see them. The other matters will be covered by successive speakers. The motion then refers to:

speech.para: . . . the increased cost of necessary pharmaceuticals due to the Therapeutic Group Premium changes;

The indexation of pharmaceutical benefits charges and the reduction of numbers of therapeutics that were available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme were brought in by the Labor government because of a cost-saving measure. All that we have done with the therapeutic group premium changes is to make comparable drugs available which have the same therapeutic effect, but those that are on the PBS rather than those that are on the private health system; so that the patient will not be affected by the availability of groups that have a similar therapeutic effect but will cost the taxpayer less.

If that had been allowed to continue, as the Labor Party well knows, the exponential rise in the cost of the PBS to the taxpayer would continue. There has to be some modification made because of the increasing cost of the PBS to taxpayers, again related to the ageing population and to the dramatic increase in the number of people in these older age groupsâ€”as I mentioned, from 350,000 to 750,000 in the over-75sâ€”in the next eight years.

There is an increased cost, there is no question about that, but there has to be a stage reached where it is impossible to continue an open-ended scheme that is going to cost the taxpayer more and more without increasing taxation. As you know, that change was launched recently. There have been other changes, of course,

The Commonwealth announced the national prescribing service in the 1997 budget last May. Funding of $22 million over four years will be provided for this unique and exciting approach to encourage the quality use of medicines, and fundings will be contingent on savings to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $24.4 million over the funded period through encouraging quality and more cost-effective prescribing. It will aim to improve health outcomes in Australia through appropriate and cost-effective prescribing, by providing national leadership to facilitate and promote quality prescribing in partnership with all stakeholders. That initiative has widespread support from all stakeholders.

The national prescribing service will primarily receive its funding from the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services. However, as a company limited by guarantee, operating at arm's length from government, opportunities will exist for other sources of funding to be incorporated. Profits will be used to advance the interests and objectives in the company and cannot be distributed to members for their own benefit.

In summary, we recognise the cost increases that are occurring for the state governments. There is no question of that; we do not resile from that. These things are occurring and would occur whichever government were in power. They are an inevitable result of the ageing of the population and the increasing use and dramatic nature of the technology that is available. Yet, what do we hear from the Labor Party? What is their solution to this inevitable increase? We have not heard a word, except to increase taxation. But that will not solve the problem of the ageing population, and it will result in more people dropping out of private health insurance. We need to get back to the era when at least 40 per cent, and preferably 50 per cent, of people are covered by private health insurance.

It is a fact of life that the throughput of the private hospitals is much less than the public hospitals. There is nothing wrong with that. It is because the teaching component in the public hospital system and the various related research activities mean that the cost of running public hospitals is higher than the cost of running private hospitals. Interestingly enough, those opposite might allege that it is because of the gross profits that are made in private hospitals. The largest private hospitals are not for profit and are church owned in this country. So that allegation is not correct either.

talk.start.para: â€”I am very appreciative of my colleague Senator Forshaw moving this motion which states:

speech.para: The Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his total lack of leadership and the total failure of his Government's health policies, as evidenced by:
(a) the rejection by all States and the Northern Territory of the inadequate funding proposals for a new Medicare agreementâ€”

I will hopefully come back to the other points listed in the motion during my contribution. First of all, I want to reinforce and restate the quite horrible pictures that we all saw of all the state and territory premiers walking out in an unprecedented experience at a Premiers Conference, because they realised that the proposals by the Commonwealth government were going to be quite insufficient to deal with the challenges of adequate health funding in this countryâ€”unprecedented. I believe Senator Herron is going to leave this debate, which is a great pity; you should stay and have your ideas reformed, Senator.

talk.start.para: â€”He is coming to join us.

â€”I am not sure we should welcome that, not with his views. The health issue is becoming so important to the state and territory governments, and so clearly at a deadlock, that it became an item for a Premiers Conference. That is pretty unusual. From time to time, premiers will take up an argument on behalf of the states about some mattersâ€”for example, guns and gun law changesâ€”which are not necessarily specific to premiers' responsibilities, but usually health business is worked out between the Commonwealth and state and territory health ministers. Here we have seen the pushing and shoving going on for so long and to so little effect that it became an item at the Premiers Conference.

speech.para: The premiers realised in very short time that they would get no comfort at all from Mr Howard and Mr Costello. They were not prepared to talk to the states about any more reasonable way of tackling the problem of health costs. So we all saw that very unseemly picture of the premiers leaving: `No point in staying.' `There's no further conversation.' `Take the money or leave it.

`Take the money or leave it' might be an appropriate line if you are debating things down a dark alley and it might be reasonable in some sorts of business, but it is hardly the line you would expect from a Prime Minister of this country when talking to the premiers of the states. That is essentially what he saidâ€”`Take the money or leave'â€”and they left. Indeed, it is quite amazing to me that even though we have a conservative Prime Minister and only one Labor premierâ€”all the other state and territory governments are conservative or from the same party as Mr Howardâ€”that does not make for any easier negotiation.

I believe what is important in all of this debate are some hard facts. The idea is being proposed that there be a full audit of the cost of health. While I would not go so far as to support it, it would seem to suggest that what we do need is some hard data. Senator Herron tabled a document that suggests that it is the states which underfunded health, not the Commonwealth. While Senator Herron was suggesting that he would go back and find my speech when we were in government that might embarrass me, I think he will be more embarrassed by his own contribution back then because what Senator Herron did in opposition was constantly blame the federal Labor government for failure to adequate fund the states.

As I argued again and again and as Senator Herron's little document proves, the Commonwealth contribution to the states over the period of the previous Medicare agreement under the Labor government did have an increase in dollars and it was the states which fiercely cut the dollars back. The more we argued that, the more Senator Herron argued that that was not the case. It takes Senator Herron only about five years to catch up with what are the hard facts. He has now got it right for what was the situation back then. Perhaps if he comes back in the year 2003, he will have it right for this year, but do not hold your breath.

What we have got by the coalition government is a whole series of obfuscated facts and figures. The fact is that the statesâ€”no doubt about itâ€”have fearfully cut back the funding for hospitals within their own areas of responsibility, within the states. There is no doubt about that. They cut that money under the previous health agreement, but under this government and over the last few years the cuts by our state colleagues have been very fierce. In particular, the state that springs most to mind is Victoria.

It is very rare for the doctors of any part of the medical profession to want to strike. Orthopaedic surgeons were minded to do something like that when Minister Blewett was the Minister for Health in the Commonwealth. But in Victoria under Premier Kennett the doctors in the public hospitals were on the verge of striking because they realise what Mr Kennett's government was doing to those public hospitals in particular. As I say, it takes a whole lot to persuade doctors to strike, but they were driven to the very edge of doing that in Victoria.

First of all we need to accept in this argument that the states are responsible for significant cutbacks in their contribution to hospital funding, but that does not absolve the Commonwealth government for being honest about their contribution as they are part of this new negotiated Commonwealth-state agreement in health. It is no good to say the states cut the funding, therefore, we are going to give them only this, it is real and they should be grateful because, as the Labor opposition can point out, the federal government are merely proposing to put back under their Commonwealth contribution to the Medicare agreements a large amount of the money that they have systematically cut out.

It is one thing to blame the statesâ€”and they are guilty and they are trying to make a good case for their argumentâ€”but their situation must not obscure the facts that we have to deal with in terms of the Commonwealth contribution. The argument needs to be put again and again. It is this Howard government that cut $800 million from the hospital system. It is this Howard government that has cut over $400 million from the Commonwealth dental health program. It is this government that has cut funding from within the health service and now it big notes itself by saying that it is giving the states real increases by doing no more than putting back the money that it has so mean-spiritedly taken out over the last couple of years. It has had only two budgets, but it has damn near wrecked the health system in this country.

If you really want to know one measure of the mean mindedness of Mr Howard, consider the Commonwealth dental health program. The people who were eligible for assistance with dental care were older people through the public hospital system and that money was just pulledâ€”lock, stock and barrel. It is just called, `Too bad. If you need your dental care, see what you can negotiate on your own behalf within your state areas. The Commonwealth has withdrawn its funding.' What is meaner than taking away dental support and dental care for elderly Australians? When you add that to the whack they were given in terms of proposed changes in nursing homes, you would have to say that this Howard government has no empathy at all for that section of the community, the older people in this country.

Senator Herron's contribution to this debate is nothing if not confused. On the one hand he says they are not responsible for the fall in private health insurance. No, somehow or another, having spent two years in government they are responsible for nothing when it comes to bad things. He then goes on to blame the Labor government: somehow or other it is all our responsibility for being in government for 13 years and wrecking the system. He certainly does not like the fact so well put by Senator Forshaw that, when we came into office in 1983, over two million Australians had no health insurance and what they got under Medicareâ€”what everybody got under Medicare, what every family in this country got under Medicareâ€”was protection from any of those health bills. That is what Medicare gave people.

As the people of Australia got used to Medicare, they embraced it. They really appreciate what it does because it says to them, `If you are sick, if you need an operation or if you have to see your general practitioner, you have to worry about being unwell but you do not have to worry about how you can pay for it. You are protected against the big health bills that have so crippled people in the past.'

In the lead up to the 1983 election many people in Australia were sicker than they needed to be because they could not afford to go to appropriate health care. The Labor government fixed that with the introduction of Medicare. People have said again and again that they want Medicare protected. They do not wantâ€”and they are telling us very clearlyâ€”to pay ever increasing and huge dollars for private health insurance when the one thing private health insurance gives you is access to a health bill.

If people think that this is me being a Labor Party person and going on, then I shall refer them to Access Economics. They came along and spoke to an AMA dinner in this Parliament House last week. I think it must have been very sobering for my Liberal-National party colleagues who were along to hear Access Economicsâ€”which is known to be from the more conservative side of the political spectrumâ€”making absolutely clear that private health insurance is a bad packet. It is a very poor economic outcome. Why would anyone want to buy it?

Take two citizens: one pays taxes; one pays the Medicare levy and that is all. They have decided no private health insurance. Compare that to the next citizen who has to pay taxes, who has to pay the Medicare levy, who buys private health insurance, and then has to pay hospital bills on top of it. It is, in simple terms, a very bad package. People in the communityâ€”the coalition government fails to realise they are not doltsâ€”are walking away from that in droves. The price of private health insurance is going through the roof, pushed there by the insane rebate offered by the coalition government. Why wouldn't people take the money? It was money for jam for the private health insurance industry and they took it.

What this means, of course, is that people buying private health insurance, who are trying to maintain it or come into it, have to pay a significant increase in their premium. It has gone through the roof: over $2,000 a year for a standard family with a couple of children. That is very big money for people who are doing it very tightly. That is a lot of dollars that people have to find. They say: `$40 or so a week versus no cost at all and the protection of our public hospital system. Why shouldn't we settle for that?' In droves they are doing that. Let us not forget the $1.6 billion handed out in rebate over three years to encourage people into private health insurance, only to see the rebate lost in almost the first rise of the cost of private health insurance and also further reduced by the number of people leaving private health insurance.

The government should have realised that the best way to help the public health system in this country, the best way to help the health system of all citizens, is to extend and promote our Medicare system and our great public hospitals. If you are really crook, where do you go? You go to our public hospitals. I like to think that the best example of this is Mr Kerry Packer. When he had a heart attack playing polo he was taken straight to Westmead hospital and it was the public hospital system that restored Mr Packer's good health. He moved on to a private hospital after that, but that was where his life was saved. If you talk about people who are in intensive care, they are in the public hospital system. If you have an accident or an emergency, I still do not know of any public hospital in this country that has ever turned away a patient.

The government is trying to big note itself in small packages. If you sign up on the agreement then you will get extra money to try and run down waiting lists. I heard Senator Knowles say in this place the last time we talked about health that in 13 years of Labor government nothing was ever done to run down waiting lists. I do not mind a bit of political over the top-edness but I do object strenuously to blatant misrepresentation of the facts. On a number of occasions the Labor government did put money into the public hospitals. On one occasion it put in $40 million, to be matched by the state governments and, of course, with that extra money the waiting lists dropped.

But I think we need to talk about waiting lists because I have a very interesting response here from the government which runs contrary to what Minister Wooldridge and Senator Herron say. I asked in a question on notice:
How many people were waiting for surgery in South Australian public hospitals on 1 November: (a) 1997; (b) 1996; (c) 1995; and (d) 1994.
And the answer was:
The Commonwealth does not hold this data.

So I would be interested to know how it is that my Commonwealth colleagues are forever reciting almost any figure that comes to mind about the size of waiting lists. They make it up. But their own department says to me, `We cannot give you those figures, we do not hold that data.' So I think your first challenge is, Minister Wooldridge, where do you get your figures from? I have noticed over the last few weeks that the waiting list figures are now 50,000, 70,000 and 100,000. It just depends on which conversation you are listening to. The answer from the Commonwealth department goes on:

However, it should be noted that waiting lists are a poor indicator of hospital and health system performance which do not necessarily provide an accurate indications of problems relating to access to elective surgery.
Many hospital admissions, including elective admissions, occur without the patient ever being on a waiting list.
Some period of waiting may be appropriate, depending on the clinical urgency of the case:
. waiting lists provide a mechanism for scheduling admissions so that the most urgent cases are treated first; and
. the clinical urgency of cases on the waiting lists is therefore more critical than the number of cases.

Because of these factors, it is accepted by both Commonwealth and State/Territory health authorities that it is more appropriate to focus on admitting people to hospital within clinically appropriate times than on the number of people waiting at any point in time.

So a million people on a waiting list may only have to wait a week. That is significantly different from 10 people having to wait two years. We do not ever hear that explanation. We are back to big figures and a scare campaign from the government itself. Who do they think people in the community are going to judge when they find things wrong with the health system? Sometimes I think this coalition government does not really know it is in office. The response continues:
For elective surgery, the incentive is not based on the number of people on waiting lists but on the length of time people wait on the list before admission to hospital.

It is important, if that is what the Commonwealth department is saying, that the ministers might want to be `in sync' with their own department. We know that is the case and it would be very useful to this health debate if we actually had a discussion about waiting times, and what procedures have long waiting times, rather than scare campaigns about the size of the waiting lists. In fact, the people who have a long waiting time are the people waiting for orthopaedic operations; ear, nose and throat operations; and eye operations. That has been the case since the 1950s, that those three types of patients have to wait on waiting lists for a long time. In almost every other area, urgent and elective surgery is dealt with in very acceptable and short times.
In the few minutes remaining, I want to talk about the public health point in Senator Forshaw's motion:
(f) reduced funding for the Public Health Programâ€”

We have been able to pursue this through the estimates. I have asked questions about this, as have my colleagues. I was interested to note that a little while ago the proposal has come from the government to roll together the public health issues, particularly women's health, family planning, breast cancer and so on, into one broadband of Commonwealth funding in negotiation with the states.

When this was proposed the first time round I was told that there would be a 10 per cent cut in this funding. This was called an efficiency dividend. My question was: why is there a 10 per cent efficiency dividend for this part of public health, particularly women's health programs, and a three per cent dividend over the rest of the department? It is interesting that the answer contained, and I should think everyone would agree, a fair amount of bluster. It was a nice way of saying, `We are straight cutting the funding.'

I have sought further information about family planning. The answer I received confirmed what I have been saying. Interestingly, family planning organisations in the states have been, by and large, actually able to negotiate with the Commonwealth that they not be included in the public health outcome funding agreements. They will continue to get their funding as a separate amount. As a result, the contribution of the Commonwealth meant that there was only a reduction of 3.3 per cent in 1996-97 but a five per cent reduction in 1997-98. The figures show that in every family planning service across Australia there has been a real drop in funding. When you put that with Senator Herron's gobbledegook contribution, how can you deal with decreased funding at a time of increased demand on services?

One of the things we need to know about family planning services is that they are providing a lot of assistance for men as well as women. They are providing advice and assistance not just in family planning and pregnancy care but in the management of sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS. While you have an increasing need for that kind of service and a decrease in Commonwealth funding, which is expressly and explicitly spelt out in this document from the department, there is a grave concern. It is the same for other areas of public health through public health funding.

talk.start.para: â€”I welcome the opportunity to address the motion moved by Senator Forshaw for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that it gives me the opportunity to address some of the issues in my own state of New South Wales which will prove just how reprehensible the opposition's allegations are in this area. Senator Forshaw's motion states that the rejection by the states and Northern Territory of the Commonwealth's Medicare agreement is evidence of the failure of this government's health policies.

speech.para: It seems to me that yet again it is important to reinforce the point to those opposite and to those listening that the states are doing nothing new in this round of health care agreements. They are playing politics at the expense of their own communities and basically making patients in their own states wait in pain. The rejection by the states and Northern Territory of the agreement is, as I think Senator Herron said earlier today, standard operational procedure when an agreement like this comes up for renewal. They are posturing performances that only hurt the patients in the states of the health ministers and premiers.

The Commonwealth's offer to the states and the territories is a generous one. It is an offer that contains $2.9 billion in new funding over five years, over and above the forward estimates, and would increase Commonwealth spending from $26 billion under the 1993 to 1998 Medicare agreement to $30.17 billion under the 1998 to 2003 Australian health care agreements.

Let us have a look at the extra $2.9 billion and the commitment in that regard. It involves an extra $1.5 billion in base funding over the next five years; an extra $750 million for veterans in public hospitals; and for initiatives in efficiency and effectiveness in hospitals an extra $500 million, particularly in the area of information technology. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, this week took the Senate through this in answer to a question from me, another $120 million will be spent on waiting lists in public hospitals. That is $2.9 billion of new money. It is a 6.9 per cent real increase in the first year of funding and over the five years of the agree ment will amount to a 15.4 per cent real increase.

The premiers cannot see fit to think about their constituents, their electors and the patients in their own states. Some 1,300 people on waiting lists for elective surgery will not be admitted for treatment this week due to the state and Northern Territory governments' rejection of the Commonwealth's $2.9 billion increase in funding at the Premiers Conference last week.

The critical and urgent treatment waiting lists incentive which provides $4 million a week for 30 weeks did begin this week, with the ACT government able to draw $550,000 to treat 200 people. That incentive money is available to the states and territories once they have signed an in principle agreement over health funding. So an extra 1,500 people around Australia could have been helped this week and every week for the next 30 weeks. As the Chief Minister of the ACT, Kate Carnell, appears to be the only state or territory leader and the only health minister prepared to put patients first, the number getting assistance is only the 200 in the ACT. One asks oneself how the premiers and health ministers can treat sick people in their states this way.

Some state ministers are attempting to claim that they can only benefit from the CUT waiting list incentive if they signed the health care agreement lock, stock and barrel. That is simply not true. It is just one of the distortions, one of the misrepresentations that some of the ministers are peddling. All that a state has to do in order to access this waiting list incentive pool is indicate that they are willing to sign in principle. They lose nothing by signing an in principle agreement, but gain immediate access to extra money to treat people who are suffering on their waiting lists.

The premiers' performance has just led to hurting patients in their own states. As Senator Hill said yesterday one hopes that their tactics were not calculated to let that happen but certainly the Commonwealth will not. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) responded speedily in this regard and said that the key parts of the Commonwealth offer would be implemented even if the state premiers could not see their way clear to come to some agreement. Notwithstanding their posturing, notwithstanding their walkout and notwithstanding the reasons for which they said they did it, the Commonwealth, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) will not let patients suffer as a result of that particular approach.

The Minister for Health and Family Services has made repeated and clear statements on the issue. The message is very clear. It is that the states' demands for an extra $5.5 billion should be dismissed. The states themselves cut their own spending in the early years of the last agreement and to date not one of the states or the Northern Territory has given a formal guarantee that they will at least maintain their present spending over the next five years.

So what is their political response to that? While they demand a 40 per cent increase in Commonwealth spending, they are yet to guarantee that they will not reduce their own spending. The actions of the states and the Northern Territory are not a reflection on the Commonwealth government's health policies, as we are aware. It has been stressed over and over again by a number of people, particularly Senator Herron in preceding me today, that the states demand is a play at politics and it is financially irresponsible.

It is important to record what some of the states in particular are doing. It is of great interest to me to look at my own state of New South Wales and what can only be described as the waiting list fiasco there. At the end of last month, more than 50,000 people were waiting for elective surgery, giving the Labor government in New South Wales the particular honour of being the government responsible for the highest ever waiting list in New South Wales. It can be described as nothing less than a waiting list catastrophe. Of the 50,778 people on the list, 4,602 of them had been waiting for more than 12 months, and the average waiting time has gone from 27 days to a month and a half.

But let us think about what happened when the Labor Premier of New South Wales, Mr Carr, and his Minister for Health, Andrew Refshauge, came to office in March 1995. What they did, and it was an interesting tactic, was stake their jobs on the need to drive down waiting lists to around 20,000. Three years down the track, in March 1998, what do we have in front of us? We have a record of in excess of 50,000 people on waiting lists. So the question has to be asked of the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Carr, and the health minister, Dr Refshauge: what happened? How is it that you can storm out of premiers conferences posturing about increased funding when you cannot even keep your own commitments to your own constituents? They have no-one else to blame but themselves because it is in fact the case that Commonwealth grants to New South Wales health increased in the last financial year. Dr Refshauge blames every one and every thing and every aspect of politics that he possibly can; he is unable to take responsibility himself.

Let us look at the situation in some of the hospitals in New South Wales in particular and make a comparison between what the previous New South Wales coalition government achieved and the Carr Labor government's ability to manage elective surgery waiting times. I am obviously particularly interested in what is going on in western Sydney, an area of New South Wales which is particularly important to me. In Bankstown and Lidcombe the number of people waiting more than 12 months in March 1995 was 11. In January 1998, the number waiting more than 12 months was 214 peopleâ€”an increase of 1,845 per cent. In Concord Hospital there was an increase of 266 per cent over the same period. In Liverpool Hospital the number rose from 78 in March 1995 to 271 in January 1998â€”an increase of 247 per cent. In the new childrens Westmead Hospital, which is firmly located in the area in which I work in western Sydney, the increase was from 11 in March 1995 to 50 in January 1998â€”an increase of 355 per cent; and in Westmead Hospital there was a 120 per cent increase from 160 in March 1995 to 352 in January 1998. The average of that particular processâ€”from 2,264 to 4,602â€”is a total increase of 103 per cent. If Dr Refshauge and Mr Carr cannot read the writing on the wall from that, I am sure the people in New South Wales will bring it to their attention in March of next year.

There is in excess of a dozen reasons why the behaviour of Dr Andrew Refshauge and the New South Wales government in relation to the new Medicare agreements has resulted in the New South Wales health system being far more to blame for this, than any allegations they can level against the Commonwealth. I have already addressed the question of the number of people waiting for elective surgery in New South Wales public hospitals, but let me remind you again: a promise of 20,000, now at 50,778.

More people are waiting longer for surgery. By January 1998, 4,602 had been waiting for more than a year. In March 1995, that number was 2,265. The average waiting time is out to one and a half monthsâ€”that is six weeks; in March 1995 it was 27 days. But apparently none of this is the fault of Dr Refshauge or Mr Carr. It is someone else's fault and they, of course, conveniently blame the Commonwealth. Perhaps they could explain this in some detail to the 118 emergency patients, on average, who in January were left lying for at least eight hours on a trolley in a corridor waiting for a hospital bed after being seen by a doctor. Perhaps they could explain to the people using hospitals in our state, including those who want to park in car parks, their lack of knowledge of an across-the-board increase of 12.5 per cent in hospital user chargesâ€”blaming the policy on their Director-General and then backing away from it.

The errors in the health restructure in New South Wales, again, were blamed on the Commonwealth. In June 1996 there were threats to close established hospitals, including St Vincents in Darlinghurst, and to axe 800 jobsâ€”without cabinet backing and with no industry consultation. So I do not know how the states can say, as they have in this context, that it is all the fault of the Commonwealth. Senator Forshaw in his motion made allegations in relation to a reduction in funding for public hospitals and inadequate funding proposals for the new Medicare agreement. The facts are that those responsible in the states, and particularly in my state of New South Wales, cannot walk away from the state of their health systems.

In many cases in New South Wales they are unable to pay their bills. The health minister came out and admitted at one stage that $10 million was owed to creditors over 45 days. It was later revealed that it was actually $40 million. How much does the minister know about what is really happening in his own health system? These issues cannot be avoided by the states. They need to face up to them and not simply blame the Commonwealth for everything that happens.

We have been told at length this afternoon about alleged failures of the private health insurance incentive scheme. I think Minister Wooldridge made it clear last month that Labor's attempts to denounce the scheme are irresponsible and largely based on untruths. Despite the claims of those opposite and the figures that are continually being bandied about, it is the facts that are important. When the Labor government came to power in 1983 and looked at private health insurance levels, it is hardly surprising to know that they fell from 70 per cent to 35 per cent by the time they left government.

This government has had the best results in the last two quarters over 10 years and, as the minister states, this is a very important aspect of the entire issue. The level of participation of Australians in private health insurance is the third highest in the Western world. As a direct result of the government's scheme, 300,000 people now have private health cover who would not have it if we had not acted. The reality is that private health cover for most families is now $450 cheaper than it would be otherwise.

Points on this issue have certainly been acknowledged by Senator Herron, and made before that by Senator Forshaw and Senator Crowley, but I also indicate that the Commonwealth has made a very clear commitment that if private health insurance numbers fallâ€”and no-one has a crystal ballâ€”there is $83 million available in that regard for the states. That is being blatantly and clearly ignored by those responsible in the states and is another part of their efforts to muddy the waters on this issue.

Senator Forshaw's motion refers to the alleged increased costs of pharmaceuticals in relation to the therapeutic group premium charges. I am surprised that Senator Forshaw and those opposite are having such a difficult time understanding what is a very sensible and necessary program. The introduction of the TGP, following last year's budget, has been canvassed in this chamber on many occasions. The motion claims that the TGP has increased the cost of necessary pharmaceuticals, but it is important againâ€”and unusually, for many of those oppositeâ€”to look at the facts.

The facts are that the pharmaceuticals included in the TGP are drugs which all have a similar therapeutic effect. The facts are that when the products were first listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme they were all promoted by their sponsors as having similar safety and efficacy as other drugs in the group. So what the TGP does is to provide a benchmark- price drug in each group. This benchmark drug has continued to be subsidised at the current levelâ€”$3.20 for concessional consumers and $20 for general consumers. So in each of the categories under the TGP, there is at least one drug that will cost the patient no more than at present.

The now more expensive drugs were originally listed on the PBS because they were of similar safety and efficacy. The patient can choose a more expensive drug but will need to pay the difference. Alternatively, in the vast majority of cases, they can choose to take the benchmark drug and continue to pay the same amount. It is not as if there are not opportunities for exemptions or to consult with one's physician on these issues, as the opposition would have us believe in many cases.

The facts are that this government has not implemented a program that has increased the cost of necessary drugs. We have maintained the cost to consumers of necessary drugs at a subsidised price for affordability. The facts are that this measure was taken so as to ensure the continued viability of the PBS. Surely, even the interest of the opposition in the health system of Australia must extend to how it is funded. We have taken measures to ensure that we can continue to provide the highest quality pharmaceuticals to all Australians at a subsidised price.

I draw to the attention of those opposite in relation to this funding issue that, even with this measure, the PBS is expected to grow by a further $200 million in this financial year. It would be irresponsible and negligent not to address these issues. I, for one, as a member of the government, am very pleased that the government has taken these issues on board and made some effort to address them.

Senator Forshaw's motion referred to funding for medical research. It is one of the most extraordinary parts of the motionâ€”an allegation that the government has cut funding to medical research. This year alone, the government has provided more than $163 million to strengthen medical research in this country. It is the highest annual amount ever committed under the National Health and Medical Research Council program.

In my state of New South Wales, the Commonwealth provided for $37.5 million for researchers, institutions and universities committed to research projects ranging from laboratory investigations through to studies of clinical treatments and public health strategies. This government acknowledges Australia's remarkable capacity for medical research. It acknowledges Australia's remarkable history in international achievements in medical research and it acknowledges Australia's remarkable future in this area as well.

We have shown a commitment to research in the areas of hepatitis C, cancer research projects, HIV-AIDS projects, diabetes, indigenous health, drug and alcohol research, and in youth suicide prevention, to name a mere few. Our commitment on medical research is unmatched. It is an extraordinary allegation from those opposite to suggest that the government would walk away from what is an enormous opportunity for this nation.

I am also intrigued by Senator Forshaw's allegations in relation to the Commonwealth dental health program. Those opposite know exactly what the plans for the CDHP were. They know exactly why the promises were made in 1993 and they know exactly what the intention was after the next election. It was never intended to run beyond the four-year agreement laid out at its introduction. I have had the opportunity to attend as many of the public hearings on this issue as Senator Forshaw has. It is quite clear to me that all the posturing in the world from those opposite will not walk away from the political promises which led to the CDHP in that regard.

It seems to me that in relation to the allegations made by those opposite regarding the Commonwealth's commitments in the health area, the states and the Northern Territory have a great deal to answer for. But those who have the most to answer for are those opposite. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I support Senator Forshaw's motion. I support it on the basis of the very great concern that exits in my state. However, as I address the motion I think we will come to realise that we face a double whammy in Tasmania. Firstly, I would like to consider how we reached the current position.

speech.para: The current five-year Medicare arrangements between the Commonwealth and each state and territory government will expire on 30 June this year. It is essential that the funding arrangement is reviewed and a new arrangement reached on health funding. Public confidence in the health system is at an all-time low and all state and territory leaders are preparing to mount a campaign against the Commonwealth governmentâ€”the Howard governmentâ€”over the funding crisis.

However, the Prime Minister and his ministerâ€”so aptly named by the Bulletin as `Medicare's Dr No'â€”appear to have no regard for the pleas coming from the state and territory leaders and their respective medical professions. The record of negotiations leading up to the 21 March Premiers Conference walkout clearly shows that, all along, this government has been unwilling to negotiate. It has simply drawn a line in the sand and told the states and territories, `That's all you'll get. Talk to us by all meansâ€”we're all earsâ€”but we're giving you nothing more than our original offer.'

On 19 December 1997, following earlier meetings in May and August, the Common wealth made an offer which would supposedly increase funding by $1.7 billion over five years. The states rejected the offer. On 15 January 1998 the Minister for Health and Family Services offered an incentive payment of $100 million to help the states and territories reduce elective surgery waiting lists, if agreement was reached on the Australian health care agreements by 16 March 1998. The ACT is the only territory government to accept that offer in principle.

On 10 March the Commonwealth increased its original base funding offer to the states and territories by a further $1.1 billion to $2.9 billion over the five years of the agreement. The offer was rejected by the states and the Northern Territory. On 13 March Mr Howard accused the state and territory governments of reducing their hospital funding in the early years of the current Medicare agreement. On 21 March the premiers walked out of their conference with the Prime Minister and his minister.

We have to ask why they walked out: I suppose, in their words, `All Mr Howard's and Minister Wooldridge's offer is doing is putting back the money that they have taken away and slashed from health funding in their first two budgets.' The Prime Minister claims he is offering an extra $2.9 billion over five years, but when we look at the detail we see that previous budgets have simply taken that money out. The Prime Minister's first budget slashed $800 million from the hospital system and it also scrappedâ€”as has been said beforeâ€”the Commonwealth dental program, saving a further $400 million and leaving many thousands of Australians without dental services.

talk.start.para: â€”With decaying teeth.

â€”Who has been expected to pick up these cuts, Senator Quirke? We have been reminded on many occasions of the great conservative win at the last federal election, and of course it has been the conservative state governments, with the exception of one. They must all be wondering to themselves, `Well, who needs an enemy when you've got a friend like Prime Minister Howard.' Is it any wonder that they are keeping up the pressure on the federal govern ment. Not only state governments but also doctors throughout the medical system in Australia that are doing so. I will read a couple of quotes by one person who would have some idea about the circumstances being confronted by Australia's hospital system and that is Dr John Yu, the former head of Westmead's new children's hospital in Sydney. He said:

speech.para: I'm not sure how well briefed the Prime Minister is. I'm certainly disappointed that Dr Wooldridge does not have a better understanding of what is happening.
He also said:

Public hospitals deserve a better deal. There is really a crisis in the public hospital system. We are faced with the denial of treatment for things many of us would believe were the right of any Australian.

In my state the Liberal health ministerâ€”and I say `Liberal health minister'â€”responded to a statement put out by seven Liberal members of the federal government. It was signed by Mr Chris Miles, Mr Warwick Smith, Senator Newman, Senator Eric Abetz, Senator Watson, Senator Brian Gibson and Senator Calvert and said, and I find this very interesting:

The present financial deal covering health and General Revenue Assistance for Tasmania represents a 2.7 per cent increase in funding. This is at a time when inflation is negligible and Tasmania is experiencing population stagnation.
That is an interesting proposition for them to be putting. They must be real pleased about that! The statement continued:
The Commonwealth's offer to Tasmania is fair, reasonable and will contribute to improving Tasmania's health systemâ€”
As I said before, in Tasmania we are getting a bit of a double whammy. But what does the state minister say about that? I quote:

State health minister Peter McKay dubbed the seven federal Liberal parrots, repeating the Commonwealth's argument, and warned that they would be picked off by the voters. Mr McKay said, `The fact sheet distributed by the federal Mps with their press statement confirms state fears that Medicare funding to the state in last week's Commonwealth offer was actually cut by $27.5 million.
I found an interesting cartoon in the Examiner of seven galahs sitting along a branch. That would make interesting reading.

talk.start.para: â€”Table it.
â€”That is very good advice from our National Party senator in the chamber. I seek leave to table the document.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”Doctors right across Australia are also saying that the hospital system is in crisis because federal and state governments have not put in the additional money that our public hospital system needs. I referred to the double whammy that has occurred in Tasmania because a state Liberal government has taken money out of the public hospital system and that is a real problem. We have a reduction at the Commonwealth level and at the state level, despite Mr McKay's best efforts to hide it and avoid argument in the state parliament, there has been a reduction as well.

speech.para: That does not excuse the fact that the Commonwealth government has plucked out a huge amount of money from Commonwealth revenue to the states. As has been said by many others, the $1.7 billion that the government provided as an incentive to get people back into private health insurance was plucked off the states in the first place. It ought to be of further pain to the federal Liberals that, on 10 March this year, when a delegation from Tasmania came to Canberra, Senator Newman and the Minister for Family Services, the member for Bassâ€”one of Tasmania's major hospitals is located in the electorate of Bassâ€”failed even to turn up. I find it interesting that they were not prepared to meet the delegation and listen to the arguments that needed to be put on behalf of the state about the crisis that our state system is in.

Let us look at the circumstances before the last election. In opposition, this government promised Australians they would subsidise private health. They endeavoured to do that, but they did it on the basis that there would be a reduction in the number of people leaving private health insurance. In fact, the then opposition said there would be an in crease in the number of people who would take out private health insurance cover.

I would like to refer to some figures, in particular, the figures since this government has been in control of the treasury bench. The latest drop of 0.4 per cent means that 66,000 people quit private health insurance in the last quarter of 1997; that is 700 people for every single day. On page 145 of the budget papers for 1996-97, Dr Wooldridge, in regard to the intended impact of the budget measures on the private health insurance incentive, said:

It is intended that the measure will stabilise the private health insurance participation rate. The funding estimates are based upon the assumption that the coverage of private health insurance will increase from 32 per cent of the population (expected at 1 July 1997) to 34 per cent in 1997-98.
What we find is that, rather than that, we are down to less than 32 per cent. This is, as I said, amidst all the promises that the government made and the packages they put out saying:
The Howard Government's Private Health Insurance Incentive was announced before the 1996 Election, re-announced in the 1996-97 Budget (August 1996) and took effect from 1/7/97.
The package has two components:
1. rebates for low income earners who take out (or maintain) private insurance; and
2. a penalty Medicare Levy for high income earners who do not.

When we look at the measures taken and the claims made by the government during that time with regard to the portfolio statement I have just read out, there has been no increase at all. Dr Wooldridge, in his press statement at the time, said:
We are expecting about 70,000 high-earning single people and 65,000 couples and families to join health funds as a result of this measure.

It just has not happened; it has not happened because the rebate did not serve as an incentive to people on high or low incomes to either join or maintain. The reason it did not happen was that health insurance premiums have gone up. This is another thing that Dr Wooldridge spoke about in his press release. He said:
The Government is also acting to ensure the value of incentives is not eaten up by rises in premiums.

It did not seem to work very well. The increases proposed on 8 March 1997 when National Mutual Health Insurance announced premium rises of up to 15.4 per cent are the sorts of things that the government really has to take a look at. If the government had taken the $1.7 billion and put it into the public health system, into public hospitals, as Michael Lee pointed out some time ago, they could have paid for an extra 3,000 beds and the treatment of more than 100,000 extra patients per year. It is fundamentally a failing of the government to understand the health system.

What is more important and what must be of serious concern to the Australian public is this: it all seems to point to the government undermining Medicare. Prior to the last election, when Mr Howard was under pressure, he said, `We love Medicare. We'll keep Medicare.' It appears that the government is trying to get rid of Medicare by stealth. It must cause serious concern to the Australian public that the government is forcing this issue now by way of cutting back on the states' funding and not offering any real funds to assist the public hospital system in this country. It must cause serious concern that, by stealth, the government will get rid of the Medicare system. It must cause serious concern that the government will go back to the circumstances that existed prior to 1983 and to the system that the government speak so highly of in which so many Australians had no health insurance cover.

If that is what the government wants, then let the people judge the government on it at the next election. I am sure the people will judge the government harshly. As the government's own conservative premiers say, and as the state health minister in my state says, `Let the people judge the Liberal members and senators'â€”I note Senator Newman is sitting across the chamber nowâ€”`who are supposed to represent them in this parliament.' Now that Senator Newman is in the chamber, I will refer to a motion moved by Senator Newman some time ago which was very critical of the government of the day. On 11 May 1994, Senator Newman gave notice of this motion:
On the next day of sitting I shall move:
That the Senateâ€”
(a) notes:
(i) the cutback in funding in the 1994-95 Budget for the reduction of public hospital waiting lists and the Government's failure to spend funds on maintaining hospital infrastructure; and
(b) condemns the Government for the abrogation of its responsibilities to improve access to quality hospital care for all Australians.
Remember that, Senator Newman?

talk.start.para: â€”Yes, I do. You had allowed it to run down. We inherited your mess.
â€”I am sure you remember that. It is funny how Senator Newman has changed her position today. She has signed onto the statement that says the deal is very fair for Tasmania.
â€”It is much fairer than the deal you gave them.

â€”As I said, Senator Newman ought to read what the state minister said about their statement. He has dubbed them a bunch of parrots, and he says that the statement, along with the graph that was put out, confirmed their fears that the Commonwealth actually cut Tasmania's funding by $27Â½ million. So it is very interesting that you, Senator Abetz and Senator Gibson have changed your positions. I will read a quote from Senator Abetz's first speech in this place. He said:

speech.para: Funding to Tasmania ought to be on the basis that Tasmania is entitled to all the rights and entitlements of a fully-fledged state.
I thought it actually was a fully fledged state, but he goes on to say:
Funding simply on a per head basis denies us, as a stateâ€”
we made it to state in the second sentenceâ€”
from enjoying all the infrastructure requirements we need to effectively run our state in such areas as . . . healthâ€”
Very interesting, Senator Abetz. It seems you have a different view when you get to government. Of course, Senator Gibson, on 13 October 1994, stated:

The agreements between the states and the federal government have not yet been made, and there is a suspicion that the federal government is pushing off responsibilities to the states and giving them a certain amount of money, but expecting them to do far more than that money will ever achieve.

As I said, Tasmanians ought to have some suspicions about the current position of the Tasmanian Liberal members and senators, and I think they will make very severe judgments on them. Senator Gibson said those things at the time, and it is very interesting, as I said, to see those opposite sign up to this document. After they have ripped the guts out of funding to the states, all they are going to do is give them back what they took away. It is the old rob Peter to pay Paul. But, of course, there are many issues that are yet to be resolved.

One of the greatest reflections on the government is this: it is not so much what the government ultimately offers; it is the capacity of the government to actually sit down and negotiate an arrangement that provides the Australian people with a hospital system and a health system that is fair and equitable. That is where I think the real breakdown is going to come. Right now, the government is offering no solutions. I do not think it has the capacity to sit down and negotiate those arrangements, and Australians are going to suffer as a result. That will be a very sad day.

If we do not do something in the very near future, we are going to see a very sad state develop, and the people in Tasmania and the people in the rest of Australia will suffer very severely as a result of that. Our state was promised much by this government. As yet, none of that has come to fruition. This health debacle is just another example of how we are being treated contrary to what the government promised us at the last election.

talk.start.para: â€”The best we can say about Senator Murphy's address to the chamber is that, as a health spokesman, he makes a very good unionist. Senator Murphy mounted his case by quoting North Shore doctors as his source and, indeed, his friends, and he failed to address the motion that Senator Forshaw has before the Senate at the moment. In fact, the government rejects the motion before the Senate, and I am more than pleased to take Senator Murphy through the motion, from (a) through to (g). Point (a) reads:
