speech.para: . . . the rejection by all States and the Northern Territory of the inadequate funding proposals for a new Medicare agreement;

The premiers walking out was nothing more than a stunt. It was a failure. Only yesterday the government assured this Senate during debate on an urgency motion moved by the Democrats that there would be no loss of public health services through this stunt.

In many respects, this general business motion today is out of date. It is too late. The Democrats' urgency motion, which the government supported, puts paid to point (a) of Senator Forshaw's general business motion today. Regardless of the stuntâ€”and it now seems obvious that each Premier had his own particular political agenda, none of which related to health care at allâ€”the fact is that the funding, as previous speakers have said, is an increase on past funding agreements.

In the last five years, the Commonwealth has in fact spent $27.3 billion on Commonwealth-state health care agreements, and the forward estimates show that the funding will rise to $30.3 billion over the next five years. So the government is committed, through its estimates, to increasing public expenditure by an additional $3 billion to a level of $30.3 billion. On top of that $30.3 billion, it has offered the states an extra $1.5 billion in base funding over the next five years.

All of this is going to be paid even though the state premiers refused to accept the federal government's offer. In addition, the Commonwealth is also prepared to pay another $120 million to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals. Therefore, what we are offering above the forward estimates is some $2.9 billion extra. That is a 6.9 per cent increase in the first year of funding, moving to a total over the three years of 15.4 per cent. When you consider the inflation rate, which is basically zero, that is a very generous offer indeed. We reject point (a) of Senator Forshaw's motion.

The truth is that the states came to that meeting with an ambit claim. I cannot believe that they were serious. They had a completely different agenda. It was an ambit claim, and in the corridors of the parliament it was accepted to be an ambit claim. The states and the Northern Territory were holding out for an additional $1.1 billion increase in base funding in the first year and an additional $1.1 billion in each subsequent year. That amounted to a $5.5 billion increase over five years. That was over and above our already increased offer of $2.9 billion. That is an ambit claim in anyone's language or on anyone's analysis. The states' demand would have lifted Commonwealth spending from $26 billion in the 1998 Medicare agreement to $35.67 billion over the next five years. That would have been a 37.2 per cent increase, an unsustainable proposition rejected by the Commonwealth. That may have caused the walkout, but there is no way we can come back to the table and negotiate an agreement under those ridiculous terms that the states put forward.

Moving on to point (b) of Senator Forshaw's motion, it relates to the reduction in funding for public hospitals of some $800 million. The first point to make here is that I do not accept the $800 million figure that Senator Forshaw has put to the Senate. This was a question asked of and answered by the Prime Minister in question time on Monday and it was also asked today in the Senate. The point is that we do not accept the $800 million figure given that the government has returned very large sums by way of specific programs and initiatives.

The first example of targeted funding was the immunisation program. It was necessary to fund that directly and it was targeted out of Commonwealth funds as it was an area that the states had completely abandoned, and the Commonwealth simply had to take it up. They abandoned it to the detriment of Australian children's health. The second example of target funding, which reduces that $800 million put forward in this motion, was the $4.8 million to tackle eye health in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, including the antibiotic to treat trachoma in remote areas. This was, again, an initiative necessary for the Commonwealth to take up and to target the funding in that area. So we reject that figure of $800 million.

It was necessary to fund directly and the reality of it was that in the 1996 budget the government was assigned the task by the Australian people straight after the election to reduce the debt legacy that we had been left, the $10.3 billion budget deficit and, equally as difficult, the $100 million government debt. The financial system was under strain and, as the new government, we had to get about the task and tackle the financial problems before us. The reductions in the health portfolio were aimed not at the health services but in producing much needed efficiencies in the hospital and ancillary health services in the area of administration. Since then, we have seen many of the hospital boards merging and becoming more efficient. It cannot be denied that there was a need for efficiencies in the administration of hospitals and other ancillary services.

I am even informed of late that before the Premiers Conference the Victorian government sent out to all the hospitals the need for an efficiency gain of some one per cent. They see that there was definitely fat there after the 1996 election. There is still room for some efficiencies in the administrative area, not at the cost of services. We reject point (b) of Senator Forshaw's general business motion. Point (c) reads:
the failure of the private health insurance incentive scheme to increase levels of private health insurance;

The question of the state of private health insurance is very fertile ground for this coalition to debate given the previous record of the Labor government. Madam Acting Deputy President Knowles, as you would know very well, between the years of 1983 and 1996, 13 years of Labor government, private health insurance went into free fall and fell from a very high 70 per cent to somewhere around 35 per cent and premiums rose 12 per cent in that time. The consequences are obvious. As people fled the private health system, the burden increased in the area of public health. The gap between what was raised from the Medicare levy and what was needed to fund our health services grew ever wider.

This fact was recognised in 1993 by what potentially seemed like a very courageous minister, the then minister for health, Senator Richardson. He set about trying to do something about the collapsing situation of Medicare and the fleeing of the private health insurance system. As the then minister said:

The trouble is, you see, when people on higher incomes drop out of private health insurance, they do elbow the old pensioner out of the queue because if you're on a hundred grand a year you know how to work the systems.

When he went to cabinet with his plan, the then Prime Minister stood on him. He said that he was going to need a lot of courage. Of course, he did not have the support in cabinet. No changes were made and private health insurance continued to go into free-fall.

It took this government to have the courage to make those changes. In contrast, we acted and introduced in our very first year of government a situation that is stabilising the free-fall in private health insurance membership. We accept that a great deal more can be done. We will act over time to make sure that we can improve the system. We have introduced the private health insurance rebate scheme to the value of $450 and set it at a cut-off rate of earnings.

Further, we have introduced an extra Medicare levy of one per cent for high income earners who do not take out private health insurance. Those opposite have opposed both initiatives by this government but yet failed to act at all during their 13 years of government. We take it from Senator Forshaw's motion and previous speakers that our initiatives are not working. I refer them to the statement by the AHA which said that the system would have fallen even further without the government's initiatives. To that extent, we have stabilised the fall in health insurance. We look for a better trend in the future.

Point (d) of Senator Forshaw's motion relates to the increased cost of necessary pharmaceuticals due to the therapeutic group premium changes. It has to be remembered that, in relation to this government's initiative, this government's fundamental structural reform is that the PBS is the most generous system of its type in the world and it is important that we maintain it. There is no other equivalent system in the world as generous as the PBS.

This policy initiative is about the wise use of medicines and the wise use of health dollars striking a balance. Independent, well-qualified medical and scientific experts have advised on the appropriate groups of medicines within the initiative. No patient needs to pay one cent more for their medicine because, within each group, other medicines with similar clinical effects are available at a base price. Exceptions are available where there is a clinical need.

Point (e) of Senator Forshaw's motion relates to the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program. In her address, Senator Crowley asked: what could be meaner than abolishing the Commonwealth's assistance to the dental health program? Let me remind Senator Crowley and members of the chamber that it was the 1993 budget by the previous government that announced that the eye test for families and elderly people would be removed. On top of that, they were going to be slugged $49.50 for the first consultation with an optometrist and $25 for a follow-up consultation. What could be meaner than that?

The Commonwealth dental health program was only ever meant to be a support for what was initially a state program. It was there to assist the states in alleviating a backlog of service demands and to set the states up for the longer term. As usual, the Commonwealth was left holding the baby on this matter. The provision of dental services is a matter for the states. It is a state responsibility. It is up to the states to determine how it will deliver its own dental services to lower income earners.

In the short time I have I would like to touch on one area that interests me, and that is the area of rural health. I would like to single this area out because this is an area where the government has brought in major reforms by taking bold initiatives. I want to compliment the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), because there has probably been no other minister who has had the courage to make the strides he has in improving health in rural areas. His legacy will be not only the fundamental policy changes he has made in the area of rural health but also the cultural changes in getting rural doctors into remote areas. The cultural changes could take up to a decade, if not longer, given the training time that doctors need, but he has definitely laid down the groundwork for the future to improve the state of rural health in getting doctors out into rural areas.

Some of the initiatives of late from the minister have been: firstly, the federal government will establish 100 extra places in medical schools for overseas trained doctors to complete their education to Australian standards on condition that they sign a contract to work in rural and remote areas. This was followed up just recently by a publication `A step by step guide to help rural communities to attract and retain a doctor within their area'â€”so information is going out to the rural areas.

Another initiative of this minister has been to look to new technologies, such as telemedicine and the Internet, to help improve the poor health status of many people living in rural and remote areas. There has been an enormous take-up of the very successful John Flynn scholarship scheme. Each scholarship is worth some $2,500 annually and will assist selected students to undertake rural electives during a vacation period. Also, to address the problem we have in the area of rural health, the government will provide $27 million over four years for six departments of rural health in universities across Australia, which will provide training and support for rural doctors and other health workers. Also, $20 million will be allocated to rural hospitals and medical schools to fund projects to provide opportunities for medical students and graduates to train in their particular rural area. That just about puts paid to every point. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to support Senator Forshaw's motion with the knowledge that to most Australians there is no more important issue than health care. In this respect, Australians expect their federal government to provide the essential requirements for their basic health care needs. Unfortunately, as last week's debacle of a Premiers Conference showed, this coalition government has pushed Australia's health system to the brink of collapse and, in the process, has put in jeopardy the health of all Australians. As a result of the Prime Minister's arrogance and stubbornness, every conservative state Premier and the conservative leader of the Northern Territory walked away from a mean-spirited man who is ideologically opposed to funding a universally free health system.

speech.para: Let us start by making a very clear contrast between the coalition and the Labor Party. The federal coalition under this Prime Minister detests everything for which Medicare stands. It rejects Medicare's universal access to public hospitals based on medical need rather than income. It rejects that Medicare provides for free or low-cost visits to GPs, and it rejects the subsidised medicines that Medicare provides through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The evidence of this rejection is plain for all to see. It is this government which is determined to destroy bulk-billing by cancelling the annual increase in doctors' fees, and therefore making it less attractive for GPs to offer bulk-billing. It is this government which has made a mockery of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by introducing the manifestly unfair and medically dangerous therapeutic group premiums. Now it is this government which has put universal access to public hospitals at risk by refusing to take the responsibility to adequately fund Australia's hospitals.

The Howard government's attack on every major component of Medicare is irrefutable proof that the conservatives despise Australia's universal health system, which has been developed by three separate Labor governments over the past few decades. The leadership of the Prime Minister once again is under the microscope on this issue. His paltry offer to the states would mean that Queensland hospitals would have to operate with about $60 million less in the upcoming financial year than they had last year. This is a state which already has a $7.1 million budget overrun, and has 12,170 people al ready waiting longer than medically advisable for surgery.

It is a state where the health minister, Mr Horan, refuses to release monthly audit performances for the obvious reason that he fears letting the public know the true position of the Queensland health system. Yet the Prime Minister is telling Queenslanders that their access to public hospitals will be even further restricted, and that those people on waiting lists will have to wait even longer periods. Just as bad is that the Howard government is saying to Queensland and other states, `Close your wards, rationalise services, delay the introduction of new medical technology and forget about non-vital capital works.' These may not be the words and the rhetoric coming out of the Prime Minister's mouth, but his actions and his inadequate offer to the states are directly giving this message.

This government despises public institutions. We have recently witnessed the transfer of funds from public schools to the private education system. Similarly, the Howard government's motivation in health has been to transfer funds from the public sector to prop up private schemes. Over the past two budgets the coalition has ripped $800 million out of the Australian public hospital system. Added to that cuts to the Commonwealth dental health program total $400 million and half a billion dollars has been slashed from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

A total of $1.7 billion has been removed from the public health system over the past two years. It is no coincidence that this figure is virtually identical to the amount taxpayers have paid out for private health insurance subsidies. In essence, that is $1.7 billion removed from the public system on a failed private initiative. When the Howard government came to office 33.8 per cent of the population had private health insurance. Now it is down to 31.6 per cent, with 66,000 Australians in the December quarter electing to opt out of health insurance, despite the government's rebate initiative.

When the chief executive of the Australian Health Insurance Association, Russell Schneider, was asked on the Daybreak program on 27 August 1996 whether the government's initiative would halt the drift away from private health insurance, he answered:

Oh, I `ve got no doubt about that. I mean, obviously, the combination of measures must increase its attractiveness. The Government rebate system will be giving low-income earners something like a 20-25 per cent reduction in the price, and for high-income earners, there's about 200,000 to 270,000 of those who will be taking it out. So it must increase the numbers.

Obviously, Mr Schneider did not factor in the eagerness of his own member organisations to raise their premiums and soak up any advantages the rebate scheme may have given to policy holders. But rather than admit their mistake and scrap their private health initiative, the government continues to waste taxpayers money on a scheme which continues to erode. Regrettably this is at the expense of Australia's public health system at a time when it can least sustain such an attack. Yet it will continue because this government despises public health institutions. It wants to continue to wind down universal health care in this country and eventually to force all but the poorest Australians into the private system.

Another prime example of the coalition government's philosophical ambivalence to public health, is evidenced in the grotesque changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Not content with making pensioners and low-income earners fork out an additional 50c per prescription by raising the fee from $2.70 to $3.20, this government introduced in the last budget the therapeutic group premiums. From 1 February this year, 38 medicines previously listed on the pharmaceutical benefit scheme are no longer eligible for subsidy. People who have been unable to afford the extra amount for drugs that many have been taking for a number of years are now being forced to seek a cheaper alternative with the potential for serious side effects.

The Howard government's own literature has admitted that these changes are due to price-conscious reasons and as such it is not unreasonable to expect that this enthusiasm for controlling costs will ultimately be at the expense of people's lives. Let there be no doubt that as well as a cost saving measure, the therapeutic group premiums is also about starving the Medicare system of funds. It is about developing a two-tier system between the haves and the have-nots: that is, those who can afford high quality pharmaceuticals and those who will have to make do with cheaper substitutes.

This change has directly affected nearly one million Australians and their families. These people will know that Labor strenuously opposed these changes. The community now knows that only Labor can guarantee a secure, universal health system. The Prime Minister misled voters prior to the last election by promising that Medicare would remain unchanged. It is quite clear that this was obviously a non-core promise and that the Prime Minister's real agenda was closer to those quotes on health that we all know him for: `Medicare has been an unmitigated disaster' and `We'â€”the coalitionâ€”`will end bulk-billing'. It would be hard not to argue that this is still a real philosophy of the federal coalition.

Take the issue of bulk-billing, which I mentioned earlier. In January 1997, 81 per cent of GP services were bulk-billed. One year later, in January 1998, this figure had fallen to 79.6 per cent. In regional areas of Queenslandâ€”Rockhampton, for exampleâ€”it is now almost impossible to find a general practitioner who is prepared to bulk-bill.

The AMA's recommended fee for a GP consultation is now $37. However, the Medicare rebate is only $21. So people in regional Queensland who have little choice but to go to a non-bulk-billing doctor are out of pocket up to $16 per visit. Some of this is due in part to a lack of competition between GPs in regional areas. However, this should be even more of a reason for the federal government to provide incentives for these doctors to bulk-bill.

When all these factors are added to the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program and the reductions of funding experienced by both the public health program and medical research bodies, the lack of commitment of the Howard government to health care is exposed. But the failure of the Prime Minister and his government to negotiate a reasonable new agreement with the states is not just confined to Medicare agreements.

The coalition government has also placed in jeopardy the health of thousands of Australians with disabilities, by failing to negotiate a new Commonwealth-state disability agreement. After three absurdly low offers from the Commonwealth to the states, it is the Howard government which has backed off from a multilateral agreement and is now pursuing bilateral agreements with individual states. If this were to occur, it would be hard to see how the lack of uniformity between the states is going to assist people with disabilities.

One of the worst features of a bilateral agreement is that it throws the whole multilateral framework out the window and, in the process, puts in jeopardy a decade of uniformity practised by various levels of government in this area. For example, under this potential system, it would be quite possible for a person with a disability who receives funding support in one state, not to receive the same level of support if he or she were to decide to relocate to another state which has a different agreement with the Commonwealth. This is similar to the approach the Commonwealth will now start adopting with the states in relation to Medicare agreements.

The sad aspect of this process is the loss of uniformity across Australia. We start to get back to the situation where there are haves and have-nots. This is the old Liberal tactic of rule by division. Unfortunately, when it comes to health care and disability agreements, it just becomes playing politics with people's lives. It has now become apparent to the Australian community that there is a very stark contrast between the Howard government and the Labor Party on health related issues.

On the one hand we have a mean-spirited government which is squeezing states to force more people onto waiting lists and is cutting back medical services, a government which, because of its ideological hatred of public institutions, is content to run down the universality of a health system considered one of the most progressive in the international community.

talk.start.para: â€”That is rubbish.

â€”You know very well, Minister, it is true. On the other side we have a Labor Party which has instigated every successful health initiative in Australia over the last three decades, a party which is committed to the Medicare system and what it stands forâ€”universal access to public hospitals based on medical need rather than income, free or low cost visits to GPs, and access to pharmaceuticals through the PBS. The choice could not be clearer.

â€”There is no doubt that funding for health is a problem, has been a problem and will always be a problem. The major problem seems to be to strike a balance between the public and private funding of health insurance. I know in my own state I and my colleagues have been criticised today in the media by my cousin, the minister for health down there. I know Peter as well as I know anybody. We know how it works in the states; when you cannot justify something you are doing, then you bash the feds. I think this is just another case of that.

speech.para: Peter McKay has accused me and my colleagues of using manipulated and selective figures. We took the unprecedented decision as a group of senators and members from Tasmania to put the facts on the table because we believed that there were too many figures flying around and the public were getting the wrong impression. The fact of the matter is, as far as federal funding for health goes in Tasmania, there was an offer of a $22 million increase for Tasmania, 2.7 per cent, when we have virtually zero inflation and a population that is at the best stagnant but it may even be reducing.

The state government down there has to come clean and tell the people the absolute truth. When the last agreement was made and the Commonwealth was offering an increase in health funding, the states cut their contribution to health by $32 million in year one and another $11 million in year two. So the states reduced health funding by $43 million while the federal government was increasing its contribution.

I will put that in better figures. In Tasmania between 1990 and 1996â€”the Labor Party was in power for most of that timeâ€”health funding from the Commonwealth increased by 27 per cent and hospital funding from the Commonwealth increased by 23 per cent. At the same time the state governments of Tasmania, whomever they were, reduced health funding by 23 per cent and reduced hospital funding by 32 per cent. If you put that in dollar terms, in 1992-93 the Tasmanian government cut its contribution to hospital services by $136 million and in 1993-94 by $103 million. This has been going on right across the country, except in the ACT.

When you look at the comparisons of spending between the states and the Commonwealth, they are quite staggering. For instance, the Victorian state government in 1993-94 reduced its spending on health by $205 million when compared with the previous year, 1992-93. In the following year, 1993-94, in comparison with that 1991-92 figure it reduced its spending by $396 millionâ€”that is, a 22.7 per cent decrease.

talk.start.para: â€”That's your mate Jeff Kennett.

â€”Okay, but don't blame the Commonwealth. Fair is fair; health is a shared burden. It is something that we are all responsible for and something that we have to share, but do not come in here today putting down notices of motion condemning the Prime Minister for his lack of leadership and lack of health policies when here we are increasing contributions and at the same time most of the states, except for the ACT, have been reducing away merrily. The Northern Territory in 1992-93 and 1993-94 reduced its spending by 43 per cent. At the same time the ACT has increased its contributions by 13.5 per cent. South Australia was minus 3.3 per cent and Queensland was minus 14.9 per cent. It is there for everybody to see.

speech.para: Senator Gibbs was on about private health insurance. The average increase in private health insurance is, I think, about 8.1 per cent. I know that is higher than the CPI, but I think we have to understand that there have been a lot of changes in health and that a lot more older people are being treated than before.

talk.start.para: â€”I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Choice of Superannuation Funds together with submissions received by the committee and a transcript of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

I table the 28th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Choice of Fund . The government's initiative to introduce choice of fund is considered by many people to be the most significant change to Australia's superannuation system since the introduction of the compulsory superannuation guarantee system. The government first announced its choice of fund policy prior to its election in 1996. Indeed, the coalition has long supported greater freedom of choice for superannuation contributors.

Subject to the passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997, of which this is part, from 1 July 1998 employers will be required to offer new employees a choice about where their compulsory superannuation guarantee payments are paid. From 1 July 2000, continuing employees who were employed prior to 1 July 1998 must also be offered a choice of fund.

The committee encountered considerable support for the broad concept of the choice of fund. Witnesses told the committee that a major advantage of the choice proposal was that it would increase awareness of investment alternatives and understanding of the need to plan retirement savings. It was also considered that implementing choice would require individuals to have greater knowledge of retirement savings options and increase their motivation to understand its importance. With choice and control, individuals are more likely to feel a sense of ownership and take an active interest in savings for their retirement.

However, it is fair to say that many groups considered the government's timetable for introducing choice of fund to be very tight. Many witnesses questioned whether there is sufficient time remaining to put all the necessary arrangements in place. It was clear that there was deep division between the specialist providers of financial products who are anxious that choice proceed in accordance with the government's announced timetable and others who advocate a delay or propose that choice be optional for a limited period and that choice be limited to investment within a fund.

The committee found that there is general acceptance for the view that for the choice of fund proposal to succeed employees must be in a position to exercise informed choice. I should note that the government is also on record as having stated that it is important that people make an informed choice.

Informed choice requires that employees understand the consequences of the decisions they make and choose funds that best suit their personal circumstances and their requirements.Informed choice requires two essential conditions to be satisfied. They are adequate education about the choice of fund and disclosure by funds of all relevant information such as returns, risks, fees, charges that should influence the employee's decision.

In order to make good decisions employees may need education about choice of fund, its benefits and its dangers. Most witnesses called for education programs to ensure consumers make an informed choice. Many cast doubt on whether such an education campaign is achievable in the relatively short time before the legislation is scheduled to come into force. However, the government has assured the committee that the necessary education measures are being developed and will be in place.

Employees will also need access to useful, comprehensive information about the fund alternatives so that they may make valid comparisons. The information about fund alternatives that funds and employers will provide to employees who are offered choice will be in the form of key feature statements. The form of the key feature statements has yet to be finalised. The government will shortly be releasing regulations that will determine their final form.

Key feature statements should incorporate clear warnings about the consequences of choosing a fund, such as the adequacy and coverage of the insurance and the possibility that insurance cover, where formally provided, may lapse. The statements should also incorporate a clear explanation about the relative risks associated with each option.

It is also likely that, despite the best efforts of education campaigns by the government and others, a large number of people will not exercise their right to make a choice of fund. During the inquiry the committee received evidence that many people will not be able to understand the concepts or the information put before them. It is also true that the understanding of superannuation in the general community still remains low.

People who do not feel able to make a choice or are unwilling to do so will have their contributions directed into a default fund. This default fund must provide adequate protection for those people who cannot or are unwilling to exercise choice. Several witnesses made recommendations to the committee about the desirable features of default funds. While the committee makes no recommendation in this regard, the default fund is a matter that responsible employers should consider carefully.

In closing, I think that the choice of fund proposal offers a number of opportunities and benefits. Employees will have the opportunity to exercise their democratic right to determine where their employer contributions go. They will be able to shift their future contribution away from under performing funds. However, it is important to emphasise that choice of fund does not mean that people feel obliged to change their funds. It is important the information provided to employees, who are offered choice, does not create an atmosphere that encourages change just for change sake. Many people would be better off by staying with their current fund. We must, at all costs, avoid the mistakes made in the United Kingdom and Chile where choice of fund has led to many poor choices being made.

I would like to take this opportunity of thanking the staff of the committee, particularly the secretary, Mr Peter Hallahan, who has had to work extraordinary hours to meet the very tight deadline in getting this report to hand. I think it is a commendable report. Under the circumstances, it comprehensively covers the issues involved. I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: â€”I join with Senator Watson in congratulating the staff of the committee, particularly Peter Hallahan, who had a great deal thrust on him when he was not quite ready for it. He has done a great job to get it all ready and tabled by today. I also acknowledge Senator Watson's comments about how comprehensive the report is in dealing with the evidence put before us.

speech.para: The Labor senators on the committee have put in a minority report. We support the principle of choice but we do not believe that the government's preferred model of choice is appropriate or that it meets a number of principles, in that it does not ensure that employees make the choice. This is really about employer choice. The government's model takes the power to choose where their superannuation funds go from the hands of employees and gives it to employers.

There was a lot of debate, during the hearings about the purported economic benefits of superannuation choice. There was broad agreement among committee members and in the evidence that everybody favours investment choice. I do not think there was a great deal of argument: a lot of funds are already moving in that direction and we have seen evidence of the benefits of investment choice. The Labor senators are recommending that we introduce investment choice reasonably quickly, as a first step and as part of an education process, so that the people who own the money in the funds understand why they should pay more attention to their reports. Certainly, in my time as a superannua tion officer, the greatest trouble I encountered was getting members to actually read the information that the funds supplied. That will be critical to a successful implementation of choice.

It would be fairâ€”and kindâ€”to say that there was a naive view about the benefits of the competitive process which would be unleashed by this legislation. When they appeared before the committee, I asked Commonwealth Bank officials if they could guarantee the price of their retirement savings vehicleâ€”the RSAâ€”would be the lower than it was today. Surely, I asked an official, if we have all these winds of competition, the cost to the consumer of an RSA would be reduced. He was not able to give me that assurance. In fact, he was quite embarrassed about the fact that he could not give me that assurance.

So I say to those who came before the committee and advocated choiceâ€”on the basis that the benefits will accrue to the customerâ€”that the challenge is there to prove that it can happen. Many witnesses came before us and demonstrated why fees would go up and why returns would go down in the new world of competition. We heard evidence that funds would have to significantly increaseâ€”possibly double or even tripleâ€”their existing marketing budgets to compete in a choice environment. Funds told us their administration fee would almost certainly double to cope with these increases. Legal costs would be substantially higher under this new regime. To many people who currently get a very low-price product, the cost structures were going to be substantially increased.

The situation at the moment with returns is that superannuation is an allowable matter before the IRC. Therefore, the minimum award requirements, in generalâ€”in most industry funds, certainlyâ€”are that payments be made monthly by the employers. This government is seeking to take that out as an allowable matter. It wants to fall back on the minimum current requirements of the SGC legislation, which is one payment a year.

The difference between getting paid monthly and getting paid yearly was calculated, on behalf of the committee, by the Institute of Actuaries. Their supplementary submission showed that, as a result, the return over a lifetime would be three to four per cent less. That one simple change, of taking away the minimum requirement of a monthly payment, had a compounding effect: not getting your money into your account monthly meant not getting the interest on interest earned. Just the one payment a year would see a three to four per cent less return, on retirementâ€”just from one stroke of a pen. The results will be: costs up, returns downâ€”that is the brave new world of competition of choice.

The most significant arguments the committee faced were over education; and whether or not the consumersâ€”the workers, whose money it wasâ€”would be able to understand the information they would be supplied with. Under this legislation, when you go for a job nowâ€”after 1 July if you are a new employeeâ€”you will be faced with four key feature statements of up to six pages per set. Although I have spent four or five years in the industry, I know that I would never be able to wade through four sets of six pagesâ€”trying to understand and compare apples with apples. Other people who testified before the committee said that they too, after 17 years in the industry, were not able to make meaningful comparisons between the key feature statements from the super funds.

The government acknowledged the evidence before the committee that education would be a problem. We asked the government what test it was going to do before introducing choice, to measure the success of an education campaign. We said:

You are going to spend dollars and centsâ€”taxpayers' moneyâ€”to educate people about choice of fund. Acknowledging there is a problemâ€”are you going to test the market to see if you have been successful?

To this day, the government still will not give a commitment to actually test whether or not people have understand and benefited from the education campaign. What is the point in saying, `We need to educate'; if you do not then test to see if you have been successful?

There is one point of concern beyond that. Twice now, I have sought information from the Taxation Office about the amount of money that the previous Labor government spentâ€”in 1992 and 1994â€”on its national advertising campaigns to publicise the benefits of superannuation. These are just statistics which should be readily available inside the Taxation Office.

A month later, I still have not received that information. I am told it has been given to Senator Kemp's office for Senator Kemp to decide whether to release, which I am very surprised about. You have to ask yourself why they will not show how much the previous Labor government spent on what, at that stage, was the biggest single change in superannuation policy in the country's history. This is as big, if not bigger. Why don't they want to tell us how much was spent on that last education campaign?

You can only conclude one thing: because the amount of money they are going to spend on this campaign is substantially less. They are not serious about an education campaign. If they were serious about an education campaign, you would be able to look at what happened in previous years and judge it against what they are proposing now. They will not give any indication of what they are proposing now. They will not give any indication of what was done before. That is very disappointing. I hope that information, perhaps with the help of some other senators in the chamber at the moment, is able to be more forthcoming than it currently is, because that is of real concern. Finally, in the last couple of minutes remaining to me, I want to respond to a commentâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”A pretty quick couple of minutes!

â€”A very fast couple of minutes! Senator Watson referred to the default fund. This is critical. Labor senators believe there should be minimum default standards, minimum insurance cover and minimum investment choice. That means that if you are 17 or 18 years old and you do not understand the process or just decide it is all too hard and you get lumped into an RSA at 17, you are not going to be substantially worse off. (Time expired)

â€”I rise to speak on this report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannua tion and to support the comments made by Senator Watson. In particular, I note that this relates to one of the most important pieces of legislation that will come before the Senate. It is a very important report. Choice of funds has been at the forefront of the coalition's policy for a number of years.

speech.para: I listened carefully to Senator Conroy. His comments reflect the very narrow view which he has of industry, as seen through the industry fund. I do not know whether his comments related to the industry fund he belonged to and represented, but they represented a very narrow view of superannuation throughout Australia. There are many other people besides those in industry funds who are requesting and requiring choice of fund, and have been doing so for a long time.

I say to Senator Conroy that I know from my experience in the industry, which probably goes back a little further than his, although I know that his was extensive, that I came across a number of people in my time in the superannuation industry who were self-employed, particularly those in rural areas who, in order to supplement their income because times were so tough, would do some casual work for a couple of months of the year. They found that, although they had their own superannuation fund, contributions made on their behalf during the time of this casual employment had to be put in another fund, and in those days, by the end of the year, it had completely disappeared because of the cost of fees and charges. So there are many other people around Australia who are waiting for choice of funds to become available to them so that they can maximise the amounts they are putting away for their retirement income. It may be that they have casual employment with three or four different employers and this choice of fund may enable them to make sure that all the contributions towards their retirement go into one fund.

I was amazed to hear Senator Conroy talk about education because, to the best of my memory, award superannuation came in in 1989. I think it had to be in place by 1989; I know it started earlier than that but I think it was about September 1989 before it became compulsory and then in 1992 or 1993 the SGC started.

talk.start.para: â€”Are you committed to a national TV program?

â€”If education was so important and if people are so ill informed in 1998, where on earth was the education that should have been put in place by the previous Labor government? Where was the education over a period of almost 10 years from the time when award super first came into being? The education process that was put in place by the previous government was practically non-existent.

speech.para: One of the reasons why education did not matter was that many of those who were running industry funds did not believe that education was necessary because a person did not have an opportunity to make an informed choice. There was no need to be educated because the employee had no say at all, anyway, so why educate them?

talk.start.para: â€”And keep it a secret. There is choice but it is a secret.

â€”We have to try to correct the wrongs of the previous government, which failed to educate employers and employees in regard to superannuation. We are now going to offer them choice. You will find that once people have some ownership of and control over their own destiny, they will be much keener to become educated.

speech.para: Senator Bishop interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I listened carefully to Senator Conroy's contribution without interjecting, although I disagreed with much of what he said, so I would appreciate the same courtesy. As far as the principle of choice is concerned, we believe it is up to the individual to be entitled to exercise that choice if he so desires.

speech.para: There need to be some safeguards, and that is why this government chose not to introduce unlimited choice, because there was pressure from some areas to have unlimited choice. That would have been very difficult to manage and that is why there is choice in the policy put forward by the coalitionâ€”enough choice so that people will be able to choose for themselves what is best for their future.

Senator Conroy also made a statement which I found quite fascinating. He said that in the new world of competition, fees will go up and returns will go down. That shows how much experience Senator Conroy has had with the real world. He calls it the new world. I would say: look at the real world. I spent some time working in this industry at a time when fees and charges were exorbitantly high. It was partly because of competition and the work of industry funds that forced those charges and fees to come down. I think it was the best thing to happen to superannuation for a long time.

The world of superannuation is a very competitive business and people are getting good returns. People have fee structures which are more in tune with what should be happening with superannuation. In the long run competition will ensure that fees do not go up; fees will remain low. That will have some long-term effect on returns, so that returns will improve.

When talking about unlimited choice, we must remember that there will be unlimited choice provided the employer offers it. It is one of the options that employers can offer. A small employer with two or three employees may choose to give those employees unlimited choice, which will be in their best interests if they are casual employees and have other funds they can channel all their retirement savings into. If the employer is prepared to offer unlimited choice, that is the best way for them to go.

This report is very important because it has enabled us to gather information from all those people who have concerns. I am concerned about the opposition's tactics in trying to stall the legislation with respect to choice. We all know that the start-up date in the legislation is 1 July. Those involved in the superannuation industry need some certainty. The opposition's stalling of this piece of legislation is increasing the uncertainty in the community of both employers and employees.

The tactic of delaying the legislation for as long as possible in order to make it more difficult for those people involved in the industry is one that the opposition should be ashamed of. Let the debate take place in the chamber. Let the chamber decide whether or not this legislation will passâ€”I do not know whether or not it will be passedâ€”because then at least there will be some certainty for those involved in the industry, both employers and employees, so they will know on 1 July what their obligations and options will be.

It is incumbent on the opposition to push this legislation forward as soon as possible. Let the chamber make a decision. If the opposition waits until the budget session in May and this legislation is passed by the chamber without amendment, it is basically saying to all those people in the community involved in the preparation of providing superannuation as employers, or choosing options as employees, `We are going to limit the time completely so that you have less than two months to put all the arrangements in place and to make sure that any education process that needs to be put in place can be put in place.'

I urge the opposition to take a good look at itself in terms of the legislation which will be coming before the chamber and deal with it as soon as possible so that it knows what the outcome of the vote in this chamber will be. The opposition will be judged by the community on any stalling tactics that it uses. It is something the opposition will have to wear if it decides to delay the bill unnecessarily.

The report is quite a lengthy one. I think it is fair to say that the views of both sides expressed to the committee have been reported in great detail. Lots of people felt that the start-up date would be difficult and that a good education process needed to take place. This has been well presented and I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your indulgence in taking the chair so that I can speak in this debate. I did have the opportunity, in the absence of Senator Nick Sherry, to be a member of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and to partake in its hearings. I can assure Senator Ferguson and the government that by no means are these stalling tactics, in spite of how one may interpret them from the other side. A welter of evidence was given to the committee that, regardless of the outcome, there should be a delay in the implementation of the issue of choice of fund. Senator Conroy has already outlined our position in terms of choice of fund. What we do not agree with is the model.

speech.para: A number of important issues came before the committee in the taking of evidence. The most alarming, as far as I was concerned, was in the area of education. As Senator Watson who chaired the committee would know, I repeatedly asked of those appearing before the committee the problem in relation to literacy and numeracy. We were given evidence, which to my knowledge has not been refuted, that in the vicinity of 48 per cent of Australians, according to an ABS surveyâ€”so it was a reliable survey, one would hopeâ€”are at the bottom level in literacy and numeracy skills. They rest in level 1 and level 2 on a scale of one to five and it could be best said that they have difficulty in reading and doing basic computations which many of us take for granted.

talk.start.para: â€”So we cannot introduce it until we have educated all of them?

â€”I am not saying that at all, Senator. What I am saying is that we have a difficulty if, as we heard in evidenceâ€”virtually universallyâ€”people must be in a position to make an informed choice. It was interesting to hear Senator Watson this evening use the words `informed choice' because I think that, across parties, everyone will agree that if a proper choice is to be made by those accessing superannuation, the proper choice must be on an informed basis.

speech.para: It is on that basis that I am concerned primarily about the issue of education and the fact that 48 per cent have lower literacy and numeracy skills. What is even more concerning, however, is that in the vicinity of 2 million to 2Â½ million people are at level 1 or were at level 1 in that survey. To me, this means that the process of education, the process of making these people able to interpretâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! the time for debate on this issue has expired. We will now proceed to committee reports and government responses.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Bishop:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to speak to the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on housing assistance. I have previously addressed some issues relating to this report. It is a very comprehensive report and, once again, I draw the attention of senators and the public to it. I also draw the attention of the government to the report as they consider their no doubt prompt response.

speech.para: There is one issue that I would like to further pursue in relation to the report. It is a matter that impacts fairly significantly on people who rent their homesâ€”private tenants. Private tenants make up a quite large proportion of the population. Around one in four people live in houses that they rent through the private housing market. An issue that seems to be growingâ€”if the information provided by a number of community housing groups is to be believedâ€”is the operation around the country of a number of tenancy databases.

This issue was raised with me by a number of housing groups in northern Queensland when I was up there recently. One organisation, the Tenants Union of Queensland, has conducted a fair bit of research into this issue. I would like to inform the Senate that I have had a long association with the Tenants Union because of my involvement in the management committee and other aspects of it. I know from personal experience that it is a very professional and credible organisation and that it knows what it is talking about with issues affecting tenants and the housing sector in general.

The union has had a lot of complaints from tenants in relation to the operation of tenancy databases and the existence of what basically can accurately be called `tenant black lists'. One organisation, whose name comes up a lot, is called `The Tenancy Information Centre Australia' or TICA for short. It appears to operate around the country, and certainly a lot of agents throughout Queensland use this database. The particular examples reported to me by housing groups were in relation to databases in Cairns and Townsville.

Under these totally privately run systems, real estate agents are able to access the database which has been compiled. The database contains the details of a large number of private tenants. Tenants are often put on this database, without their knowledge, by real estate agents, property agents or managers who have had problems them. Obviously, these problems sometimes are quite genuine, so there is some case to be made that people who are involved in the business of managing properties should legitimately be made aware of people who have a bad record for damaging properties or those sorts of things.

A number of cases have come to light where incorrect information on people has been put on these black lists; information that is incorrect, highly pejorative or out of context. The information simply said that someone had not paid their rent, or something like that, without giving any indication that it was because of failure on the part of the property owner to fulfil their obligation to repair property and to make it livable, et cetera. In a situation where a tenant is simply acting to try to enforce their own legal rightsâ€”such as they exist under tenancy legislation in Queenslandâ€”they can, unbeknown to them, find themselves on one of these databases which are available to real estate agents throughout the country. Next time they try to rent a house, a unit, a flat or whatever, they find their application for tenancy being refused because the agent was able to access a database containing incorrect information on the prospective tenants. People can be refused property without knowing the reason. That is obviously a completely unacceptable situation.

Reports have come from the Tenants Union office in Cairns. Cairns is an area that has a higher than usual proportion of private tenants and a very mobile population. This issue comes up even more strongly in these sorts of communities. The Cairns office reported a lot of examples of people being denied accommodation due to their inclusion on tenant black lists.

It is really the unregulated nature of the system that leaves it open to potential abuse. It is not so much its existence in itself but the fact that there are no controls on it. This was addressed to some extent in this report from the community affairs committee, and it highlights the need not only for adequate tenancy legislation to protect the rights of tenants and of property owners around the country but also for adequate enforcement and adequate regulation of it. It is something that I hope the government considers when it looks at that aspect of the report.

It also touches on the broader issue of privacy principles in the private sector and around the country. As has been mentioned previously, it was a commitment of the coalition prior to coming into government that they would extend privacy legislation to the private sector. They have backed away from that commitment, an alternative the Democrats are most disappointed with. One of the alternative approaches which is now being pursued is through the Privacy Commissioner under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Senators probably recall receiving some national principles for their handling of personal information which the Office of the Privacy Commissioner released around the end of February, about three or four weeks ago, which is aimed at setting a privacy benchmark for the handling of personal information. I urge senators to have a look at that document as well because it does correlate with this issue that was touched on in the Senate report into housing issues.

I will quickly touch on a few of the principles that are contained in this suggested benchmark. They are very fundamental principles that are suggested for adoption. If information is collected about a person that is provided by someone else, an agency should, wherever possible, make sure that the person knows that this has occurred. Agencies should ensure that information they hold about a person is accurate when they collect it or when they use it. Wherever possible, they should let people see the information held about them and correct it if it is wrong.

That is a crucial factor. It is one thing to have this information but, if people are not even aware that their information is being put onto these databases and is being used by property managers and real estate agents and they are not able to get it corrected when they find it exists and believe it has inaccurate details on it, it is obviously a very fundamental breach of a person's basic privacy rights as well as an unfair hindrance to their being able to access accommodation.

The Tenants Union reported on people who have unsuccessfully tried to clear their name with this private company and who were getting fairly short shrift when they tried to do so. That is something the Democrats believe is totally unacceptable. Just exercising your normal rights as a tenant should not result in your potentially being put on some sort of black list that can continue for an undetermined length of time.

Examples were quoted of tenants being given a bad tenant status for agreeing to forfeit part or all of their bond to fix or clean vacated premises, which is a not unusual practice. Reportedly, by their own account, database agencies such as TICA make little or no attempt to check the accuracy of information they place on the database. They just take the word of the agent or the property manager who has provided it to them. Again, that is something the Democrats believe is unacceptable. I do hope that the government, both at the federal level and at the state level, works to address this issue.

The Queensland state government currently is examining privacy legislation through one of its state parliamentary committees. It is something I know was raised before that committee, and I hope that action is taken there. I would also urge the Real Estate Institute of Australia and Real Estate Institute of Queensland, which are certainly aware of this concern, to act to address it. As the Privacy Commissioner said in releasing the suggested national privacy principles for the handling of personal information, these principles are issued as recommended princi plesâ€”a recommended national approachâ€”for fair information handling, and the aim is to devise a benchmark which is workable and flexible in the business context without compromising basic principles and core privacy standards.

Whilst these are out for comment and consideration, the Privacy Commissioner does urge people to move quickly on them. They are on the table, and the commissioner strongly encourages Australian businesses to take up the challenge and adopt them. I hope that the real estate industry takes on board those principles and the consideration in relation to this tenancy black list and does do something about trying to implement them. I hope the government, in consideration of this report, takes on board that issue as well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! As consideration of committee reports and government responses has now concluded, I propose the question:
