talk.start.para: â€”There has never been any doubt that the government's waterfront strategy is nothing more than a political campaign. It was built on detailed and expensive public opinion polling and a carefully constructed political public relations campaign. It is a campaign being implemented through a newsletter put out by Mr Reith's ministerial office that deals in trivia and hearsay. It is a campaign built on personal attacks on individuals in the union movement.

speech.para: It is a campaign built on misinformation. It is a campaign designed to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia and to erode the authority of the ACTU. It is a campaign about sacking people. It is not a campaign built around good public policy. It indeed is not a campaign built on fact, and it is not a campaign built on ongoing reform on the waterfront, because that can only be achieved if all parties are working together in pursuit of a common goal, as was the case in the WIRA reform program.

In the past couple of days we have seen what I described as the Reith plan begin to unravel because there is not solid policy foundation and it does not enjoy the support of stevedores or the workers. The level of support from users is now dissipating, if it ever was there at all. I just remind the Senate of that plan which was spelt out in a minute from the most senior waterfront reform officer in Mr Reith's department. That minute advised:

What would be needed for the MUA's influence on the waterfront to be significantly weakened would be for a range of effected service users and providers to take decisive action to protect or advance their interests.
It continued:

Stevedores would need to activate well prepared strategies to dismiss their workforce, and replace them with another, quickly, in a way that limited the prospect of, for example, the Commission ordering the reinstatement of the current workforce.

Let me go to part 1 of the planâ€”that is, to get the users to attack the Maritime Union of Australia. On ABC radio yesterday the Executive President of the Australian Peak Shippers Association, Mr Frank Beaufort, laid the blame for the current problems on the docks at the feet of Patricks management, not the Maritime Union. It is important to note that this body represents about 80 per cent of shippers in this countryâ€”shippers in areas such as dairy, horticulture, cotton, timber, meat, wool and rice. Mr Beaufort said that there will continue to be problems on the docks as long as Patricks remains in the stevedoring business. He said that the turmoil in the docks was being driven by Patricks. And of course Patricks is being driven by Mr Reith.

I noted that today in order to illustrate widespread support for the Reith plan the minister read out a handful of letters from anonymous authors. He did not, however, get up and read from a handful of letters from major users of the ports attacking the MUA and supporting the government, because he could not. That support is not there. While a number of employer organisations came out in support of the government, in reality they would have been given little choice. So it would appear that phase one of Mr Reith's plan is now under some pressure.

One possible reason for this that I have touched on in an earlier debate but it bears repeating is that many users are putting the costs of a full-scale industrial war against the benefits that might flow from the campaign to smash the MUA. While there may be some isolated examples where stevedores charge users $200 to move a container for large contract users in Melbourne, for example, the actual cost is about $70. Whilst isolated examples of charging $200 a container no doubt exist, that is not the norm.

The main exporters putting product across the wharves are facing much lower chargesâ€”charges which, on information that I have, are as low as $70 per container. That is 30 per cent below the cost Mr Reith said could be achieved if the union was forced from the docks. So there is no saving in his campaign. The savings are already there by his figures. That $70 represents two per cent of the total transport costs or only 0.2 of one per cent of the value of a typical container in the case of one of the big users of the Melbourne waterfront, according to information that has been given to me.

What of the second part of Mr Reith's plan of getting a stevedore to sack its entire work force and replace that work force before the Industrial Relations Commission could reinstate the sacked workersâ€”that is, beat the system, in fact, to act outside the terms of Mr Reith's own legislation? It appears to me that Patricks were prepared to act as Mr Reith's lieutenant in this exercise of union bashing, not for any reason of reform or efficiency but because the company was in trouble. In that case it felt, no doubt, that it had to choose.

In a story in today's Australian the Sea Land stevedoring company was quoted as saying that Patricks attempt to blame the union for its low productivity on the waterfront was a smokescreen for its own poor management. The General Manager of Sea Land, Mr Andrew Andrews, said that the company had included the union in its plans right from the start and would continue to use union labour when it commenced its operations in Brisbane in July. He was quoted as saying that the company had not found the MUA to be a barrier to reform. He went on to say:
We're very bullish on the attitude of the union in that they're very receptive to change. I just don't understand the people who are finding itâ€”
that is, the unionâ€”
a road block to changing things.
I quote also from the Chief Executive of P&O, which is the other major stevedoring company on Australia's waterfront. The Chief Executive, Richard Hein, is reported by AAP as saying:
We are not about tearing up our agreements and setting out to destroy the MUA.

Clearly, it is not the employers who are out to smash the unions but it is this governmentâ€”Mr Reith in particular and, no doubt, Mr Howard. Patricks chose to carry out the Reith plan and it appears that it is now paying an increasingly high price.

In my view, the faltering performance of Patricks has led to Mr Reith inviting the National Farmers Federation to take up the mantle. It appears that the NFF is struggling as well. On this morning's AM Mr McGauchie said that he had still not signed up any business and he was forced to organise a teleconference last night to shore up his support in the bush.
The attitude of the National Farmers Federation to the interests of its own membership was best illustrated by the following question and answer. Mr McGauchie was asked:
If you are not using fighting funds in this exercise why not open up the fighting fund books for the past three years?
He replied:
. . . one of itsâ€”
that is, the fighting fundsâ€”
great strengths is its mystery.
I take that to mean that the use of that money must remain a mystery not only to the public but also to farmers who actually donated the money.

I also want to refer to the March issue of the P&O newsletter. There is an article in that publication on crane rates for a vessel called the Kasuga. That is a vessel which, I understand, was the subject of stevedoring activity in Singapore and in two Australian ports all under the control of P&O, so they know what the crane rates were. That article said that in Singapore there were 1,298 moves at a crane rate of 28.8 TEUs per hour using four cranes. In Adelaide, the same vessel saw one crane achieve 338 movements at a rate of 28.6 TEUs per hour. In Fremantle, one crane achieved 608 moves at a rate of 26.8 TEUs per hour. In other words, there was no great difference.

In my view, this illustrates partly the fact that this has been a political exercise from day one as far as the Howard government is concerned. The stevedores and increasingly the users of the ports are indicating that the political games are not substitutes for good public policy and sustainable economic reform. I would say that this exercise by the minister will fail. Unfortunately, a lot of people are going to suffer while it is being played out.

talk.start.para: â€”On Sunday, 15 March the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced the further sale of Telstra shares to reduce Labor's debt legacy and to give all Australians, especially Telstra employees, a further opportunity to invest in this great Australian company. Labor's reaction from its policy vacuum was to be negative without offering an alternative. Labor's negativity would be understandable but for its duplicity and unconscionable scaremongering. Labor's duplicity is best highlighted by this exchange:

speech.para: So it doesn't matter whether Telecom is publicly or private owned?
Answer:
Not of its essence, no.

Who gave that answer? None other than Labor's last Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Labor will tell you that Mr Keating has been left behind. They have entered a new era. I suppose we need to accept that. But then Labor need to leave the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, behind as well, because he is on record supporting the sale of public assets. His quotes relating to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and CSL are legend. In relation to Telstra, Mr Beazley said, `You could sell Telecom if you set your mind to it.' A bit embarrassing for Labor, I would suggest.

Labor does have a policy on the sale of assets. Its policy is that, in opposition and in the lead-up to an election campaign, you reject the sale of public assets. Once in government, you sell in complete breach of the undertakings given. No wonder the lady in red, Labor's new recruit, said about Labor:
I think Labor in opposition won't sell Telstra, but I'm more worried about Labor in government.

The difference is that the Liberals are honest and up-front. Labor isâ€”how will I put it?â€”economical with the truth. The truth is that Telstra will be sold no matter who wins the next election. The difference is that the Liberals are honest. The other difference is that we will use the proceeds to pay off Labor's legacy of debt. Labor will squander the proceeds of the sale as they did with the Commonwealth Bank, with Qantas and with CSL. In paying off Labor's debt, we free up the money supply and, as a result, we can live in a low interest rate environment which benefits all of us.

Labor's unconscionable scaremongering has already started. In weighing up the credibility of Labor's campaign, I invite my fellow Australians to cast their minds back to the 1996 election campaign. In my home state of Tasmania the people in the electorate of Lyons were submitted to a very deceitful campaign. Labor circulated a mock Telstra account using Telstra's logo and ACN without permission. On the account, Labor asserted that, after the one-third sale of Telstra, metered calls, STD calls, mobile network and 0011 international fees would all increase after the sale. Well, the sale has occurred. Have the prices increased as Labor so dishonestly asserted? The answer is no. Has Labor apologised? The answer is no. But is Labor asserting all these untruths again? Unfortunately, the answer is yes. There is no sense of remorse, just blind adherence to the Labor motto `Do whatever it takes.'

The most outrageous assertion on that Telstra account peddled by the Labor Party was the claim that a network charge would come into being. Actual figures were nominated for key areas in the electorate by the Labor candidate. For example, one of the best places in Tasmania, an area I often visit and enjoy visiting, is the west coast. West coast residents were told the horrendous untruth that this fictitious network charge would cost them $1,250 each. In Ouse they were told it would be $950. In Deloraine and Oatlands they were told it would be $680. In St Marys they were told it would be $910â€”all untrue, proven to be untrue.

Indeed, connection fees have not increased in the past two years. Despite being exposed as charlatans, Labor, without any sense of shame or remorse, are yet again embarking on a dishonest scare campaign. The Labor member for Lyons (Mr Adams) must be aware of the disdain his electorate now holds him in for this dishonest campaign in 1996. The recent poll in Tasmania reflected his very shaky position.

Can I turn now to debunk some of the assertions that have been made of late. In offering services to all Australia, we need to keep this in mind: the law says that all Australians must have access to a standard telephone service and access to pay phones within a legally specified time regardless of where in Australia they live or work. This law will continue to apply and be enforced regardless of who owns Telstra.

Consumer protection laws will remain strong. Thanks to the government, all phone companies are required by law to offer a historic customer service guarantee. If your phone company offers an inadequate service in line installation or repair, you receive financial compensation. This law will be maintained and, if necessary, strengthened. In relation to untimed local calls, the law says that phone companies cannot force a residential phone user to pay for timed local calls. The law says that phone companies cannot force businesses to pay for timed local calls. These laws will stay.

Australians in regional and remote areas will continue to receive special help with their phone services in recognition of the special problems caused by distance. The government will keep the price cap regime, which means the real cost of Telstra's average price across a basket of services must fall every year.

There has also been some talk about who will own Telstra. Telstra will remain an Australian company. The government will ensure by law that Telstra will remain majority Australian owned, with no more than 35 per cent foreign ownership. No single foreign interest will be allowed by law to own more than five per cent of Telstra. The chairman and the majority of the board will by law have to be Australian. Telstra's headquarters will by law remain in Australia.

It is unfortunate that we need to continue to remind those opposite that these points I have just made are part of the announcement and part of the policy package that we are offering the Australian people at the next election. Everywhere that I have gone, I have seen Labor making these assertions which are completely untrue as to foreign ownership, timed local calls and the like. So I seek to clear up the record and make absolutely clear what the government's proposal is. Experience has shown that, in Tasmania, especially in the electorate of Lyons, three days before the last election, Labor put round a fictitious Telstra account full of misinformation, which caused a lot of concern to the people in that electorate, and because of that campaign I believe the Labor candidate was able to squeak back into his seat. I am not so sure that that will occur next time round.

In short, the Liberal proposal on Telstra is honest and open for analysis, unlike Labor's history of sleight of hand when it comes to the sale of public assets. Our proposal will protect consumers and guarantees the universal service obligations. Our proposal will significantly reduce Labor's legacy of debt. Our proposal will give all Australians, and especially Telstra employees, an opportunity to buy part of Australia's largest company.

Labor's campaign of misinformation from 1996 will undoubtedly be resurrected; indeed it has been already. But it will not be able to take the shine off the fact that this proposal is good news for all Australiansâ€”consumers, employees, taxpayers and shareholders alike. I commend the Telstra proposal to my fellow Australians.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to pay tribute to the late Justice Bill Zeeman, who died of a brain tumour in Hobart earlier this month at the age of 54. Bill Zeeman died while still serving Tasmania as a Supreme Court judge. In the true meaning of serving, he continued to apply his intellect right up until his death. I believe that on the day he died he was still working on some legal papers. He was a man who had a work ethic second to none. I remember hearing stories that, as a partner in the firm Zeeman, Kable and Page in Launceston, other junior practitioners filing past his office at week's end for the constitutional Friday drink at their local watering hole, would see the silhouette of Bill illuminated from inside working on a file. They would continue to see that same silhouette on their sometimes staggering return home in the early hours of Saturday morning. Some of them believed that nobody could work with such discipline and proffered the explanation that the image they saw was in fact a cardboard silhouette. That was never the case, for here was a man who had unquestioned commitment and self-discipline. As Justice Pierre Slicer said of Bill in an obituary in the Mercury newspaper:

speech.para: His sense of purpose, intellectual rigour and embrace of responsibility, evidence a value system to which most of us can only aspire.

As a partner in the firm Zeeman, Kable and Page in Launceston, some said he was the countervailing force to the larger than life character of the late John Kable. John was the nephew of an equally larger than life character, Reginald Wright, both of whom were from the conservative side of politics, although I must say it is difficult to judge which pigeonhole you slotted John Kable into.

Bill Zeeman was involved in Labor politics. He was seen as the person in that firm who raised the red flag and so counterbalanced an individual as persuasive and demonstrative as John Kable. Bill Zeeman did this very effectively. It was an unusual practice, it was an unusual union of solicitors, but it was one which I understand worked very well.

Bill's life may have been very different if he had been successful in his tilt at entering the Tasmanian parliament. In the early 1970s he lost preselection to enter the Legislative Council by only one vote. If he had been successful, I am sure he would have left his mark politically. Later, in 1984, he also had an opportunity to enter the lower house in Tasmania. On a count back, he would have taken his place in the House of Assembly as Labor member for Bass, but he declined, no doubt largely because the focus of his life had changed and he had a young family.

He was born in the Netherlands and his subsequent career as a lawyer, magistrate, administrator, university chancellor, and supreme court judge encapsulates just how Australia, as a nation of immigrants, through the diversity of its people is that much stronger. Bill certainly gave a lot back to this country, and in particular to Tasmania, in his short life.

I have spoken with a number of legal practitioners who advised that the judgments that he delivered could always be relied upon to be first class. One practitioner went as far as to say that his judgments were of a quality that placed him as one of the finest legal thinkers in Australia. He had a fine legal mind. I shudder to think what it would have been like to appear before him. His legal mind was also recognised overseas and he was in some circles better recognised outside Tasmania than within it. Justice Slicer said it all when he stated:

To many Australians who did not know him, his death has no import. But his capacity to look at death, reflect on it and continue his life's work does. His life tells us that there is a reward in devoting one's skills to the good of the community. His life tells us that the values of integrity, commitment and self-discipline are central to a healthy society.
Bill Zeeman is survived by his wife Anne, sons Mark, Phillip and Justin, and to them I extend my sincere sympathy.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to pay tribute to the memory of a very dear friend and member of my political party who was also a stalwart supporter of the West Perth Football Club in Western Australia, Rosa Townsend. Rosa passed away a couple of weeks ago but her memory will live within the party, within the Labor movement and within that particular football club for many years to come. A woman who was tiny in stature but as aggressive as a terrier dog could be, she pursued issues on behalf of working people in her earlier career as a trade union official at a time when it was not popular for women to be involved or active, or at the forefront of trade union activity.

speech.para: She had a great sense of justice for those who needed representation in the industrial arena and she did that very capably and very competently, not all the time with the wholehearted support of her colleagues in the individual union or in the trade union movement in general. She was one of Australia's real battlers and real representatives. She maintained that aggression into the political arena. She ensured that people like me, when we became public representatives, did our job adequately and faithfully and honoured the ideals we stood for when we entered public office. She was universally liked within the Labor movement in Western Australia, even by those whom she aggressively pursued to make sure that they in turn were doing their job.

Unfortunately, her funeral occurred at a time when the Senate was sitting and neither I nor my wife, nor indeed any of our other Senate colleagues from Western Australia were able to be at the funeral. We did make sure that we were represented at that very sad occasion. As I said in opening, her memory will live forever because we do treasure what she did.

I also want to make a brief comment about the pending retirement of another individual whom I hold in the highest regard. I refer to Barry Young, who is the electoral officer for the Electoral Commission in Western Australia. Barry is moving to what some consider to be premature retirement after many yearsâ€”actually, I think it is all of his working lifeâ€”working with the Australian Electoral Commission. He has faithfully undertaken his duties as an electoral commissioner and is, indeed, universally liked for the very professional job that he did while he held that position. I am sure all colleagues from Western Australia join me in wishing he and his wife a most enjoyable retirement. They have had very tragic circumstances in recent times where their only daughter was tragically taken from them. I am sure that those events precipitated his decision to move out of the Perth metropolitan area and grow trees. We do wish Barry and his spouse all the very best for the future.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 23 December 1997:

question.para: (1) With reference to the `Revised Process for Medicare Benefits Schedule Listing and Review' contained, in Budget Paper No. 2 for the 1997-98 financial year, relating to evidence of efficacy being a prerequisite for Medicare: (a) what percentage of current medical interventions have solid scientific evidence to support them; (b) is the Minister aware of the editorial comment of the British Medical Journal, Issue 303, that `only about 15 per cent of medical interventions are supported by solid medical evidence'; (c) would this opinion cast serious doubt about the estimate of $3.1 million savings by the year 2001; and (d) as there is no dramatic increase in Government research finding to validate the other 85 per cent of medicine, does that mean that evidence-based cost effectiveness is not really going to apply to Medicare.

(2) With reference to the Budget Paper's promotion of `Evidence-based Medicine' as a way to ensure `the most cost effective and medically appropriate outcomes', in particular, one of the Government's `cost effective clinical practice guidelines' projects: (a) is the statement made by the Minister in Parliament on 11 February 1997, that `one thing the Government has done is to contribute money to the RACP to develop guidelines into the most cost effective treatments', a statement in relation to Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS); and (b) how does the Minister intend to develop further guidelines.

(3) Given the terms of the Government contract with the Royal Australian College of Physicians (RACP) specified that these guidelines were to be completed by 31 December 1996: (a) are these guidelines for CFS now available: if not, when will they be made available; and (b) is the Minister aware that the co-chairman of the RACP working party, Dr Loblay, has written publicly that `we do not regard the conditions of grant as binding us', `conditions of grant are not relevant to our deliberations', `As far as I'm concerned they are simply an administrative necessity which enables the bureaucracy to justify the expenditure to their political masters'; and `we did not believe that questions of cost would enter into our deliberations, and indeed they have not'.

(4) (a) Does a member of the Department sit on the working group; if so, was he or she aware of the decision in September 1996 not to do cost studies; and (b) when was the Minister made aware of that decision.

(5) Given the Budget Paper's promotion of `Evidence-based Medicine' as a way to ensure `the most cost effective and medically appropriate outcomes', and given that the RACP working party does not intend to look at cost effectiveness, are they looking at medical outcomes.
(6) Did the Minister advise Parliament on 11 February 1997 that CFS research, including health outcomes research, has not been funded.

(7) Is it a fact that, despite a special ministerial committee, the CFS Review Committee, making recommendations on funding general practice research, CFS health outcome surveys in general practice have still not been carried out.
(8) Is the Minister aware that the previous minister instructed the department to implement CFS Review Committee recommendations but that these have not been carried out.

(9) Is it a fact that CFS consumer groups' requests for funding to carry out health outcome surveys have also recently been denied, the reason given being that the Minister has every confidence in the integrity and process being followed by the working group.

(10) Is it a fact that the RACP working group, despite the emphasis on outcomes in the National Health and Medical Research Council (NBIRC) guidelines and despite the provisions for such outcome surveys under the NHMRC process, does not intend to carry out health outcome surveys.
(11) Has there been any breach of the terms of the contract relating to the CFS Review Committee.

(12) Is the `adoption of Best Practice by the profession' under the Better Practice Payments scheme, a requirement to adhere to clinical practice guidelines of the nature of those currently being produced in CFS, which lack research on appropriate outcomes and lack cost-effectiveness studies.

(13) Can it be confirmed that it is not the Government's intention to reduce Medicare availability of treatments without first carrying out appropriate health outcomes research, as well as cost-effectiveness studies.

(14) Can it be confirmed that the RACP-CFS clinical practice guidelines will not be used to reduce Medicare availability of diagnosis or treatments in CFS until appropriate cost-effectiveness studies are carried out.

(15) Will the department be instructed to ensure that the RACP process complies fully with the NHMRC guidelines for production of clinical practice guidelines current at the time of formation of the working group.
(16) Will the Government provide research funding for CFS health outcome surveys.

(17) Is the Minister aware that the RACP working group has not contacted all Australian researchers with scientific emerging treatments and therefore valuable contributions on diagnosis and treatment will not be included in the guidelines.
(18) Is it lawful for practitioners to itemise to Medicare services delivering emerging treatments in new areas of medicine such as CFS.

(19) Will the Minister: (a) guarantee Medicare funding of any identified CFS emerging treatments until they can be documented and evaluated for cost effectiveness; (b) implement the CFS Review Committee recommendations to provide funds to general practitioners to document emerging treatments; (c) instruct the department to investigate the use and/or the threat of prosecutions to general practitioners itemising services delivering emerging treatments in CFS; and (d) acknowledge the `Catch-22' situation that the department has placed on doctors prepared to scientifically document emerging treatments in CFS

(20) Given that the RACP contract without outcome surveys, without identification of emerging treatments, without cost effectiveness studies only serves to continue this situation: what steps will be taken to correct this matter.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions

answer.para: (1) (a) The percentage of current medical interventions which have solid scientific evidence to support them is not known because of the complex issues surrounding evidence, and its diffusion and adoption into medical practice. However, all medical services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) have been assessed according to the best standards of evidence available at the time of their listing on the MBS, and/or reflect longstanding medical practice
(b) Yes.

(c) The revised process for Medicare Benefits Schedule listing and Review is focused on the assessment of new medical technologies and procedures, where more evidence is likely to be available. Funds are also available to support the collection of data where existing evidence is insufficient for definitive assessment. Under this initiative, existing MBS items will not be reviewed unless they are direct comparators to medical technologies and procedures being assessed or where new evidence raises doubts about their safety, effectiveness and cost effectiveness. The estimated savings of $3.1 million out of a $6 billion program are extremely modest and the Government is confident that it will be achieved.

(d) The Government will be spending $15 million over the next four years to ensure that the best available evidence on new medical technologies and procedures is assessed. As already indicated above, the aim is to assess proposals for new items on the Schedule, not all items currently on the Schedule.
(2) (a) Yes.

(b) With the CFS Clinical Practice Guidelines now in the final stages of preparation (an Exposure Draft was widely circulated for comment in December 1997), there are no plans to develop further guidelines on CFS in the immediate future.

(3) (a) Having sought and received approval for the extension of the contract until 30 June 1998, the RACP working group distributed an Exposure Draft of the CFS Guidelines titled Draft Clinical Practice Guidelines on the evaluation of prolonged fatigue and the diagnosis and management of chronic fatigue syndrome for comment in December 1997. A copy of that Exposure Draft has been sent to the honourable senator. The Exposure Draft is also available on the world wide web site http://www.mja.com.au/public/guides/cfs/cfsl.html The closing date for comments is 16 February 1998 and publication of the final guidelines, as a free standing supplement to the Medical Journal of Australia is scheduled for May 1998.
(b) The Minister is not aware of Dr Loblay's comments.

(4) (a) No Departmental officer is a member of the RACP working group. However, an officer has been an observer at some meetings. The departmental officer is not aware of the decision referred to. This project involves the development of guidelines on the most clinically relevant and cost effective methods of diagnosing and treating CFS. New cost studies are not required in the project outline, only a survey of existing literature.
(b) Since the Department was not aware of any such decision, the Minister was not advised of the matter.

(5) As mentioned above, the purpose of the grant was to enable the RACP in consultation with other relevant bodies and consumers, to develop guidelines on the most clinically relevant and cost effec tive methods of diagnosing and treating CFS. The guidelines were to cover definition, diagnosis, management of the condition and research. The process adopted by the RACP working group in developing the guidelines is described in Part 6 of the Exposure Draft and summarised under the heading Guideline Development in that document's Preface.

(6) While stating that the NHMRC has not specifically funded research for CFS, the Minister advised that a new subcommittee of the NHMRC, the Strategic Research Development Committee, whose role was to advise on the need for targeted research into different health issues, could properly address this issue. The Minister also mentioned the funding provided to the RACP to develop the guidelines. He expressed the hope that if agreement on this matter could be attained, people suffering from CFS would more easily be accepted by the broader medical profession. There was no explicit mention of health outcomes research in the Minister's response.

(7) In its 1994 Report, the CFS Review Committee recommended that a suitably structured survey of the attitudes, knowledge and practices of general practitioners regarding CFS be undertaken to establish a baseline. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners was contracted to conduct such a survey in March 1995 and produced its report the following year. A copy of the Report has been sent to the honourable senator.

(8) No instructions were ever issued to the Department by the former Minister for Human Services and Health with regard to the recommendations of the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Review Committee's report. However, the Government has taken the report seriously and has given effect to the spirit of its recommendations. The production of evidence based guidelines through a process involving consultation with CFS support groups, relevant medical experts and individuals was judged to be a more appropriate way of providing guidance to doctors in the diagnosis and treatment of CFS than the Consensus Conference recommended by the Committee.

(9) The Department is not aware of any requests for funding of health outcome surveys from CFS consumer groups. A number of letters have been sent to the Minister from consumer groups and other individuals expressing concern about the composition of the RACP working group. The Minister's response to the letters included information on the membership of the working group and the statement that he has every confidence in the integrity of that group and the process being followed to produce the CFS guidelines. He also noted that every effort had been made to ensure that consumers and professionals had been able to express their views throughout the process. While one CFS Action Group has sought funding to conduct a "Consumers' Conference", the Department is not aware of any applications which seek specific funding for health outcomes surveys.

(10) Yes. Under the conditions of the grant, the RACP working group was not required to carry out health outcome surveys. However, the RACP working group did generally follow the process recommended and endorsed by the NHMRC which is based on the general approach to improving health outcomes as agreed by Australian Health Ministers. The main purpose of the guidelines is to achieve better health outcomes by improving the practice of health professionals and by better informing consumers about treatment options.

The NHMRC recognises that clinical guidelines should be based on the identification and synthesis of the best scientific evidence, a goal which the RACP working group is pursuing. The RACP working group used the NHMRC process to conduct an exhaustive review and evaluation of the relevant published scientific studies on prolonged fatigue and CFS. Evidence was systematically evaluated and the findings published and cited in the draft guidelines.
(11) The Minister is not aware of any breach of the terms of the contract with the RACP.

(12) No. Nor is it the case that the draft clinical guidelines produced by the RACP Working Group lack research on appropriate health outcomes, since it contains an exhaustive review of current world literature on this aspect.

(13) To attract a Medicare benefit, the Health Insurance Act 1973 (the Act) requires a professional service to be "clinically relevant". A clinically relevant service is defined in the Act as being a service rendered by a medical practitioner that is generally accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient to whom it is rendered. Provided a treatment meets this definition, Medicare benefits can be paid.

(14) The intention has always been that the work will be available as guidelines for treating practitioners. The basis of a valid Medicare claim remains clinical relevance, not rigid adherence to guidelines.
(15) No. The Department will not be so instructed. The process the RACP has followed would in any event obviate the need for such an instruction.

While the contract with the RACP makes no mention of NHMRC endorsement of the CFS guidelines, the Working Group at its first meeting on 21 September 1996 agreed that such endorsement was desirable. The guidelines were, therefore, developed with this objective in mind

(16) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) provides funding for health and medical research on the basis of scientific merit and subject to a rigorous peer review process. The NHMRC does not, as a rule, direct researchers to undertake research in any particular field, although it recognises that particular areas of research may need special attention, including strategies to facilitate the development of further research.
The Strategic Research Development Committee (SDRC) of the NHMRC will examine data on CFS, according to the following criteria, in order to determine research priorities:
. the significance of CFS as a health issue in the Australian context. including impact on sufferers;
. the research currently under way in Australia and internationally; gaps in Australia's research effort in this area; and
. the capacity for additional research to be undertaken in Australia.

It will take several months to undertake this analysis and the results will need to be carefully assessed against other competing priorities. It is expected that this assessment will be completed by April 1998. The issue of health outcome surveys will be considered in this context.

(17) I am assured that the RACP Working Group has consulted widely and made good use of Internet access as well. In January 1997, a letter was sent to 46 organisations (including 21 doctors) seeking written submissions. The RACP working group received 80 submissions in total. Of these, 17 were from individuals and bodies representing alternative organisations and 15 responses were from doctors who were either writing as individuals or as representatives of academia or other such organisations. The circulation of the RACP working group draft guidelines asking for comment provides a further opportunity for all Australian researchers with scientific emerging treatments to provide input.

(18) The basis of a lawful Medicare claim is set out in the Health Insurance Act 1973. A professional service must be clinically relevant, i.e. a service rendered by a medical practitioner that is generally accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient to whom it is rendered. New procedures must be evaluated for safety, efficacy and cost-effectiveness before being listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule. For professional attendances, where no listed procedure is performed, the clinical relevance test still applies. The treatment must still be accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the patient. Some "emerging" treatments may not meet this test.

(19) (a) No. All new procedures must be properly evaluated before Medicare Benefits can be paid. However, the new MSAC may recommend that some treatments which are promising, but as yet unproven, be the subject of further research and interim benefits could be paid in these circumstances.
(b) No. The RACP working group process took the place of the CFS Review Committee recommendations.

(c) No such `threats' have been or are being issued by the Department or the Health Insurance Commission. The test for whether a service attracts a Medicare benefit is whether it is a clinically relevant service as defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973 as being a service rendered by a medical practitioner that is generally accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient to whom it was rendered.

(d) Doctors treating CFS patients have faced a difficult task, trying to sort out which of the vast range of new treatments emerging for CFS over the past decade are worthwhile. This is the reason the Department has funded the RACP to develop and publish guidelines based on a scientific assessment of evidence. The draft guidelines developed by the RACP Working Group fully assess health outcomes and new emerging treatments.

(20) The distribution of draft clinical guidelines by the RACP working group in December 1997 provides the clearest perspective to date of which treatments and diagnostics are generally agreed to be clinically relevant in respect of CFS. The distribution of the final version will enhance this situation. Anyone who believes that the draft contains inaccuracies, makes incorrect conclusions or omits relevant material should take this opportunity to inform the Working Group accordingly.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1063)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 February 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Does the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) have any independently-verifiable information to justify the claim, made in ANSTO's `background information' document, that one third of imported isotope shipments arrive late; and (b) is it a fact, as stated by the former Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr McGauran), that the above claim relates to High Flux Australian Reactor (HIFAR) maintenance shut-downs; if so, how can this claim be reconciled with the claim of the South African Atomic Energy Corporationâ€”now the supplier of molybdenum-99 (and other radioisotopes) during HIFAR down-timeâ€”that only one in two hundred of their overseas shipments arrive late.
(2) Can ANSTO provide a detailed breakdown of imported radioisotope shipments during routine HIFAR shutdowns, giving a break-down of which suppliers are used, the quantities and product range.

(3) (a) Why does ANSTO's background information document say that technetium-99m cannot be imported because of its 6 hour half-life, without going on to mention that the parent radioisotope, molybdenum-99, is widely transported all around the world; and (b) is ANSTO prepared to remove this comment from the background information document and the ANSTO internet site.

(4) (a) Given that ANSTO claims in its submission to the Research Reactor Review that research reactors can be defined as encompassing a range of facilities from subcritical assemblies to prototype power reactors, how can ANSTO justify the comment in its background information document that `No research reactor has ever adversely impacted its community'; and (b) is ANSTO prepared to adjust this to take note that there have been a least three fatal research reactor accidents around the world (namely Yugoslavia 1958, USA 1961, Argentina 1983).

(5) Can ANSTO provide up-dated projections of molybdenum-99 production versus LLW and ILW waste co-production at Lucas Heights from 1997 to the year 2025, assuming the use of low enriched uranium targets.

(6) (a) Leaving aside the general maintenance and development of nuclear expertise, precisely what activities are carried out using the HIFAR reactor in relation to safeguards issues and other `national interest' issues; (b) what other facilities at ANSTO's Lucas Heights site are used for these purposes; and (c) precisely which facilities are used for which purpose (for example, the tandem accelerator ANTARES for environmental sampling).

(7) With reference to ANSTO's background information document which says that, `Costs of spallation sources plus required accelerator range from $US 500 million to $1 billion' and ANSTO's submission to the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste which mentions ISIS (United Kingdom), SINQ (Switzerland) and planned spallation sources (for example, ASTRON/Austria), and goes on to say that `The cost of each of these facilities is around $200 million: How can the above statements be reconciled with each other'.
(8) Does ANSTO have data on the costs of existing and planned spallation sources; if so, can this data be provided.

(9) (a) Is ANSTO aware of the claims of Yongen et al. (Belgian SCK-CEN, IBA) that a Myrrha/ Adonis spallation system is expected to cost considerably less than a commercial 15 MW reactor, and (b) does ANSTO dispute this claim.

(10) With reference to ANSTO's background information document, which says that spallation sources do not match reactors for cold neutrons used in the study of polymers, biological molecules and many other areas: Can this claim be reconciled with the following comments from J W Boldeman (ANSTO Nuclear Physics section):

- the proposed European Synchrotron Source would outperform ILL by a very large margin for most applications in condensed matter studies and would outperform ILL marginally in cold neutron based research

- for applications involving cold neutrons, the dc spallation source significantly outperforms both a 15 MW reactor and AUSTRON, because neutrons are produced in a spallation source with less heat production and it is possible to couple the cold source more effectively to the neutron production target (Boldeman, J W, 1995, `Accelerator Reactor Hybrid Systems', Proceedings of the 1995 Conference on `Nuclear Science and Engineering in Australia, 1995', Lucas Heights, 30-31 October).

(11) With reference to ANSTO's background information document, which says that `A spallation source cannot provide for bulk radioisotope production nor does it enable commercial irradiations': (a) is ANSTO unaware that the Belgian Myrrha/Adonis research and development program envisages the construction of multi-port, multi-purpose facilities used for various purposes including commercial purposes (for example silicon doping) and radioisotope production as well as research : and (b) does ANSTO dispute the claim that multi-purpose spallation sources are feasible.

(12) With reference to ANSTO's background information document, which says that `Due to high maintenance requirements, spallation sources only operate for approximately two-thirds of any year': Precisely what is the basis for this claim, apart from the singular example of the UK facility, ISIS.
(13) Does ANSTO dispute the claim of the Belgian Myrrha/Adonis team that its design promises easier maintenance, repair and upgrading because of its modular, flexible design.

(14) Is ANSTO aware that the Belgian Myrrha/Adonis program is designed, specifically to replace the BR-2 reactor; if so, why does ANSTO continue to peddle the argument that spallation sources and reactors are complementary rather than competing neutron sources.
(15) Is the Minister aware of ANSTO's misrepresentation of American nuclear scientist, Dr Lagu nas-Solar, who has written to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this matter.

(16) Given that ANSTO continues to misrepresent Dr Lagunas-Solar on its internet site: (a) is the Government prepared to direct ANSTO to remove the offending material from its internet site and send a written apology to Dr Lagunas-Solar; and (b) what faith can the Government have in ANSTO's views on the potential for cyclotrons to replace reactors when ANSTO is evidently unaware of the current status of Dr Lagunus-Solar's research program, nor even whether Dr Lagunas-Solar's research is still in progress, and when ANSTO has misrepresented Dr Lagunas-Solar.

(17) (a) Has Dr Lagunas-Solar also been misrepresented by the former Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology (Senator Ellison); (b) does Senator Ellison also quote selectively from Dr Lagunas-Solars's internet site, thereby misrepresenting him; (c) is it a fact that there has been no apology from Senator Ellison; (d) has Senator Ellison continued to misrepresent Dr Lagunas-Solar's views, claiming in Parliament that Dr Lagunas-Solar's letter to the Prime Minister indicates that a `large' number of cyclotrons would be required to service Australian needs, when Dr Lagunas-Solar's comments indicate no such thing; and (e) will Senator Ellison send a written apology to Dr Lagunas-Solar and refrain from misrepresenting him in future.

(18) (a) Was a review conducted in 1997 to determine the feasibility of a cyclotron production of technetium-99m, as claimed by ANSTO; (b) who was on the review committee; (c) can a copy of the committee's report be made available; if not, why not; (d) why was Dr Lagunas-Solar not contacted during the course of this review.

(19) (a) Is the Government aware that neither the Chief Scientist, nor the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), were even consulted before the decision was taken to build a new reactor; (b) how can this be justified; and (c) how can a new reactor be justified in the context of science funding cuts of 10.9% since the Coalition won government and projected cuts of 30% to medical research over the next 2 years.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Please refer to the response to HoR Question No 2345.

(b) Yes. The South African Atomic Energy Corporation (SAAEC) was only one of the suppliers of molybdenum-99 to ANSTO during the extended shut-down of the HIFAR reactor for maintenance in 1995. I am unaware of the basis of the claim attributed to the SAAEC, but I note that the factors that cause delay, identified in Question No 2345, can affect deliveries from South Africa.
(2) The requested data cannot be supplied as commercial-in-confidence issues are involved.
(3) (a) ANSTO's comment about technetium-99m is accurate. It rebuts claims that Australia's requirements of technetium-99m can be supplied from direct imports.
(b) No.

(4) (a) & (b) ANSTO is not aware of any reports of off-site health consequences arising from the operation of a research reactor, including those identified in the question, and its position reflects this.

(5) The current rate of generation of intermediate level waste (ILW) from molybdenum-99 production at ANSTO is about 340 litres per year (comprising 90 litres of primary waste and 230 litres of secondary waste with a lower radioactivity). Based on current projections of molybdenum-99 production, the quantities of this waste could increase by about 20% between now and the year 2005. The quantity of waste generated will depend on the process adopted. ANSTO is currently examining ways for improving the efficiency of its molybdenum-99 production operations, including minimisation of wastes. Increases in molybdenum-99 production are expected to have little impact on the quantities of low level radioactive waste generated.

(6) (a) The expertise established by the operation of the HIFAR research reactor is used directly to undertake assessments for Australian government policy departments and agencies. These include non-proliferation diversion scenarios of specific countries based on knowledge of their research reactor programs, assessments of the environmental consequences of an overseas reactor incident, environmental monitoring to detect clandestine nuclear activities, measures to enhance nuclear safety culture, and safety assessments of visiting nuclear powered warships to Australia.

(b) & (c) The ANTARES Tandem Accelerator is used for investigating the application of signature fission products at minute levels to determine the nature of nuclear activities carried out at nuclear research establishments. However only the operation of the research reactor provides the expertise required to assess the non-proliferation implications of these results. It is through the broad range of multi-disciplinary expertise necessary to underpin ANSTO's activities at the Lucas Heights Science & Technology Centre that the capability is available to undertake strategic national interest assessments.

(7) The full cost of the proposed Spallation Neutron Source at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in the US is budgeted at $US1.33 billion. ANSTO's submission to the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste does not include the statement attributed to ANSTO in part (7).

(8) Yes. Costs of planned facilities are in excess of $US1 billion for the European Spallation Source (5 MW) and the Spallation Neutron Source (1 MW) in the US. Costs were estimated at about $US300 million for the Austrian AUSTRON facility (240 kW) in 1997. The cost of existing spallation sources is difficult to evaluate due to the fact that they are typically former high-energy physics facilities that have been converted to provide a neutron scattering competence.
(9) (a) Yes.
(b) ANSTO notes that Myrrha/ADONIS is still at the concept stage. ANSTO has not seen any detailed costing data and, in the absence of such data, is unable to express a view on this matter.

(10) A modern spallation source of a comparable cost to the replacement reactor would not have an equivalent capability for cold neutron research. The statement quoted from a paper by an ANSTO officer refers to the billion dollar facilities such as the European Spallation Source which will have a competitive performance for cold neutron research. These billion dollar facilities are specifically designed for neutron scattering research and do not have the broad range of applications of a research reactor. The operating costs of such facilities would also be significantly in excess of those for a 15 MW reactor.

(b) ANSTO is aware of claims by Myrrha/ADONIS proponents that multipurpose spallation systems are feasible, but notes that, to date, no Myrrha/ADONIS facility has been constructed to prove its feasibility.

(12) The statement is based on discussions held by ANSTO with directors of spallation source facilities in the US and UK. Further, the Web page for the IPNS spallation source at the Argonne National Laboratory shows the operating time as 52%.
(13) As the ADONIS/Myrrha design is only at the conceptual stage, ANSTO has not seen relevant detailed technical data and, in the absence of such data, is unable to express a view on this matter.

(14) Yes. The Myrrha/ADONIS concept has been discussed for several years. Nevertheless, no commitment has been made to the construction of such a facility. The spallation sources currently in operation are major items of scientific research infrastructure. It is widely recognised by the neutron scattering community that such spallation sources are complementary to research reactors.
(15) (16) and (17) Dr Lagunas-Solar has not been misrepresented.
(18) (a) ANSTO established an informal working group to assess the use of cyclotrons for the production of medical radioisotopes in 1996.

(b) The working group consisted of ANSTO officers and representatives from the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney, the Austin Hospital, Melbourne, and the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism.
(c) No. The working group did not produce a formal report.

(d) Dr Lagunas-Solar was contacted on behalf of the working group and his views sought. Further, an ANSTO officer attended the International Atomic Energy Agency's Consultants Meeting on Molybdenum-99/Technetium-99m Technologies in April 1997, which Dr Lagunas-Solar also attended and discussed his work. During the meeting, Dr Lagunas-Solar expressed the personal view that cyclotron-produced technetium-99m might have a role in a small country or a regional centre with limited infrastructure (for example, no reactor), and a willingness to purchase an 18-30 MeV cyclotron in order to be self-sufficient in "instant" technetium-99m.

(19) (a) & (b) The process that led to the 1997 announcement began in the early 1990s. Following input from the scientific community, the Australian Science Technology and Engineering Council (ASTEC) listed a replacement research reactor as one of its seven priorities for new facilities in its Major National Research Facilitiesâ€”National Program Report (1992). The current Chief Scientist deals with a small number of issues at the request of the Government. The issue of the replacement reactor was not referred to him.

(c) Direct support for science and innovation has risen by 3.5 per cent in the two budgets since this Government was elected. The replacement reactor is being funded on a whole-of-government basis, not at the expense of science and innovation programs.
